posts.text:
Before we came back to Korea to live and work in Gwangcheon, we visited our new apartment and posted pictures of the shell of a place that we would call home. Now we live here and have settled in. We aren’t really decorators, although I think that this place is already slightly more decorated than our apartment in Busan. Anyway, now that we’ve settled in (and the apartment is clean), here is our apartment again.

First of all, the bed is bigger. That was a necessary upgrade.

In Busan, we only had that photo of the three nieces on our wall. Here, we also have Ashley’s work schedule, the calendar that came with the apartment, and the coloring page Ashley and Kaylee did together in March.

In order to get as much of the room as possible, I had to slide the wall next to the computer desk out of the way.

I think this is the first time that I moved that panel of the wall out of that spot. It was so weird.

Rice cooker and electric water kettle on the fridge. Pot of chamchi jjigae (tuna kimchi stew) on the stove.

Other side of the kitchen. We recently moved that pantry over to put the recycle bags between it and the sliding wall. Before that, they were right in front of the door and somewhat unsightly.

My bass amp is in the  outside corner of the apartment to be as far from other apartments as possible.

More of our stuff.

In case you forgot, here is our bathroom. That is indeed our shower. It’s not really that bad. It’s especially nice for when it’s time to clean the bathroom (after scrubbing, just hose everything down…everything).

Shower-toilet proximity.

We usually have a tray of cherry tomatoes on hand. They’re a good snack.

Suddenly, Ashley put up the Decalogue around our apartment door. When I saw her doing it, I smiled widely, because “You shall write [these words] on the doorposts of your house and on your gates” (Deuteronomy 6:9 NASB).

Sorry for the long interim. I suppose at times I could say that, following some blog-worthy events, we felt very tired or had been working much. At other times, though, it was either sheer laziness or neglected thought. I apologize.

So I’ll mention a few of the things we’ve been doing in the past few weeks. First, Ashley wanted to make sure I took a picture of the ramyeon (or ramen) aisle of a Korean grocery store so that you all understand how big ramyeon is in Korea.

Here’s the top shelf, where you can get the cup variety. Pour in hot water, stir it around, and you’ve got stoveless ramyeon (Ashley hates this kind in America, but it’s not bad in Korea).

And this is the rest.

There are so many varieties, and it’s very different from ramen in America. American ramen comes in flavors like beef, pork, chicken, mushroom, oriental, or creamy chicken. They cost about 20-50 cents a pack, including a small brick of noodles and a single packet of flavoring powder. Korean ramyeon usually comes in flavors based on different dishes, such as guksu (a kind of noodles one might eat in Korea), bibim noodles, yukgaejang (a kind of soup), and so on. Others might be known just for their primary taste, like “spicy” or “mild” or “seafood.” Some of them are very spicy. The cost of ramyeon in Korea is more than ramen in America, but the bricks of noodles are larger and most of them come with two packets, one containing the flavoring powder and one containing dehydrated vegetables or miniature pork meat balls (so we don’t eat that one).

___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___

A few weeks ago our school had Sports Day. We went to work on Sunday and took Monday off, because the students’ parents had requested Sports Day be on Sunday (Sports Day is an event parents come to watch). We work at a school where parents pay money, so we went to work on Sunday. But it was okay, because Sports Day involved no classes and very little actual work for us.

Students lined up for the opening ceremony. There was a prayer and, well, it was in Korean so I’m not sure what else. But as you can see from the students in the background, it didn’t start quite yet.

The opening formalities have finished. Now the students are waiting to be split into their stations. And yes, that girl’s shirt says Andrew. They all wore shirts with the name of an apostle on the back.

Eventually, all the students were split into teams and then they went to various stations, competing against each other. To make things fair, every grade was split into two, so there wasn’t an issue of older students against younger students. Two teams, each made up of all six grade levels, broke into smaller groups, with each pair of opposing groups going to a different station. There were classic games like limbo…

…and jump rope…

…and bulls-eye games…

There were also unconventional games like “Try to eat a cracker”…

Run to the crackers, take a bite without touching it with your hands, then run back and tag another teammate. Yes, the women supervising this event did change the crackers every time a student bit one!)

…and “Yogurt drinking”…

(Yogurt in Korea is drinkable. They had to run to the table, open and drink one, throw the empty bottle in the trash bag, then run and tag another teammate.)

…and “Flip the cards”…

In the allotted time, each team tried to flip over the cards for their color. One team wanted as many blue cards as possible, while the other team wanted the cards facing white side up.

And there was one involving what I can only call a Korean version of piñata:

Here I am holding the pole.

Then the students threw hacky sack-like things at it to break the tape seal and open it up.

There was also tug-of-war. I don’t have a picture because we participated. And there was a 100-meter dash. Also no picture because we foreign teachers stood at the finish line and stamped the hands of the students to mark which place they came in. Four students ran at a time, and I had stamp #4. One girl was so upset about getting last in her group that she refused to be stamped. Her mom asked me to stamp her instead so that she could collect the prize for her daughter (4th place got a pencil, while 1st place got four pencils).

Eventually the day was over and we could go home. We were quite tired by then because it was a bright, hot, sunny day. We had also come in around 6:30 to help set up everything (two foreign teachers didn’t, though, having chosen instead to come in at the start of the competition and stay after to help dismantle everything). The results were close. I think the final scores of the two teams were about 10 points apart within the higher end of the 900 range. But even though half the students lost, it seemed that they all had fun.

___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___

We went to Seoul the other weekend because Buddha’s Birthday, a national holiday, was on Monday. Thus we had a three-day weekend. Whenever there’s a three-day weekend, we don’t teach Sabbath school, so we went to Seoul to visit Dr. Closser and Dr. Greig, who are in the country for a month, and to meet Kristina, who came back to Korea.

It’s nothing really new. Last year we also went to Seoul to meet our former professors, and we’ve also seen Kristina in Korea. We didn’t meet with the professors until Sunday evening, as they had work on Sunday. So we spent the weekend alone. We took a Sabbath walk in Seoul’s Children’s Grand Park (which is much bigger than Busan’s Children’s Grand Park). We had purchased some foods (Korean pears, cherry tomatoes, grapes, bread) when we arrived in Seoul on Friday afternoon, so we enjoyed a little picnic on a bench in one corner of the park.

There was a zoo in the park, but it closed at a certain time and I forgot all about that while we took our break to eat (and to relax and talk thereafter). We were still able to see some birds and some of the animals which have windows in their night houses, though.

When you exit the subway station outside of the park, you see this.

Lots of beautiful birds!

People could buy bird feed to attract the birds. (This is a stranger’s hand, not mine.)

Ashley! In front of a nice little waterfall.

재미있겠다! (“That looks like fun!”)

여보와 장미 (Honey* and Roses)
*The pet name equivalent of “Honey,” rather than the food.

Look familiar?

Once dusk approached, Ashley and I went to VIPS! VIPS is a popular Korean restaurant, and we almost went when we were in Busan, but we never got around to it except for one time when there was a long wait. It’s kind of pricey, but we decided to go this time because did I mention that it weekend was our anniversary in two days? Well, it was, so we went.

And I would definitely go again. It’s probably the best buffet I’ve been to in Korea. It’s also a steakhouse, so Ashley and I ordered a steak to share. At first, when the steak came out, I was concerned. It looked hardly cooked at all. But then we realized that it was on a stone. It continued to cook, and we could take it off the stone once it reached our desired doneness. At VIPS, there was a section for making pho, or Vietnamese rice noodles. Somehow, I’ve lived my entire life without eating that. I went back for seconds. You know what else I went back for seconds to get? Salad. If I hadn’t wanted to eat the pho and some smoked salmon (okay, and some ice cream), I could have eaten nothing but that salad that evening. It was good.

Finally on Sunday we met our professors. We didn’t want to show up until we felt safe that they were back from work, so we went to Itaewon, which is probably the most popular place in Korea for foreigners. So popular, in fact, that I felt culture shock when I saw Koreans. I exaggerate, of course, but even the Koreans I saw spoke English. (It often consisted of “Sir, would you like a custom made suit? Very cheap. No? Take my card.”) We also ate lunch in Itaewon, where I had a massive cheeseburger. Look at this thing:

It was HEAVY.

Ashley’s meal was a Mexican omelette, which was also very good, except instead of pinto beans, they used 팥 (paht) beans. It’s a Korean red bean that tastes sweet. Not so good for the omelette.

And we went to a famous English bookstore called What the Book? because Ashley wanted to find a book for the book club she’s in, and also to find some books to use for her classes.

Eventually we met with the professors. We talked with them and caught up with what’s going on with us and with them and the school. And the next day we went with Dr. Closser to meet our friend Kristina (Dr. Greig stayed to do some work before heading downtown later in the day). Oh, did I mention we also met Kristina’s boyfriend? That was something different about this meet-up.

Here we are, taking a walk. (Well, minus me, as I took the photo.)

I took a few other pictures, but they aren’t so great. (I shouldn’t try to take pictures of people while they talk, or I should learn how to do it right!) It was nice to meet everyone again (and quite nice to meet Kristina’s boyfriend; I think he’s quite alright, and we plan to meet up with them again on occasion).

___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___

Last section. I promise.

This past Wednesday was Korean Memorial Day, so we didn’t have to go to work. We went to a nearby city called Cheonan. We ate at a Western restaurant, Ashley did some shopping for clothes, and we went to Independence Hall of Korea, which is a very massive museum complex. In the picture above, Ashley is walking toward it from the parking lot where the taxi dropped us off. This broad sidewalk leads to those two pointy columns in the distance.

…Then it continues a considerable distance to that building which is also in the background.

…And once you pass that building, which is more or less a very stylized gate, you come upon a large courtyard with a semi-circle of buildings before you.

You go from one building to the next to see the history of Korea (starting in building 1), with an emphasis on the fight for independence during Korea’s subjugation under various invading forces, especially the most famous and recent invasion, the Japanese occupation of 1910-1945.

We only had a couple of hours, in order to catch our train back home, so we didn’t see even half of the buildings. But that’s okay, because we’ve already learned so much about the Japanese occupation. Although I must say I was quite impressed with the museums, inside and out.

I didn’t feel like taking too many pictures at this time, though, so I’m sorry about that. It was dimly lit in many places, and I wasn’t sure about flash photography, for one. For another, I wanted just to enjoy the museum. But here are some of the outside:

Here is that building which I call a stylized gate.

A ton of Korean flags. There were just as many on the other side of the sidewalk.

Okay, I lied. Here’s one from the inside. It’s a model of Dokdo, which is a very famous island. Actually it appears to be two islands. Anyway, people outside of Korea or Japan, I think, call them the Liancourt Rocks. In Korea, they are called Dokdo. In Japan, they are called Takeshima. Korea and Japan constantly argue which country these rocks belong to. You can’t really live on them, but I heard from one Korean that it’s not only a matter of nationalistic pride, but also because, well, if you own those rocks, you have that much more fishing space.

Well, that’s all for today. It was quite a bit. I hope that I’ll post again much sooner next time.

(by Brian)

Dr. Pittman stressed in her seminar about the epic tradition that the genre always strived for telos (or end, to be brief), despite not being able to achieve it even when the poems came to a close. If I have misremembered that information, Dr. Pittman, please forgive me and believe that I forgot nothing else.

Our orientation with EPIK is over, and in fact, we were told when we signed our contracts that EPIK is finished with us. We are not employed by EPIK. We are employed by our school districts, and EPIK simply got us to that point.

But getting us to that point was sure a lot of fun and insanity. You’ve probably already read what it took to get us to Korea. That was only half of the intensity. Our first week in Korea was filled with enough study and sleep deprivation to earn ourselves a college degree. They even gave us diplomas:

 

Ashley and I arrived in Korea on the night of Wednesday, February 16. Most people showed up on the standard arrival date of February 17, which was technically the first day of orientation, but the only scheduled events that took place that day were breakfast, lunch, and dinner. I feel bad for the people who got to Pukyong National University at night on Thursday, because Friday morning we had our medical check-up (the Korean government wants to make sure immigrants aren’t users or carriers). And we were told to fast starting 9 PM Thursday night.

Some people had to show up at the auditorium at 7 AM. Ashley and I were in Class 6, so we arrived at 10:20 in the morning. I guess the people in Class 1 got to break their fast sooner, though. At the auditorium, a medical staff had set up several booths. We had to fill out a medical check list and then go to the various booths to have the medical team fill in the appropriate information. We had a hearing test, two vision tests (one for color and one for distance), a “consultation” (which consisted of a woman asking us if we had had any diseases or questions), a height-and-weight check, a blood test, a urine test, and a chest X-ray, which was taken in a bus outside the auditorium. Yep. They had a bus outfitted with a chest X-ray machine.

There’s something you should know about certain buildings in Korea. Many of them are not heated, especially the large parts. Classrooms, yeah. Hallways, no. And it makes sense. No one is supposed to stay in a hallway for very long. So most of us were rather cold while waiting for each station in the auditorium.

And between classes. We had four days of lectures in our orientation. We had to look at our orientation manual to determine, according to our class number, which room we should be in at any given time of the week. From 9 AM to 10:30 we would have a class. From 10:50 to 12:20 we would have another, and then we would have lunch. Back to class at 2 PM until 3:30, and finally our last ESL training lecture of the day at 3:50 to 5:20. Then it was time for supper, followed at 7:00 by mandatory Korean lessons. The official end time of the lessons was 8:10, but they also lasted an hour and a half. When you consider that the first few days of the orientation were spent also adjusting to the time difference, 8:30 at night was pretty much pass-out time.

Most of the lecturers did their best to make sure they didn’t add directly to our exhaustion. I found probably 85 to 90% of the information very helpful, despite much of it being geared toward elementary or middle school, while I had indicated a preference for high school. Probably four out of five lectures or lecturers were also highly entertaining. But having six hours of classes a day, not including Korean lessons, was draining.

We had a break after two days. Half of the people at the orientation got on buses and headed to POSCO, a steel factory in a city about 100 minutes from Busan, to have a tour of the facility and to learn about the industry that helped South Korea’s economy grow. Then they returned to Busan to have lunch at a resort and to watch JUMP, a comedic martial arts show. The other half, my half, took this field trip in reverse. Let me say now that JUMP is one of the best things I’ve seen on stage besides Blue Man Group. But we weren’t allowed to take pictures (for safety purposes with the martial arts choreography), so stop expecting right now.

The lunch was great (except the caterers assumed we all wanted Western silverware and I’ve grown quite accustomed to the flat metal chopsticks and long spoons of Korea), and the tour at POSCO was painful. Most of the tour was by bus. Each bus was fitted with a representative, who spoke to us, through our bus leaders, about the company as we drove by different parts of the property. Whether something was lost in translation or the representatives just didn’t know the technical terms, I don’t know. What I know is that “stuff” was a very common word. We did get to go inside one building and see (from a very far distance) massive bars of cherry-red steel passing by on rollers and being doused with water to cool them down. Even from a hundred or so feet above the ground, we could feel blasts of heat as the bars rolled by. So seeing (and feeling) that process kind of made up for the bus part of the tour.

So we were glad for the break from classes, but going to POSCO meant that several hours of our day was spent on buses, so we were still rather tired upon our return to the dormitory.

Back to classes the next day. And the next. Except on this fourth day of classes, we didn’t have Korean lessons. Because, instead, we had time to work on our lesson plans. There’s something I didn’t tell you yet. All throughout the orientation week, we also had a project to make a lesson plan, with a group of three people, to demonstrate on the final day of orientation. We had to make the lessons for a full class but our demonstrations had to be 15 minutes, so we had to teach the lesson through representative samples of the activities.

And finally we did the demonstrations and sat through the other demonstrations in our class. Then lunch, followed by going back to the lecture hall (which was a good 10-15 minute walk in the chilly Busan winter air, I should add) to hear the reactions to our lesson plans. Then, meeting the supervisors of our POEs and MOEs (Provincial or Metropolitan Office of Education). Ours, from the Busan Metropolitan City Office of Education, was a funny guy but he simply presented a PowerPoint outlining the major points of our contract.

The next day, today (as I write this, but not as I post it, as I don’t currently have Internet), we all went to the lecture hall to sign contracts and then meet our co-teachers, who helped us gather our belongings into their cars so they could take us to meet our schools and apartments.

But that is another adventure.

It’s probably not fair, because sudden obligations and changes of plan happen in all lines of work, but Korea is famous among foreign teachers for being a country where such detours are expected. Our colleagues in the public school system are very familiar with scenarios where you expect to teach a class and, five minutes before the class begins, you find out that the class is canceled for whatever reason. I think it even happens on occasion that you wait for your students and after they don’t arrive for five or ten minutes, someone tells you that the class is canceled.

Well, that sort of stuff has happened to me both in Busan and in Gwangcheon. It’s not so obvious here because we generally know at least a day in advance, or we’re told at the beginning of the day that, for example, periods 1, 2, and 3 for grades 2 and 3 are canceled, and periods 1, 2, 3, and 4 for grades 4 through 6 are canceled. So it’s not quite last minute. A few things, such as the English competitions, have had two- or three-week warnings.

But in a way, generous advance warnings are worse. If I find out that there will be a harassment lecture for all students during fourth period, and third period just ended, well, that’s no big deal. I just have to push everyone for that class back a day. And in fact, now I have a free period. Maybe I badly needed the time for class preparations. Or just to take a breath.

But if we’re given seven days’ warning, we just know that means there’s time for the notice to change. On Wednesdays, by the end of the day, we have to put our “lesson plans” (usually just page numbers) on the school network for the following week (Monday through Friday, meaning we have to take into account what we expect to do on Thursday and Friday). So of course the sudden changes alter those plans, but so do the longer term notices. We think we know what will happen next week, so that’s reflected on our plans. Then they make a change.

We take it in stride, though. I don’t think we’ve had a normal week since we’ve been here (we miss classes both because of these sudden changes and because of national holidays or field trips and whatnot). We just say, “Okay,” and then push our plans back another day or two.

But today began a hint of a sinister change. First, the necessary details:

The final exams are coming up soon. The last day of the semester is July 20, but exams are far before that, so that we can grade the exams and make report cards, and also just because final exams happen about two weeks before the end of the semester in Korea. So two weeks ago it seemed that we were going to have our exams during the first week of July (between July 2 and 6). With that in mind, we were told to have our final exams written by this Friday. Next week, the week before final exams, we planned to review for the exams.

We have to include our page numbers when we save the exams to the school network. There’s a separate file that has a table, so each class has its own cell, and we have to input the page numbers relevant to the questions on the test. Well, today we found out that the school now wants our page numbers by tomorrow, Wednesday, two days before the exams are due. This means we might not be done with the exams, but we have to know which page numbers we will use.

Well, okay, we’ll just hurry our exams along. Most of our classes were canceled today, after all, due to Korean final exams (that is super early, and yes, we learned of the cancellations this morning). But then the head English teacher and his wife (the Korean intermediary) were talking about what was going to be on the agenda for our weekly Tuesday afternoon meeting. I and another teacher were in the office at that time, and here’s what we learned: maybe the school was going to push the exams ahead to start next Wednesday rather than the following Monday. The other teacher present, Stephanie, and I were a little upset about this possibility. We had worked out how far we had planned to get in our shared science class (I teach the low level for science grade 6, she the high) and thus how much material to put on the exam. And due to holidays and field trips for the 6th graders and a few other things, we went more than two weeks without seeing that class, only to meet with them once on the third week, rather than three times. That was last Thursday. There was no school on Friday because the students stayed at school all day on Thursday (until 10 pm) for a science day involving star-watching (too bad it was cloudy that night).

We looked at each other and said, “Well I guess we have to remove questions from the section on magnets from the exam” (which we had just made). Because if they move the exams forward, there’s no way we’ll get to that section before it’s time to review for the final. But of course this wasn’t made official (and in fact our weekly meeting was postponed because the school hadn’t fully decided yet). And we still have to have our page numbers turned in by tomorrow, so we just have to count on having no time for magnets.

It’s also problematic because we have to feature four quiz scores on the students’ report cards, in addition to the final exam. It works out to be about one quiz per month. Most of us planned on having our last quiz at the end of this month, followed by review for the final, followed by the final. If the exams get pushed forward, it squeezes all of that together. There’s a possibility that we could give a quiz after the final, but it depends on how soon the school (or the parents) will want the report cards after the exams.

So it’s quite crazy at times. I don’t really mean to complain or to make Korea sound like the Land of Horrible Schedules, because I’m sure teachers across the world deal with these issues. I just want to let you know just a bit more about what’s going on in our lives. This post just happens to be about one of the less glamorous aspects of our job. In a way, though, it’s kind of exciting. I did feel rather productive today.

This will be just a quick update to keep the blog alive.

It’s raining here. Quite a bit. One of my coworkers, the one married to a Korean, said Korea was having its most severe drought in over a hundred years. That was less than two weeks ago. Within days we had a good rain. And we’ve had a few even better rains since. And this morning I woke up to probably the best rain ever. Any better and it probably would have been bad. I liked hearing the sound of it.

We’re working on grades now. Today the final exam grades are due. We have to have them entered on the network, but they already are there. We graded the tests quickly and even showed the results to the students. But now we have to make their report cards, which are due by 4:30 on Wednesday. It’s quite a bit of work, and I think it’s not much fun. For each class, we have thirteen total boxes of input. One box is for the exam. Another is for the combined scores of 4 quizzes throughout the semester. Ten more are for individual assessment criteria, things like “Can distinguish phonic sounds” for conversation class, and “Can explain weather and the seasons” for science. Finally we have one more box. We have to write three sentences for each student. Things like “She is a kind, friendly student,” “He has greatly improved his English speaking skills,” or “Demonstrates a need for improved social skills.” Nothing too negative, of course.

Anyway, so far I have input the 12 letter boxes for four of my six classes (the exam and quiz grades and the 10 individual assessment points are given letters, ranging from NI for Needs Improvement to E for Excellent). I haven’t yet made any of the full sentence comments in the last box. I’m not looking forward to it.

But who knows? Maybe, for some of the students (which does not necessarily mean either good or bad students), it will be fun. And after all, when they’re finished on Wednesday, we have seven more days of work. For three of those days, the 4th, 5th, and 6th graders will be on a field trip (Monday through Wednesday of the week after next). We have full classes on Thursday and then on Friday, from what I hear, we might not have any classes to teach.

Then it’ll be time to go home for a couple weeks.

끝. Fin. End.

Not yet. No, we have seven work days remaining. But effectively, it’s the end. It’s as if I had been dropped into the middle of Lake Michigan, and I had to make it back to the shoreline. And I’m not there yet, but I’ve finally reached to where I can stand. I don’t have to swim any longer. The beach is but a few steps away.

And after all of that paddling, walking feels a bit weird. I mentioned earlier that we had to make report cards. Before that we had to make report card templates, including writing ten performance comments for each of a few classes, to which we assigned letter grades, such as E for Excellent and VG for Very Good. Before that, we had to grade final exams. Before that, we had to make the final exams. And of course, some of these tasks involved various steps and approvals.

I haven’t gone too much into my schedule, like Ashley has, but I’ll tell you a few details: The first half of the week is heavily weighted. I have four classes Monday, five Tuesday, and six Wednesday. On Monday we receive the students’ English diaries, and we’re expected to return them by Wednesday morning. So we usually spend an hour or two extra on Monday and/or Tuesday working on those. On Wednesday, before we leave work, we’re supposed to fill in our weekly plans for the following work week (it’s usually only a matter of filling in the appropriate page numbers, but sometimes it’s more complicated than that).

As I mentioned, our report cards are due today. That means we had extra work for the past week, and inevitably much of it in the last three days. I stayed an hour after quitting time yesterday to ensure that I’d be done with enough of my report cards so as not to worry about completing them by 4:30 today, considering that today, Wednesday, is my heaviest day, and that I’d only have a few hours of office time.

Well, I finished those report cards maybe between 2:00 and 2:20. My “after school program” (ASP) class is at 2:40. I set to work on filling out next week’s weekly plans. Our head teacher had also told us today that we should fill out not only next week’s plans, but the weekly plans for when the second semester starts, the week of August 20-24. So after my ASP finished, I came back to tackle that week’s plans as well.

It was when that was done that I stood up and stopped kicking my legs, thrashing my arms about the waves. After all that effort, and then I didn’t know what to do. Thursday is already an easy day (four classes in the morning, lunch, then three hours of break before a 3:30 ASP). But the fourth graders are going on a field trip tomorrow. That knocks out 1st and 4th period.

We get off work at 2:30 on Friday (no ASP). Next week, the 4th-6th graders will be on a field trip Monday-Wednesday. It’s likely that Friday will involve canceled classes for school cleaning or a ceremony or whatnot.

Those last few steps to the beach should be pleasant. The waves are calm. The water is clear. There are no sharp rocks to cut my feet. I can take it easy. And when I get there, that beach will lead me to America.

Last week we went for a walk after church with one of the new teachers at our school, who came in late August to replace a teacher who moved back to America at the end of the semester. We ended up walking to Oseosan (오서산), the nearest mountain. It took an hour to walk there, and it was a hot day. We decided to walk up it, but only to a familiar resting spot about 30 minutes uphill. It felt good to get out for a change and get some exercise, so we decided that we should make a weekly habit of going for a long Sabbath walk.

Today, it was a very, very long walk.

We hiked to the top of the mountain.

Today was not so hot. There were clouds, and the breeze was pleasant. I carried a 2-liter bottle of water with me. Our friend Linda made some 김밥 (kimbap), which is rice and vegetables (or meat sometimes) rolled in a layer of roasted seaweed. We planned to eat that 김밥 at the top of the mountain, or as high as we dared go. Linda had never been to the top of a mountain before, and we haven’t reached a summit since leaving Busan, so we kept saying to each other, “Well, let’s see how far we get today.” Wherever we would stop, that would be the top. That would be where we’d eat the kimbap that Linda made and the 약과 (yakgua, a kind of traditional Korean cookie) that I brought.

We decided to climb slowly and steadily, like the victorious tortoise. We didn’t want to hurt ourselves early on and end up quitting.

 At one point, we reached some stairs. You’d think, “Oh yay, stairs!” but you’d be wrong. Unless the terrain is slippery, stairs seem to make us tired quicker. I think it’s because the rise and run of your pacing is set for you, rather than something you can choose yourself. Anyway, there were a ton of these. I liked how the trees popped straight up through the steps, though.

Here’s part of our view about halfway up the mountain. Quite pretty. It was even more amazing once we got to the top, but the pictures are not so great. The sun really limited where I could point my camera.

We met a Korean man at this platform about 3/4 of the way to the top. I took a picture for him, and he took this picture for us.

We kept climbing. We knew from the map near the bottom that there would be 13 markers until we got to what would be relatively close to the peak. We thought we’d at least go to the marker, if not the peak. 

Almost to 13!

When we passed these bushes, we saw the top. It didn’t look far, so I convinced Ashley and Linda that we should try to make it. We passed 13 on the way (we had wondered where that marker was at, as it was spaced a bit farther than the normal interval). So it turned out I was right.

Or was I?

We made it to the top. 

791 meters above sea level, according to that rock.

 

It was amazing. Linda, of course, had every reason to be stinkin’ proud. For one, that was her first time all the way to the top of a mountain. For two, we climbed all the way to the top of a mountain, so we might have been a bit stinky. We went over to a large wooden platform and looked out on the view in the above picture. We were going to eat that well deserved kimbap.

Suddenly we heard a Korean man exclaim, “Kimbap!” so Linda offered him a piece. His friend just ran right over to us so he could have a piece, too. He had a big grin. I think he really likes kimbap, because he ate about three or four pieces. When they came, I said to them, 그녀가 그거 만들었어요. “She made that.” So they were very impressed that a foreigner made kimbap that tasted so good. They kept saying, “Made in USA!” Because Linda shared her kimbap with them, they brought their camping stove over (by the way, some people had set up tents on top of the mountain on this large wooden platform, which seems like a rather fun idea) and shared some ramyeon and an apple with us. It was nice to have an impromptu, friendly picnic with strangers, even though we could barely speak one another’s languages. Maybe that made it even more fun.

When the picnic was finished, we walked back down the mountain. It was already close to six o’clock, and I thought it would take about an hour to go down, perhaps a bit more. It would be a little dark once we reached the bottom. We made a mistake, however. On the way up, we had seen a sign that pointed another way down the mountain to the temple that is somewhat near the bottom. It said the distance was shorter, and we contemplated taking that route on the way back. The stairs were much easier to go down than up, though, so we almost didn’t take that different route. We saw some Koreans taking that route though, so it increased our confidence that this would be a good path to try.

Well, it wasn’t. We really should have taken the stairs. The path was a bit steeper, had no stairs, and was full of sticks and leaves and rocks. We had to go down much slower. We found some sturdy sticks and used them to guide us and to help us keep our footing. For inexperienced Linda, though, it was of little help. She slipped a few times and at one point even hurt her wrist from landing on it. Thankfully, it wasn’t broken.

The path was also a bad choice because, unlike the stairs which were on the edge of the forest cover, this new path was right in the middle, which meant that the approaching sunset was approaching all the faster. So we had to take it easy so we wouldn’t fall, but we also had to go fast enough not to be caught in the middle of a mountain forest in pitch black. Eventually we had to use our cell phones for light. Relatively soon after that, we made it to where we were no longer under so many trees. The moon was our friend. So were the streetlights and homes we were approaching.

So we learned some valuable lessons today. One is to bring a flashlight on all future hikes. Even if we only plan to go on a three-hour trek starting at 8:00 am. The second is to choose the stairs for the descent. The third is to bring extra kimbap.

(by Ashley)

I have to  say, our apartment building is not in an ideal location. Tonight Brian and I wanted to go to Seomyeon and look around. Seomyeon metro station is right below an underground mall and Lotte department store/hotel. So we went to Seomyeon ate some street food, which was delicious, but probably overpriced, and I even did a little shopping in the underground mall. It was a nice outing, but the commute was not so nice.  Since our apartment is in the boonies and we don’t yet understand the bus system, it took us 30 minutes to walk down the gently sloping street to the metro station to take the train to Seomyeon, and it took 10 minutes from Dong-Eui University station to Seomyeon. Forty minutes one way. Since our apartment happens to be up the side of a mountain, on the way back we were quite unhappy to be  walking uphill for half an  hour.

Apart from our location in the boondocks, our apartment does seem to need some TLC. The previous tenant did not clean, so there are things to be done. The apartment is also not very shiny and new–some newer apartments have automatic locks and cool gadgets, but not ours–and the outside looks a bit run-down, but from the first moment I stepped inside, I saw the potential. The apartment is small, but much bigger than I expected, and it will be cozy once everything gets all put in place. Right now all of our luggage and clothes are still all over and there are things from the previous person that need to be thrown away. Yikes.

Anyway, we actually have a “two” bedroom place with a small room I assume could fit a tiny bed. Right now it just has our wardrobe and a few left-over things.  Next to the kitchen there is also what I tend to refer to as the yucky room. It’s an unheated room with tiled walls and floors that smells weird and seems made to get wet. Many Korean apartments I’ve seen on Youtube have rooms like this, but I don’t know what they are for. I guess the previous tenants used it as a storage space for the Christmas tree.  And so will we.

[Note: I wrote this about 4 or 5 hours ago, before we got Internet. Also, this post mostly deals with everything that led up to being in Korea.]

I’m listening to cars driving on the highway. If I had grown up in a city, I would say that I feel like I’m home. From where I sit, on a dormitory bed, I can see apartment buildings, trees, and cars driving on the right side of the highway. There’s a bridge near the sea that fades into the morning fog.

But I’m not at home. I’m in the dormitory of the Daeyeon Campus of Pukyong National University in Busan, South Korea, and a dorm room is hardly home to a full-time student, much less to someone who will only stay there for a week. But in eight or nine days, Ashley and I will move into an apartment, and I will call it home.

We got to the university around eleven last night. For those of you in America, that’s somewhere between six and nine in the morning, depending on your time zone. The journey was long. We started traveling before five in the morning and arrived at the dorm 28 hours and 14 time zones later. But the journey started two years ago. Ashley and I found out about EPIK (the English Program in Korea) when Isaac Lee handed us a flyer advertising the program at the Andrews University International Food Fair. We had been engaged for a month or two. We didn’t have any plans. And we both liked the idea.

We didn’t decide on Korea right away. We thought about jobs we could get in the States and places to live. Ashley briefly considered becoming a registered dietician, and I thought about getting a PhD or getting a job in some company’s shipping and receiving department to make ends meet for a few years before resigning myself to the glamorous life of an adjunct composition instructor. Ashley could never stay away from her true calling in English, though, and she has enjoyed tutoring Korean students via webcam over the last few years. Me, I just really want to eat Korean food.

I have some right now. Well, it’s a beverage, but it’s Korean. It’s the first thing other than water that I’ve consumed since my arrival in Korea, and I think it’s called 잔치집 식혜 (janchijip sikhye). It’s a rice beverage I got from a vending machine for 600 won (54 cents), and it tastes pretty good. I even get a grain of rice to chew on sometimes, which is good, because it’s serving as my breakfast. Ashley and I were too tired and lazy to make it to the cafeteria on time.

So what kind of journey has it been? For the sake of brevity (if that’s possible) and because of my body’s demand for rest, I’ll give you a list of what we have had to do to make it here. (It’s very long and tedious and I will understand if you want to skip it.)

  • Research EPIK and other overseas teaching opportunities.
  • Decide EPIK seems like a good decision.
  • Apply in early summer for August intake. Includes an 11-page application and two scanned letters of recommendation.
  • Get fingerprinted ($15 each) for state criminal record checks ($30 each)
  • Get rejected for August because positions were already filled.
  • Apply as soon as applications are accepted in early autumn for February intake.
  • Pass webcam interview and receive instructions for submitting official documents.
  • Get fingerprinted ($15 each) for national (FBI) criminal record checks ($18 each) because of a new Korean immigration law requiring national-level record checks.
  • Mail FBI CRC requests and return envelopes Priority Mail ($20 total).
  • Have Ashley’s MA and BA, my BA, and our state criminal record checks apostilled ($1 each document) for international recognition. Involved a trip to Grand Rapids, MI.
  • Mail documents to Korea ($80 for FedEx shipping because positions are first-come-first-served based on receipt of official documents and EPIK wanted tracking numbers; joint application means we used one envelope for the both of us thank goodness!):
  1. Two copies of signed applications
  2. Apostilled copies of diplomas (and copies of the apostille)
  3. Original hard copies of letters of recommendation (and copies)
  4. Apostilled state criminal record check (EPIK allowed American applicants to submit these while waiting potentially 13 weeks for national record checks to arrive from the FBI, and we can submit the FBI record check when we arrive in Korea). Oh, and copies.
  5. Passport-type photos (free because we made some on our own)
  6. Copy of passport photo page (“free” because we already had passports)
  • Wait.
  • Wait some more.
  • Join a Facebook group of people who are applying and have other people to wait and be anxious with.
  • Receive FBI CRCs in the mail. Turns out we’re not criminals.
  • Mail FBI CRCs ($20 total for Priority Mail and return envelopes) to the US Department of State to be apostilled ($8 each).
  • Receive apostilled FBI CRCs in the mail.
  • Receive Notice of Appointment (NOA) and a copy of the contract in the mail!
  • Apply for E-2 (teaching) visa ($45 each, plus $20 Priority Mail shipping with return envelopes):
  1. Visa application page
  2. NOA plus copy
  3. Signed contract
  4. Passport
  5. Photocopy of passport page
  • Receive phone call. Contract not valid because of a stamp that says “This contract will only be valid upon submission of the following document(s): FBI CRC.”
  • Try to explain to the Korean Consulate in Chicago that EPIK doesn’t need the FBI CRC until we get to orientation.
  • Contact our EPIK coordinator, who tells us (thank the LORD) that so many people had problems with the Chicago Consulate that he’s sending new contracts (sans invalid stamp). Saves us the $80 to ship FBI CRCs pronto and wait for new contracts.
  • Receive new contracts and ship them Express to the consulate ($14 – I put both contracts in one envelope but with cover pages for each so they would find their appropriate application).
  • Buy plane tickets despite not having visas yet, because prices are going up ($1425 total).
  • Receive visas.
  • Go to Grand Rapids again to have my fresh-off-the-press MA apostilled ($1).
  • Panic. Freak out. Come to terms.
  • Pack. A lot. Including the original and a copy of pretty much every document we have.
  • Go to Chicago Midway Airport (thanks, Dad and Grandpa, for driving us there).
  • Get on a plane to Detroit.
  • Get on another plane to Tokyo.
  • Hear my name called IN JAPAN by someone I’ve NEVER MET BEFORE. It’s Kyle, a guy on our Facebook group who recognized me and who knew we shared his final flight to Korea.
  • Meet a few more people from the EPIK program.
  • Get on yet one more plane to Busan.
  • Clear customs.
  • Exchange US dollars for won. Feel like a MILLIONAIRE.
  • Take a taxi (my first taxi ride ever and it’s in another country).
  • Almost get lost because our driver understands “Pukyong University, Daeyeon Campus” but not “dormitory.”
  • Finally find the dormitory (after a student pedestrian looked at a printout we had of the campus with the dormitory circled that EPIK had on their website). Taxi cost: 30,000 won ($27.19).
  • Check in. Cost for an extra night for early arrival: 36,000 won ($32.63).
  • Total cost: -$350. EPIK will give us 1.245 million won each as flight reimbursement. That comes out to $1,128 for each of us. The total is $2,256. The cost of application and postal expenses is $481. That cost plus the $1425 for our flights is $1906. So we will actually make $350 just for applying to EPIK and showing up.

It’s been rather fun. As long as our flight was (the longest was 13 hours), it wasn’t that bad. We had two meals, a mid-flight snack, and there were four movies on. I also had my iPod and some books to read. And I slept some.

Meeting people in Tokyo was strange. Ashley and I were headed toward our gate and passed a coffee shop when I heard someone say, “Brian?” I knew that not many of the Japanese people walking in our same general direction would be named Brian, and I also knew that Kyle was going to be looking for us.

So I turned. Kyle wears a hoodie on Facebook, but I could still tell it was him. “Kyle?” Yep. A fellow EPIKer, Zach, was getting coffee and we all decided to stick together. After we moved to our gate, a couple more people showed up. Jason and Zach went for a smoke and a girl named Rachel came up to Kyle and asked if we were all teaching for EPIK, prefacing her question by saying that she wouldn’t normally walk up to a stranger and ask them why they’re on a certain flight. A later revelation told us why she had seemed a bit apologetic in approaching us: she didn’t know about the Facebook group. She just saw a few non-Japanese people sitting at her gate and wondered if we were like her, if we were EPIK teachers.

And we were. We are.

One of Korea’s two most important holidays happened this weekend. Chuseok (추석) is considered Korea’s version of Thanksgiving. Unlike American Thanksgiving, it is determined according to the lunar calendar, not the solar calendar. This year, Chuseok fell on September 30, a Sunday. The day before and the day after Chuseok are national holidays, so we had Monday off from work. Today, Wednesday, is another public holiday, Foundation Day. So most schools gave their students and teachers Tuesday off as well.

We took advantage of the five-day weekend to visit our first hometown outside of America: Busan. We left on Sunday morning around 7:30, taking a train to Cheonan, where we arrived an hour later and waited about 50 minutes for our four-hour train to Busan. (You can see why we don’t often go to Busan.)

Outside of Busan Station

We arrived after 1:30 in the afternoon. To pass the time until we could check in at our hotel (3 pm), we put our carry-on suitcase in a locker and ate lunch at Lotteria. It sounds like a place to buy a lottery ticket, but it’s the Korean equivalent of McDonald’s, and its name comes from Lotte, which is one of the big companies in Korea. We tried their food a few times in the past, but we always hated it. Their beef hamburgers were tasteless. However, someone once told me that their chicken burgers were pretty good, and I’ve discovered that that is true. So I ordered the Hot Crispy Burger set, while Ashley hoped that a Hanwoo Bulgogi Burger, made with traditional Korean beef, would be better than the normal beef patties featured at Lotteria. It was probably made with the cheapest grade of hanu (also spelled hanwoo, even though there’s no ‘W’ sound in that word whatsoever; same goes with Daewoo), because Ashley said it wasn’t all that impressive.

Our hotel, E Fashion Hotel in Choryang, was one small block away from Choryang Station, which is one stop from Busan Station, so after we ate, it wasn’t long until we arrived at our hotel. We checked in and then promptly did nothing for a few hours. After six hours of travel, and probably not the most nutritiously energizing of lunches, we just wanted to lie down and watch TV (it seems we watch significantly more television on vacation than we do in our everyday lives, since we have turned on the television in our apartment probably two times since we moved in).

We managed to find a good show, despite not understanding Korean. In my students’ weekly English diaries, I read that many of them like a show called Running Man. That’s the show we watched. In this episode, a group of about a dozen people were in a room inside what appeared to be a factory for making subway trains. One by one, each person left the room to go hide somewhere in the facility. They wore T-shirts with their team’s color, and on their backs were tags with their names on them. The goal seemed to be the last person (or team) standing, meaning that no one from another team has removed your name tag.

Eventually we got hungry again, and headed downtown. We went to Emilia, a buffet. We went there once before, but it was a bit different this time. The weekend price was covered up to match the weekday dinner price, so I’m guessing that the restaurant is trying to encourage more customers to come. After we ate, we took a brief walk through Jagalchi, the famous fish market of Busan. I expected many of the fish stands to be closed (and they were, either because it was Chuseok or because it was after 9 pm), but I didn’t expect the fish eateries to be opened. Many of them were, and we saw dozens and dozens of Koreans eating at these holes in the wall.

After this, we went to find a cab to take us back to our hotel. Sure, we could have taken the subway, but the distance was not far, so the price was barely more than the cost of two people on the metro. In addition, Ashley’s legs were still extremely sore from Saturday’s adventure on Oseosan, especially when walking up or down stairs. It took some time, though. We stood in one spot where we saw a couple successfully hail a cab. We saw an old man with a can stand along the road before us, waiting for a taxi to pick him up. One cab almost stopped for him but kept going once the driver got close to see that it was an old man with a cane. So we didn’t want that cab to stop for us, not if the driver wouldn’t pick up a poor old man. But eventually we got back to our hotel.

The next day our friends Brian and Kathleen contacted us to meet for lunch at a Thai restaurant in Nampo-dong. So we met them and went to Arun Thai, which is a very good restaurant. Check out our food:

The chicken pad thai I ordered. It was awesome.

The red curry Ashley ordered. The rice was bear-shaped!

Ashley liked this hanging chair in one corner of the restaurant.

Then we went to a place called Red Velvet, which is a nice little cupcake shop. We each ate a cupcake (much thanks to Brian and Kathleen, who paid). Ashley got the dark chocolate cupcake, while I ordered the namesake cupcake. Ashley liked mine better.

I meant to take a picture of the shop once we left, but I forgot. All I got is this picture of the design along the upper wall from where I was sitting.

For dinner, we met Mr. Jung, one of the English teachers from Jurye Girls’ High School, where I worked last year when we lived in Busan. We went with Mr. Jung to T.G.I.Friday’s, and he said that as guests in his hometown, he would treat us. Of course, he also said that Busan is like our hometown too. I affirmed that indeed, it is our first hometown outside of our home country.

Mr. Jung said that the students at Jurye miss me. I asked how the new native teacher was doing, but he said that the students don’t like her as much because she’s too strict. I thought out loud, Well at least I hope she is a better teacher and that the students are learning more from her, but Mr. Jung said he wasn’t sure. He doesn’t teach with her. I guess the new teacher teaches mostly with Mr. Lee (the head English teacher) and Ms. Park, unlike my situation from last year, when I had five co-teachers.

We discussed various other things, including his family situation. He became a father a few months before we left Busan, and I guess he and his wife are now on their way to being parents doubly. He also said that they plan to visit America after a few years, so they will stop by and meet us. I caused him a moment of confusion by saying, “Well, then, you are welcome,” because he at first wondered what he had thanked me for.

The next day, Tuesday, we met Mr. Lee at his apartment for lunch. He was very happy to see us. He said that I looked skinnier and that Ashley looked prettier. Mr. Jung had only met Ashley briefly once at our co-worker’s wedding, so he couldn’t comment on whether she was prettier now, but he had also made the remark that I looked skinnier. I don’t feel skinnier but I appreciated the compliment. Normally, if we visit Mr. Lee, his wife and mother-in-law are home. This time, however, only he and his own mother were there. His mother prepared us a wonderful lunch, although she kept telling her son to apologize to us that it was not so delicious since Mr. Lee’s wife wasn’t the one who made the food. I don’t know, though, because it certainly was delicious.

매우 맛있었어요! (It was very delicious!)

While we were eating the food, I asked Mr. Lee if the new native teacher eats Korean food well, but he said never. She doesn’t like Korean food at all. She started out by eating a bit of rice and soup for lunch at school, but now she brings her own lunch. Some people just don’t like Korean food much, and I guess I’ve finally now heard of someone who doesn’t.

Mr. Lee showed me the school newspaper that he and some of the English teachers and students put together. It looked very nice, and he gave a copy for me to keep. Ashley and I looked through the newspaper, which looks a bit more like a magazine actually, and we were very impressed. I told Mr. Lee to tell the students I am proud of them. After lunch, we had a dessert of apple and Korean pear slices and traditional Korean snacks. Ashley told Mr. Lee how much she likes Korean pears, so when we left his house, he gave Ashley a bag of four large Korean pears, plus an apple! (To buy a single Korean pear at the store costs around 3500 to 4000원, or $3.15 to $3.60.) Mr. Lee walked with us to the bus stop, where we took a couple of pictures and said goodbye.

Finally, we met Brian and Kathleen once more in Nampo-dong. This time we went to try a new Indian restaurant. The name of the restaurant is “New Little Indian Restaurant,” or something like that. The menu looked fantastic and it was hard for me to choose what to get, but eventually I settled for Tandoori Lamb. It turned out that all of us chose some sort of lamb dish. Unfortunately, the waitress misremembered our order (she was Indian and spoke perfect English, so it wasn’t a language thing) and came out with chicken vindaloo for Brian instead of lamb vindaloo, and chicken dopiazza for Kathleen or Ashley (they both ordered the same thing) instead of lamb dopiazza. When she took it back to the kitchen, we saw the chefs yelling at her, so we felt kind of bad. Brian and Kathleen said they’d give the place another shot before writing it off. But as for me, the tandoori lamb was wicked delicious. During our dinner, we had an interesting conversation about Brian, because the waitress said that he looked like a movie star. He wondered which one. I guess lots of people tell him Morris Chestnut, although he doesn’t seem to agree. Finally she said Forrest Whitaker, although he looks almost nothing like Brian. I think Brian disagreed more with that than with Morris Chestnut.

This is Brian.

Our last outing in Busan was to Baskin Robbins. We had chosen Red Velvet between the two on Monday, so we went here after supper on Tuesday. I planned on buying this round as Brian paid for the cupcakes, but he snuck in and paid while I wasn’t looking. That jerk.

After ice cream, we went to the subway station and parted ways. We had an early trip ahead of us. Train tickets for Chuseok weekend sold fast, so that the latest train out of Busan we could get was at six in the morning. We woke up, got ready, and went to Busan Station to board our train. Luckily, this time we rode the KTX to Cheonan-Asan station, so that leg of the journey was only two hours rather than four. We slept most of the way back to Gwangcheon. And also once we got back to our apartment around 10 am. We were quite tired. And now I am tired once more. In fact, it’s time to sleep. Good night.

A few (okay, maybe several) weeks ago our school went on a field trip. Where did we go? We went to EVERLAND! Everland is a famous amusement park in Korea. We knew about it for about two weeks in advance, which is quite a generous notice in Korea. Therefore we feared every day that someone would come and tell us, Oh, nevermind, we’re not going to go to Everland after all.

Unfortunately, Ashley was not feeling well on the particular day we decided to go. She told me to go and have fun anyway, and when I arrived outside of the school and told my co-workers that Ashley was sitting this one out, they said all the more reason to scope out the good parts this time and to go again. I also found out that Brad, the head English teacher, was skipping out because his back was bothering him.

So we went. There were to be two foreign teachers on each bus, Ashley and I on a bus with the second graders, but now I was the only one. I saw down toward the back near some students. I don’t teach many of the second graders, but I was near some of those I do teach. Two girls, whose English names are Sarah and Alyssa, talked with me the whole way. They are so cute and funny. On the way back to school, Sarah sat with someone else and Alyssa insisted that I sit next to her. She taught me how to play 묵 찌 빠, which is like 가위바위보 (scissors rock paper), but with some added rules. And some other students, ones I teach and ones I don’t, kept giving me chocolate and snacks. Korean students sure know how to share.

About two hours later we arrived at Everland. One foreign teacher got lassoed into helping watch the lower level students who didn’t want to ride on any rides, so we didn’t hang out with her (but she, having plans to be in the area the next day, stayed to have some fun after we left, which was merely four hours after arriving—it was a Friday, though I imagine any other day of the week also would have resulted in an “early” departure, this being an elementary school field trip and all). That left Linda, Alex, and me. We wandered a bit to decide what to do. We quickly thought, T-Express (the world’s steepest wooden roller coaster). We made our way to the T-Express and immediately decided No. Once we saw the woman with the sign that read “180분,” we turned around. Three hours is quite a long wait.

But that’s how it was there. We rode one roller coaster, the Rolling X-Train, and we waited about 90 minutes. The ride lasted perhaps 45-60 seconds. It was fun, but as Alex theorized, there just aren’t enough roller coasters at Everland to accommodate all the people that were there that day. (We don’t know if the crowd was a normal size or not, since Korea is crowded, but on the other hand we saw more school uniforms than casual clothing, suggesting that every school in Korea had the same idea for a field trip on the same day.) One large attraction was even shut down that day for whatever reason.

Every time we saw some of our students, we asked them, “How many rides did you ride?” “One,” they would say, or even, “Not yet.”

I edit and comment on the weekly English diaries for the fourth grade students. When we came back to school the next week, I read Herald’s diary, wherein he said that he rode the T-Express, bumper cars, and three or four rides I can’t remember. I thought, “How did he have the time?” It turns out he bought an express pass for those rides which have them (T-Express being one of them). We should have thought of that.

But Everland is quite nice. We didn’t see everything, but we might go back (and buy express passes, if we do end up taking the effort to go there again). When we only had a short time left before the departure, we discovered the Four Seasons Garden area. Quite beautiful.

And playful.

Anyway, I can’t complain. It was free and a day off from teaching. Also, I got a lot of exercise from walking around and I practiced my queuing patience skills (though not at the same time).

Whew! It’s midnight right now as I begin to type this. This (I hope) will be a quick post, because I need to get to sleep.

About ten days ago we finally learned when the final exams will be for English classes at our school. The 26th through 28th of November. About a full week or two earlier than our head teacher had expected based on his three years here. We were given until the 16th to turn in the first draft of our exams for review, which is today (it’s 12:04 AM at the moment of this sentence). We were all rather shocked. I think you can guess that we’ve been busy.

We also have to have four quizzes for each class, which have to be finished in time to put the grades on the students’ report cards (which I imagine will be due at least a week before the last day of the semester). Most people have two or three quizzes given for each class so far. So some of us have also worked to squeeze in quiz number three or four before the time for exams. Some classes will need to have a quiz after final exams (which is not an entirely new thing – due to odd schedule changes last semester, Stephanie and I had to give quiz number four to the sixth grade science classes after summer finals). I already had three quizzes in most classes, so I didn’t need to rush as much as a few other people, but I wanted to get through quiz number four anyway, just in case of sudden and probable class cancellations or if I end up deciding to give a fifth quiz (which is an opportunity for the students to have the lowest quiz score dropped). So I guess I should say I kind of brought this (some of it) on myself.

So with all of the exam-writing, quiz-writing, quiz-grading, and various other things going on at school, we’ve all been putting in some really packed days. Which is good. I feel very productive and not at all like I’m deadweight at work. Though if I had a day or two like that next week, I wouldn’t mind! (I know that we English teachers in Korea don’t have quite the work load that Korean teachers have, so I wonder what kind of mess they have to deal with around this time!)

Ashley and I stayed late at work three days this week. Almost two hours on Tuesday and Wednesday, and a full two hours today. When we left the English teachers’ office, the hallway was nearly pitch black, and only a few Korean teachers remained on the other side of the building. On Tuesday and Thursday we came home, made supper, and did more work, which we had brought home. (I just finished Thursday’s work before beginning this post.) The only reason we didn’t bring work home Wednesday was because we had a plan to go to our co-worker’s apartment for FAJITAS. With REAL PINTO BEANS. It was amazing and a much-needed break. Thank you, Linda.

Well, I realize that that was a rather abrupt change in tone and topic, but as I said, it’s late and I should go to bed. I just thought I’d share what we’ve been up to lately (and to receive a cathartic effect from writing this recent activity).

The first snow came. It came on Wednesday. It came with lightning. It came with thunder.

Before, there was no snow. In fact, even last winter there was no snow, because we lived in Busan. Busan has milder weather. I guess there is a bit of snow there now, but last year there was but a scattering of flakes that I observed on the way to the grocery store one day. Not one flake stuck. Ashley thinks I made it up. We saw snow on Jeju Island in January, because the bus from one side of the island to the other crossed the mountain. Once we had finished crossing, there was little snow.

So the last time I really spent considerable time in a snowy land was when I lived in Michigan at the beginning of 2011. I have not lived in snow since moving to Korea. Yet now I wake up, walk outside to go to work, and my feet are in snow. The trees are covered with snow. The students are playing with the snow. And I think it’s here to stay. So I imagine I’ll see it every day until spring. But I’m not sure. I don’t know if the snow in Gwangcheon remains or if it comes in doses. I guess I’ll find out.

That first snow on Wednesday was something called thundersnow. On Wednesday evening, we (foreign teachers) received text messages from Teacher Heather. She is the Korean who is married to the head English teacher, who is Canadian. She teaches English classes and is also the intermediary between the Korean side of the school and us. She told us to come to school one hour later than usual. So when we walked to work the following morning, the sun being a little higher in the sky, we saw students playing in the snow and sliding on the ice. It was a happy sight.

Yesterday the students had an official exam, I think some kind of province-wide standardized testing. All of my classes were canceled, so I worked on writing comments for student report cards. I didn’t see very much of the students until lunch time. When we came back from the cafeteria (which is in a different building), the students were playing in the snow. They were throwing the snow at each other. And they threw the snow at me. It was fun.

Hello. 오랜만이에요! (Long time no see.) It’s been a while. Let me tell you what we’ve been up to.

To start with, we went home for a couple weeks (most of you knew this already). It was great, and it was relaxing. We didn’t have much time, though, so if we didn’t get the chance to see you, please understand. I spent much time playing with my three wonderful nieces. I was very excited because the youngest one played with me, too. Before I moved to Korea, she was very fussy (she still is) and wouldn’t let anyone near her other than her mother and grandmother. When I was home in July, she still didn’t know me very well. Therefore, I was still on the NO list. But this time…this time she knew me. She had seen our photos around the house and so now she knew who her Uncle Brian was (even if she called me “Uncle Tian”). And as fun as it was, three little girls (and a large family beyond that) is not exactly relaxing, even if it’s refreshing to be home with family after months in a foreign country.

So we went to Maryland and saw Ashley’s family. Now there…there we relaxed. For a couple of days Ashley and I stayed in her Aunt Sharon’s house and just did nothing. If people wanted to see us, they came to see us. And they did, and after we had rested a couple of days we also went out of the house. I can say nothing other than that it was fun.

Now, fast forward to Korea. Why? Because you’re mostly familiar with what happened in America, and this is a Korea blog, that’s why.

On January 14, we resumed work. It was not ordinary work. The normal semester will not resume until this coming Monday, and it will last for only one week. That will be the end of the 2012 school year, and the 2013 school year will start on March 4 (the first weekday of March that isn’t the national holiday falling on March 1). Instead, at work we taught winter camp.

In Korea, even during vacation, students often study. At our school, we had English winter camp for two weeks of the vacation. About a third of the school’s students signed up to take winter camp, which is an intensive program only in English. Normally, the students take only two English classes a day, and the rest of their schooling is in Korean. However, we taught them for every class in the morning, and then for one class in the afternoon, and then we had activities for two class periods to end the day.

We started a little later than usual, and we taught the same students each day. I had a group of nine second-graders and one third-grader. Ashley taught a group of nine first-graders and two second-graders. We started the day with morning devotion, a ten-minute slot scheduled before our first class. In my class, we sang an English Bible song and did a very short memory verse. Then we had our first class, “Conversation.” I put that in quotation marks because even though the next class was “Reading Comprehension,” and the one following was “Grammar,” we didn’t follow that pattern at all. We simply went, page by page, through the books we had.

We all had short books to use with our groups. Each student had the textbook, the accompanying workbook, and a winter camp booklet. The winter camp booklet had a page for each day of winter camp. There was a space to put that day’s earned stickers, an English diary entry for the day, and one or two sentences about an English book the students would read after lunch.

So when we first started work on Monday, we didn’t know which group we would have or what we would be doing. We simply took the books to the classrooms, distributed them, and opened to page one. Fortunately, the books were decent. It wasn’t difficult to teach with them, and it wasn’t too difficult to throw in some activities to make the book more interesting.

After three class periods (with a twenty-minute break between the first two), we had lunch. The elementary school doesn’t have a cafeteria. It has only a dining room. Normally, workers load a van with food and bring it to the school from the middle/high school next door. However, with the small student population, we simply walked over to the middle/high school cafeteria. (We foreign teachers usually go to the cafeteria anyway, and the whole school also does this whenever construction or weather prevents the van from getting to the elementary school.) The students normally eat with their Korean homeroom teacher in the elementary school dining room, but this time we walked the students over to the cafeteria and ate with them. It was kind of fun, actually. Later I would remark that leading a single-file line of students to and from the ping pong building felt good. I felt more like a teacher, since it’s a task I don’t normally do. As I was walking with a group of first graders and two kindergarteners on a foggy day, I saw Oseo Mountain in the distance and thought, “This is like an adventure. We’re heading for that mountain, escaping from orcs. I must protect these children from the orcs.”

Anyway, back to reality, and the winter camp schedule. After lunch students worked on their diary entries and/or read a small English book. (Some students wrote their diaries at home.) I would check their diaries and make a few marks, and give them their earned stickers for the day (up to three for their morning vocabulary quiz, up to three for their diary entry, and up to three for reading). After this last forty-minute period, it was activity time.

Each of us had an activity. I had ping pong. Ashley had English board games. The head English teacher had hockey. (Guess his nationality. You’re right.) Other activities included basketball, assorted playground games (tag, red rover, etc.), and piñata-making. On the first day of winter camp, I played ping pong with my group. The next day, all the groups rotated, so that each group did every activity at least once (and two activities twice). We made some adjustments to ensure that all groups had piñata-making twice (once to make the piñatas, and again after the paste had dried to decorate and break the piñatas).

We had ten days (two weeks) of winter camp. The first Monday through Friday and the second Monday through Wednesday were normal days. It was Wednesday when my group, and Ashley’s, decorated and broke their piñatas. The next day, Thursday, we all went to 안면도 (Anmyeondo, a nearby island). We stayed the night there at a sort of campmeeting resort place. In the afternoon, we had “Olympic Games” for the students. Instead of keeping our normals groups, though, students were quite reasonably re-grouped so that the physical attributes of the groups were more evenly distributed. We had tug-o-war, a sack race, pop-the-balloon-by-sitting-on-it, everyone-hold-hands-and-pass-the-hoola-hoop-without-letting-go, and musical chairs. My team came in second place. After a break, we had a collect-the-signatures game. We had nine stations, with a teacher at each station (a couple of Korean teachers helped us out on this one). Students had to go to each station and perform the activity. Once complete, the teacher would sign their sheet. We had a game of memory, a game of Twister, a code-breaking worksheet, a task of spinning a hoola hoop 100 times total among all team members, lining up in alphabetical order and introducing yourselves (having to restart if the alphabet was out of order), a game where students had to sequentially put on and take off a funky outfit, and so on. My team came in third in this one.

And here’s where I say that the students got spoiled. The day before, they got candy from their piñatas. Before the Olympic games started, we told the students an object lesson about the ingredients of cake, which on their own aren’t very tasty (especially flour or a raw egg), but together are delicious (leading to Romans 8:28 and a small piece of cake for each student). After the Olympic games the teams got snack prizes, and also after the station race. The next morning, some students told us proudly that they had stayed up the whole night having a snack party. 아이고! (아이고 is an interjection mildly expressing dismay, shock, or frustration.)

Then we had dinner. The school appreciated our hard work so much that they forked over quite a bit of money to order 회 for us. 회 is raw fish. Ashley had been busy when the vice-principal came to ask us if we were interested in having 회 for dinner. When she came back I said to her, “우리는 저녁에 회를 먹을 거예요” (“We’ll eat raw fish for dinner”), and she said, “REALLY?” with the biggest eyes I’ve ever seen on her. She was so very happy to hear that.

After dinner, we went to the backyard, near the beach, and had a bonfire and some small fireworks. This was one of the worst parts of winter camp. This was when the air was icy and windy. Quite windy. I think we went back in earlier than the school had planned.

Afterward, we retired to our rooms. The next morning, we had a walk along the beach scheduled for 7:00 am. The students were not pleased about this. Neither were the teachers. The conditions were icy, windy, and “7:00 am.” We pretty much walked out to the water and turned back, had breakfast, and went back to the school. There, we had a small lunch and a closing ceremony, where we gave each student a certificate. Among the certificates were Excellence Award, High Achiever Award, Most Helpful Student, Good Reader Award, Good Writer Award, and Perfect Attendance, for those students to whom we couldn’t honestly give any of the other awards. Finally, we had one last round of spoiling the students in order. We had counted how many stickers they had earned. Each sticker translated into one talent (like the Biblical measure of wealth). We had the “talent market,” where students used their talents to buy snacks and gifts.

In the end, winter camp was a lot of fun. It was stressful at first, because we taught effectively without break for the whole day. Normally we have prep periods and whatnot, but in winter camp, it was a whole-day sprint. However, I think we adjusted (even if we did feel relieved and exhausted when it was all over). By the second week, I felt like I was in the groove. After all, I had only ten students, and I worked with them all day every day, so I got to know them quite well.

This last week we worked without teaching at all. Instead, we have been getting things ready for next week, our final week of school, and for the next school year. We have been making yearly plans, attendance sheets, grade sheets, and report card objectives. We’ll teach next week, and then we’ll have a week off. That week off is not a normal thing, but instead it was the school’s kind offer. I guess they think we’ve been working really hard and wanted to treat us. After that, we’ll come back for another week and a half to finish preparations for the 2013 school year. Then it will begin.

(by Brian)

Last Friday, the 25th of February, I met my primary co-teacher. Her name is 박누리 (Pak Nuri, or Nuri Park) and she is quite nice. That’s her next to Ashley in the picture below:

That picture was taken outside the Ambassador Hotel in Haeundae Beach by 이원구 (Lee Won Gu, or Daniel Lee). You can see him here:

Mr. Lee is the head teacher over the English teachers at 주례여자고등학교 (Jurye Yeoja Godeung Hakkyo, or Jurye Girls’ High School). He took Ms. Park, Ashley, and me out to breakfast on Sunday (he is a very nice old man – would you believe that he is 60? I was quite surprised when he said so).

Not only did he treat us to breakfast at a beachside hotel, but he also bought us a pizza to eat on Friday when we met him. Here’s something you should know about the price of pizza in Korea: As with most Western food, it’s pretty expensive. Your average pizza in Korea runs the equivalent of around $35. Of course, in Korea, pizza is LOADED with toppings. (I’d show you a picture, but I didn’t take one that day. Sorry.) [Update: This is wrong. Mr. Lee said this, and it's true that some pizzas can get to that price, but it's also possible to find pizza between 6 and 15 dollars.]
