So Ms. Park had taken me to our school to meet the principal, Mrs. Jung, and Mr. Lee also greeted us and sat down with me to talk. Ashley’s co-teacher brought her to my school because (I assume) Mr. Lee wanted to meet her too. At one point, Mr. Lee asked me if I was a Christian. I couldn’t figure out why he had asked me (the previous topic had nothing to do with religion), but I said yes, and he replied, “I am Presbyterian.” I think his excitement over our shared beliefs is a major contributor to all the nice things he has done for us. I will list a few more of them here. In addition to giving us a much-needed lunch on Friday and treating us to a fancy breakfast on Sunday, he has:

  • provided me with a (temporary?) pay-as-you-go cell phone to use (I think until I get paperwork to get my own…or maybe for the whole year?)
  • arranged for Ashley to get one soon, too
  • took me to work on the first day of school (Wednesday, March 2) since my route to work involves two buses
  • took Ashley and me to Costco on Tuesday so we could get groceries and cleaning supplies for the apartment
  • brought another pizza over on Monday because he wanted to take us to Costco then, but couldn’t, so he brought a pizza instead and ate it with us
  • asked his co-workers if someone lived close enough to my apartment to give me a ride to work (I don’t think anyone does live nearby, but it was a nice thing for him to ask)

Anyway, Mr. Lee asked us where we went to church, and I told him it was called Pioneer Memorial. He asked if it was Baptist, Methodist, etc., so I told him that it was a Seventh-day Adventist church. Apparently he has heard of it. He even went to the SDA English Language Institute when he was in college. I think it’s good that he knows our denominational background, so whenever I have to turn down extra hours on Saturdays (as I had to do already, because Ms. Park asked if I was interested in earning extra money by teaching two Saturday classes), he will know why (it’s in our contracts anyway that we’re only supposed to work Monday through Friday, but we have heard of some people getting pressured to work on weekends by principals who don’t know the contracts so well).

Speaking of principals, I think I have a pretty good one. Ms. Park took me to the principal’s office on that first Friday, and at first it was kind of awkward. But I can tell that Mrs. Jung wants our professional relationship to be a good one. She also wants me to be well-adjusted to Korean life and her school. She told me that first day something along the lines of, “You should be comfortable in my school so that you won’t go home exhausted.” She also said, “You can get to know the male teachers of my school, and you can play table tennis or badminton.” Apparently it’s true. Ms. Park has told me that some of the male teachers want to recruit me to play ping pong and badminton with them after school. I’m okay with that!

Mrs. Jung also said on the school’s intercom (on the first day of school on Wednesday when she and various staff members were making start-of-school announcements), “He is a foreigner and is not accustomed to our school, so please treat him like my favorite.”

So that’s what happened at the beginning of the first day of school. Lots of things were said over the school’s PA system in Korean (unless they regarded me, and then Mrs. Jung spoke in English). Then we went to the auditorium, where Mrs. Jung introduced all the new teachers, including me, to great applause and cheering by the student body. Someone gave me a sheet that had a chart on it, and I asked Ms. Park what it was. I knew what it was, actually, but I could tell (even though it was in Korean) that someone had scheduled me for two Saturday classes. She looked at it and said, “This is your timetable. [pointing at each day] Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday — oh, someone put Saturday in your schedule.” So she gave it back to someone to have it fixed, and thus I didn’t know my schedule until Thursday. Good thing, then, that I didn’t start teaching until Thursday.

Here’s another reason it was good that I didn’t start teaching until Thursday: I already told you that Mr. Lee picked me up on Wednesday. He told me he would be at my apartment at 7:30. At 6:50, while I was finishing the last 10 or 15 minutes of my lesson plan, he called and said he would be here in 10 minutes. I still had to get dressed, and I figured I needed most of those 10 minutes to do so. I managed to finish my work in the car, but I was still rather out of order for a few hours afterward!

So if I didn’t have to teach on Wednesday, what did I do after the assembly? I sat around and met people, of course, and tweaked my lesson plan. One teacher, a mathematics instructor named Mr. “John” Park, was one of the more notable co-workers of that first day. He introduced himself and chatted with me for a few moments. Later, around 11:30, he asked me if I liked kimchi and if I wanted to get lunch. So I went with him to the cafeteria, but then we discovered that, because it was the first day, the cooks were still getting things in order. Okay. So we went back down to the teachers’ office and waited. He also showed me a room upstairs that had some workout equipment and some ping pong tables. He said it was important to exercise to relieve the stress of being a teacher in Korea.

On Thursday, I had my first class. Ms. Park was my co-teacher. It went horribly. We couldn’t get the laptop connected to the big screen for my PowerPoint, so I had to adjust my speech because of it. We had a game/activity that didn’t seem to go so well, and overall it felt very awkward and even more like failure. I had two more classes, 3rd and 4th period, before lunch, with Mr. Jung (not related to the principal – remember that most Koreans have one of a handful of family names), and these classes also didn’t go so well, but maybe a bit better than the first. At least my PowerPoint worked, and I liked Mr. Jung’s co-teaching style.

After lunch, I expected the students to have the full-stomach effect. But 5th period completely made up for 1st, 3rd, and 4th, and thus I went home feeling much better. My classes on Friday continued the trend, and I think the answer is this: The students in the first few classes could sense my unease and nervousness, and that translated into resistance.

My major failure on Friday was attempting to use the Korean alphabet to explain the pronunciation of pizza. In Korea, pizza is called 피자. It’s pronounced “pee-jah,” and I don’t understand it. Many words in Korea that are borrowed from English sound the same, but with the Korean writing system (Hangeul). Or they don’t sound the same because Hangeul doesn’t have a character for certain sounds. But neither is the case with pizza. If Koreans spelled it 핕사, it would be pronounced peet-sah, which is not quite peet-zah, but much closer than pee-jah. So, because quite a few students used the word “pee-jah” in class, I decided to try to show them a “better” way to spell it so they could understand the proper pronunciation (after all, we’re supposed to help with that anyway). But at the crucial moment, I misremembered how Koreans spelled pizza. You see, ㅂ and ㅍ both make a P sound. But ㅂ is also a slightly B sound, while ㅍ is purely P (aspirated). I wrote ㅂ on the board instead of ㅍ, so the students kept saying no. Then, because ㅅ (S) becomes a T if it is at the bottom of a syllable, I used it like this: 핏사. But apparently, if it is ALSO at the top of the NEXT syllable, it remains an S. So I was still wrong. Thus I looked like a fool, and I don’t even want to know what Mr. Lee was thinking. It was my last class of the day so I couldn’t even make up for it with a better performance in the next class, but I think I got over it. I’m just going to be very careful from now on with Hangeul.

The English teachers of Jurye Girls' High

(by Brian) (written the night before posting)

I won’t lie. Korean food was a major factor in my decision to uproot myself from where I had been growing for 24 years and replant myself in foreign soil. The job opportunity was appealing, yes, but what I was excited about was the food.

Yet when it became official that we were actually going to Korea, I became slightly nervous. Was I right about the food? I had only tried a few things at the Korean restaurant in Mishawaka. Would I like the rest of it? As it turns out, yes, I would. I’m thankful that nearly every dish I have tried in Korea has been, if not delicious, adequate.

Except for that dark thing on my plate. It was some kind of leaf coated in some kind of sauce, and pretty much everyone at orientation hated it. I would rather eat a liquefied Big Mac.

I love how Korea has so many options for how to get or eat your food. There are sit-down restaurants and low-table restaurants of all different sizes and styles. There are street vendor carts and cozy street vendor tents. There are food courts and convenience store food stations. There are take-out places and there are magnets.

Wait. Magnets?

Yes. Magnets. A few days after we arrived at our apartment, we came home to find a magnet on our door. Every door had one. The magnet was fixed to a booklet advertising the local delivery options. We learned from the Internet that these magnets are pretty common, and after a while I think we might be able to coat our fridge with them.

Each page has a phone number and a menu, or part of a menu, if a business has multiple pages. We can’t understand much of the booklet, but we understand enough. Some of the menus have pictures for every item. Some do not. We can read and understand some of the food names. Some we cannot.

One day, we collected some courage and called one of the numbers from the booklet. I had seen a video from eatyourkimchi.com about ordering delivery food, so I had an idea of what I had to do. It was easy to guess anyway. The phone rang and someone answered in Korean. I said 안녕하세요 (annyeonghaseyo, or hello), and then I read the food item I wanted to order, a sushi platter big enough to feed two or three people. The man on the other end of the line said something that I pretended was, “Where would you like this delivered to?” So I told him my address, carefully enunciating the apartment number. A mistake could mean the wrong apartment or even the wrong building within the complex.

If he had asked me something else, he must not have minded because then he proceeded to ask me for my telephone number.

No, really. He said it in English. I tried to provide my phone number, but even though I can count to ten in one of the Korean number systems, I realized that I wasn’t sure how to say “zero.” I think he started to get frustrated and then I realized that he recognized the zeroes. He must know English digits, then. And he did. He said something else and then hung up the phone.

And then we waited. “Well,” I told Ashley, “if no one knocks on our door in about an hour we’ll know that someone else got an unexpected visit.”

But, as you can see, the food came. It even came with little bowls of yummy udon soup.

Tonight we decided to order delivery food again. I called a different place this time and ordered three items: 김치우동, 생선초밥, and 카레정식 (kimchi udong, saengseon chobap, and kare jeongshik).

Pictured: Translation.

One of the soups was kimchi udong (or kimchi udon). It is good stuff that I will definitely eat again. The other soup was a plain udon soup that came with the curry. And there was some nigiri sushi, too.

The curry was kind of mild for our tastes and we didn’t like that three of the pieces of nigiri were shrimp, but other than that our meal was excellent.

In America, nigiri sushi will cost you between one and five dollars, depending on what kind of fish you get and whether you get sushi at a place like SoHo Japanese Bistro or a hole-in-the-wall like Lawrence Fish Market. One piece of nigiri probably uses as much sashimi-grade fish as an entire maki roll, which is why one bite of food is so expensive.

In Korea, though, we can afford to eat nigiri sometimes. It cost us ₩16,500, or about $14.81.

Oh, wait. That was our entire meal. The sushi alone (without the side dishes it came with) might have cost us $20 or $30 in America, twice the amount we spent on our entire dinner. And it was a lot of food. We both got full, and then we finished the food. We could have ordered two items instead of three.

Also, there is no tipping in Korea. That price included the delivery. And if you take another look at the most recent image, you can see that this particular place is one of the many that provides “real” dishware to use rather than disposable (the first gave us disposable, though). We ate our food out of washable bowls and trays, and then we put the dishes outside our door for the restaurant to pick up at a later time.

How awesomely convenient!

I would like to thank my Father in Heaven for some of the best days I’ve had in Korea this year. I am still elated by the joy I felt the first half of this week in Seoul.

Last week was the final week of the 2012 school year at our school. Next week and the week after we’ll go in to work in order to prepare for the 2013 school year, which will start the following week (March 4). But this week that is about to end we were given off as an unexpected and additional bonus to the three-week vacation we had at the end of December.

Ashley and I spent the first part of the week in Seoul. We met our friend Kristina on Sunday morning at COEX, which is a large underground shopping mall in the Gangnam district of Seoul (that famous district from PSY’s song “Gangnam Style”). We would have liked to hang out with both Kristina and Rodrigo, but Rodrigo is Korean, and Sunday was 설날 (Seollal, or Lunar New Year). Seollal and the harvest festival, Chuseok (추석), are the two most important holidays in Korea. They are observed for three days (the day of and the two days surrounding it), and everyone goes to spend these days with their families (or their husbands’ families). Therefore, Rodrigo was not available.

So we spent the day with Kristina at COEX. We’d been there once before, just to walk around and to eat dinner at the food court. We were there late in the evening on Christmas Day (the night before boarding a plane to Chicago), so the place was rather crowded and some places were closed (the aquarium, for example). This Sunday, though, the place was rather empty when we first arrived. We arrived in the later part of the morning, for one, and most people were still with their families. That would change later in the afternoon, though, because Korean holiday traditions and rituals are morning activities. In the afternoon and especially in the evenings, people will go out.

All three of us had eaten just before coming to Seoul, so we weren’t hungry, but we made a plan. We asked each other what we had wanted to eat, and Kristina suddenly said that she felt a craving for Mexican food. It was perfect. We hadn’t thought of it ourselves, but one of the places that had been crowded the last time we visited COEX was a Mexican restaurant called On the Border. Last time, we were told the wait would be around two hours.

So knowing that COEX had a Mexican restaurant and suspecting, by all appearances of the partial menu posted outside and the number of people (including foreigners) eating at this restaurant, that the food was worthy, we jumped at the idea. We told Kristina that we knew just the place. But as I said already, we weren’t ready to eat. Not yet.

So we walked around COEX awhile and then decided to check out the aquarium, which had been closed last time. There were quite a few families here, of course, because of the holiday, and also because aquariums are good places to take your children. If I end up back in Korea for some reason or other when I have children a few to several years old, I would like to take them to COEX Aquarium.

The aquarium looks small. There is an entrance and next to it you can see the exit. It’s among dozens of other establishments in the mall, so you don’t really expect it to have much. So we went up and saw that an adult ticket cost ₩19,500 (or, according to current currency conversion calculations, close to $18), which almost made me hesitant, considering the apparent size of the attraction. But we went and were delighted to find that foreigners get a discount. After looking it up, I found that international visitors received a 30% discount for the first 11 days of February in celebration of Seollal. So yay Seollal!

Then we were further delighted to find that the aquarium wove in and out and round and about and betwixt and between and in places unseen from outside. We spent a couple of hours looking at the various sea creatures in the aquarium. The animals were truly beautiful, and I just loved one section of the aquarium that turned various non-aquarium items into aquarium items. There was a telephone booth filled with water and goldfish. There was a post office box with fish. There were lamp posts and washing machines filled with water and sea creatures. There were fish tanks in the walls framed by picture frames, with paintings at the backs of the tanks, so that the fish inside were swimming in paintings. There was a harp-shaped fish tank with strings made of light, which made sounds whenever the fish swam through and broke the paths of light (an awesome concept, even if the resultant “music” is not so inspiring).

Ashley looking at a manatee. Those things are so cool.

By the time we got out of the aquarium, it was well time for lunch. We went straight for On the Border. We only had to wait fifteen minutes. We sat down and were overwhelmed by the menu. What to do? There were so many delicious things. There were enchiladas, empanadas, tacos, fajitas, salads, and oh so many more. For me, I had but one solution, the final page of the menu which informed me that I could create my own combo of two, three, or four items.

So Ashley ordered a steak fajita salad. Kristina ordered a plate of enchiladas. I ordered a combo: a chicken empanada, a cheese and onion enchilada, a beef enchilada, and a chicken taco. It came with rice and refried beans (you can’t get them in Korea). We also ordered guacamole and some stuffed peppers as an appetizer. Those stuffed peppers…that empanada…those beans and the cheese enchilada…I nearly cried with joy. I’m serious. Ashley asked me if I was about to cry. The only disappointments were the guacamole (not so well seasoned, but other expats assure us to next time try the “Guacamole Live”) and the beef enchilada (a bit dry, but I’ve had dry enchiladas in the States, too).

Thus began a very food-centered mini-vacation. Our lunch was late and very filling, so we didn’t eat much for supper (other than a few “mooncakes” and some drinks at a coffee/tea shop in the evening). But for the following days, we indulged. On Monday we ate at Richard Copycat’s All-American Diner, a place we had visited once before in foreigner-heavy Itaewon. Ashley got a garlic butter steak. I ordered a Philly cheesesteak sandwich. It was nothing short of delicious. For supper we tried Kervan, a traditional Turkish food restaurant, also in Itaewon. Ashley ordered lamb kebabs and I ate Turkish lamb chops. We had a lavash (balloon-like bread) with some hummus, which was amazing, and I braved to try ayran, a Turkish yogurt drink. Nothing disappointed.

Am I making you hungry yet? Me, too, but I’m not finished. Various people had told us to try Butterfinger Pancakes, so we went there for a late breakfast (essentially lunch) on Tuesday. You should know that Korea doesn’t really have breakfast food. They eat rice, soup, and kimchi for breakfast, just as at most other meals. Anything you can eat for lunch or dinner can be eaten for breakfast, it seems. But Butterfinger Panckes, in almost IHOP fashion, serves breakfast from 7 am to 3 am. The menu is massive: about two feet long, one foot wide, and double-sided. There were too many options, and it was a risk that I would take too long to decide even though we asked to look at a menu while we waited for a table. No problem, though. I have a breakfast weakness. One of the first items I noticed on the menu was a corned beef hash that came with pancakes. I browsed the rest of the menu, but my mind was essentially made up. For a moment I was tempted to try something called the French Spongebath, because I like to try new things, but it didn’t come with pancakes.

When we sat down at a table and the server came to take our order, Ashley asked for an omelette, which came with pancakes. She chose honey instead of syrup, and when the server brought our food, she brought a jar of honey with one of those old-fashioned honey sticks with the beehive at the end. I was impressed. However, when I ordered the corned beef hash, the server told me that they were sold out. “That’s fair,” I thought, “and shows that the customers before me know what’s good.” This might have been a cause for panic. But I thanked God that I had a back-up dish in mind. I ordered the French Spongebath.

The French Spongebath (after a few bites, I admit). Toasted ciabatta bread and crackers with corned beef cream sauce and three different kinds of cheese. It wasn’t corned beef hash, but it was delicious.

I also ordered a Butterfinger Blast, seen in this picture with beautiful Ashley. It’s a vanilla shake with crushed Oreos and also a mixture of ground sweets (Oreos, Skittles, butterscotch, and Choco Crunch, according to the menu, and some nuts, according to my eyes). No Butterfinger candy bar (I think the name of the restaurant is not based on the candy), but it was…I want another one.

Ashley’s omelette. She exercised more pre-photo restraint than I did (she but cut the omelette in half). Fortunately for me, she wasn’t hungry enough to eat it all. I got to taste everything, including those delicious pancakes.

For supper that night, we ate at a place that serves 찜닭,  or “steamed chicken.” The English translation is wholly insufficient. I encourage you to click the link to see a picture of the food to better understand what it is that we ate. This restaurant serves only 찜닭, but they make it very well. Your menu options, other than for drinks, are to choose which kind of noodles you want (thick, thin, or a mixture of both), what size plate you want (small, medium, or large, with half a chicken, a whole chicken, or a half and whole chicken), and whether you want some seasoned overcooked rice to add to the remaining sauce once the chicken is gone. We ordered a whole chicken with thick noodles and hot pepper burnt rice. It was yum yum YUM. We remarked how it was the first time we’d eaten 찜닭 since leaving Busan (when we used to even order it by phone and have it delivered to our apartment).

So our vacation was very satisfying in terms of food. When I went to Korean class Thursday evening and one of my co-workers asked how my vacation was, I said, “I ate all the delicious food.”

But food wasn’t all. As I said, we spent some time with Kristina, a friend we haven’t seen in several months. After On the Border, we walked around some more in COEX. We browsed the large bookstore in the mall and, after we tired of that, we took the subway to 몽촌토성역 (Mongchontoseong Station), which was the station nearest our hotel, so that Ashley and I could check in. After that, we walked to a nearby coffee shop and spent a few hours there simply chatting. Eventually the time came when Kristina needed to go to Gangnam Station to catch a bus back home, and so we said our farewells and Ashley and I went back to the hotel.

The next day, after eating our steak and Philly cheesesteak sandwich, we went to What the Book?, which is an English bookstore in Itaewon. Usually we browse the whole store but this time, for whatever reason, we walked in, looked straight at the used section of science fiction books, and did not leave that spot until we were finished. There was a 3+1 deal on used books, so Ashley bought three and even I chose one (I say “even” because I’m usually hesitant to buy books, having already and shamefully a few unread books in my possession).

Since we were in Itaewon, where the big size clothes stores are, I decided to try going to one to see what they were like. I also wanted to get another sweater or two. I didn’t used to be a sweater kind of person. I would wear T-shirts year round and wear a jacket or coat outside. But my parents gave me some sweaters for Christmas and I really liked them. Plus, you can’t really get away with T-shirts indoors in Korea, not when they don’t insulate their buildings the same way Americans do, or when the hallways in the schools aren’t heated.

So I went to a store that looked approachable. (In Itaewon, many men will accost you and try to sell you a custom-made suit, or sports jerseys, or whatever, because Itaewon is the place for buying custom-made suits or sports jerseys or whatever. It is the more annoying aspect of this area.) It was a nice little shop. I found some nice sweaters and bought them, and the woman who worked there was very nice. On the way out the door, I said to her, because it was the third day of the Seollal holiday, 새해 복 많이 받으세요 (“Happy new year,” or, more literally, “Please receive much happiness in the new year”). She was very touched and quite shocked at my Korean. I think that even though Koreans are often shocked if a foreigner can speak a few words of Korean, this woman was especially shocked because we were in Itaewon. The first time I visited Itaewon I had culture shock from seeing so many non-Koreans.

After this, we went to a coffee shop, where Ashley ordered a black tea drink and I ordered a mint chocolate drink. And where we also sat for a few hours reading the books we had bought at What the Book? until it was time for supper (when we ate at Kervan). After supper we went back to the hotel and continued to read. I picked a good book. I finished it at home, after we came back to 광천 (Gwangcheon), and I think it was written very well. The book easily stands on its own, but I was delighted to find out from the Internet that it’s the first book in a trilogy. Normally I avoid series (remember, I have enough books on my waiting list already), but I’m glad that later, when I feel like devoting a day to reading again, I can resume reading about these characters and find out more about the world they live in. I won’t even have to wait, because all three books are already published. Sadly, when Ashley approached the final pages of her book, which she had thought was a single-volume story, she realized that the story was not anywhere near finished. The Internet told her that book two of her trilogy will be published next month (and who knows when book three will be out).

Finally, day three of our trip. Tuesday. (Okay, we left Wednesday, but that consisted of checking out of the hotel, going to Yongsan Station to catch our train back home, and eating lunch at the station before actually boarding the train.) This was museum day. After our Butterfinger Pancakes breakfast of awesome and joy, we went to 서울시립미술관 (the Seoul Museum of Art), where we saw a special exhibit based on the works of Tim Burton, including not only props and clips and designs from his movies, but also sketches and sculptures and artwork from his personal life. In fact, 85% of the exhibit was from his personal collection of unseen artwork (according to the pamphlet). There was even a page from his high school composition class and an encouraging rejection letter from Disney after he submitted a children’s book early in his life. No pictures allowed, of course, but here’s one of Ashley outside the building:

The exhibit was kind of creepy. You know what Tim Burton’s movies are like. His artwork is not much different. Some of it was, though. (And I have to say that I was surprised to learn that Burton directed Mars Attacks!, Batman, and a few other movies that seem completely different in style compared to movies like Edward Scissorhands, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street, or Alice in Wonderland.)

After the Seoul Museum of Art we journeyed to another area of Seoul popular with foreigners, Hongdae, to find the Trick Eye Museum. After that we ate the 찜닭. Here is now, to end this post, a series of pictures we took at the Trick Eye Museum.

UPDATE: I somehow forgot to mention that after we went to the Trick Eye Museum, before we ate 찜닭 for dinner, Ashley and I went to 노래방  (singing room). It’s like karaoke, but you get a room for yourselves, so the only people watching you sing are your friends or co-workers, and not the entire establishment. We took turns singing, and since there were only two of us, we each sang more songs than usual (we’ve never gone by just ourselves). I started by singing “바람기억” by 나얼, which is one of my favorite Korean songs at the moment. It’s slow enough that I can actually sing along, and my score at the end was 98! I tried a few other Korean songs, with varying levels of success, until I gave up and crossed over to my native tongue. I’ll have to practice a few Korean songs before I go again. Ashley stuck to English-language songs, but she sang them, of course, with a much more beautiful voice than with the voice I used. Her only disappointment was that her selection was limited, since most songs she knows and likes to sing are hymns and gospel songs.

노래방 is a lot of fun, but usually one of us isn’t in the mood for it. On Tuesday night, we both happened to be in the mood for it, so we went. After we left, we said to each other that it was fun, that we should go more often.

(by Brian)

Ashley and I went on our first hike in Korea on Saturday. We went to a mountain called 금정산 (Geumjeongsan). Some fellow foreigners from our Facebook group for Busan Guest English Teachers were going to meet at a subway station and take a bus to the trailhead for the mountain.

It didn’t quite work out that way, but it still worked. A married couple of GETs who live near us (but whom we haven’t met yet with our busy schedules) figured out a better set of directions for the mountain than the ones posted on Facebook, so we were going to follow their lead (which they also posted on Facebook). But somehow, to make a long story short, we never met up with anyone at either of the two proposed subway stations (probably because our bus ride took longer than we expected).

So we went alone. We found bus 90, which took us from near 범어사 (Beomeosa) Station to the Beomeosa Temple. We didn’t see much of the temple complex until after our hike, but we walked around a garden path before beginning our primary journey. Then we took photos of some stone flag pole bases and began our climb.

The stone pillars had turtles on the bottom. Their faces looked kind of angry.

Most of the trail was made of rocks and boulders. Sometimes we would see a family eating lunch on a large flat boulder off to the side. We walked for probably thirty minutes before we saw some familiar faces.

They came from behind us, two people from our class in orientation, Luke and Daniela. Not a minute later, another half-dozen or so GETs (from the group we were supposed to meet with, but not the entire group) came down. They had started on another trail and were going down the one we went up.

The Great Wall of Geumjeongsan

We continued, and it was a long journey. We stayed with our two companions, so now there were four of us. They were the first two people I had seen since orientation ended, except one girl we saw briefly at the subway the day after it ended. I don’t know how long it took, but eventually we got to the North Gate, which reminded me of the Great Wall of China. There was a water fountain that had some very awesome water (and no, it wasn’t only because I was thirsty; we brought water, and I tried both kinds back-to-back with a clear winner, pun intended). From the North Gate the trail split into three sections. I think there was some talk of taking the longest (about 3.7 kilometers), but we ended up taking the shortest (about 1.1 km).

Amen.

This is the Fountain of Life. Daniela is filling one of the plastic drinking bowls, and those are Ashley's hands taking her picture. And yes, there were about 10 bowls there, and everyone drinks from them.

Ashley had read about how there were two main paths up the mountain, with one being significantly easier than the other. After about 15 minutes of hiking, we realized we had started on the difficult side of the mountain. So we were tired already. The fork in the road was on a flat surface, which was nice for a while, until it resumed its steep, rocky existence.

But hey, we finally made it to the top, which was well worth the work of walking so far and climbing so much. We could see very far, farther than my camera’s f/8 aperture could capture. (So if you want to see how awesome it looks, you can come to Korea…or give me $500 for a low-end professional camera to take some more detailed photos…or I guess you can go with a Google Image search, but where’s the fun in that?) The four of us sat down and shared the food we had all brought. Luke gave us some 김밥 (gimbap, which is rice and veggies – and sometimes meat – in a roll of sheeted seaweed), and we shared some chocolate-covered cherries that we had brought with us across the ocean. After we had all rested up, we made our way back down the mountain. It took much less time, and it was a bit easier, but I still could not wait to get back to the bus.

And now, for a photo break:

People in Korea love to make the peace sign for photos.

The sun was almost behind us, which makes this photo kind of dark, but there we are at the very top.

We are on top of the world.

We had plenty of space on the top rocks to sit and walk around.

And even climb some more! (That's me on the right)

I can't take credit for this photo. Daniela took it. Quite nice, though, eh?

At orientation some people, who had been in Korea for a few months or years already, had told us that everyone is very friendly while hiking, contrasted with the impersonal characteristics of people in the city. A large number of people passed by us, heading in the opposite direction, and many of them would say 안녕하세요 (annyeonghaseyo, or hi) or even “Hello.” One older man, whom we saw shortly after we got off the bus, asked us, “Where are you from?” I thought his English was pretty good for an older man (since the strong push to learn English in school did not start until the early-middle 90s), and I replied, “미국” (miguk/mee-gook, which means beautiful country and also America). Because of that one word, he asked me, “Where did you learn Korean?” (Many Koreans will be very excited or surprised when foreigners say just a word or two of Korean.) Then he asked if we were living in Korea, so we replied yes. He told us to enjoy our hike, and then we went our separate ways.

At the fountain of life, a Korean woman ran up to Ashley and had a friend take her picture with her. She also pushed Luke into the photo, and maybe me too. I was already close to Ashley, so I might have already been in the frame. Daniela, although a Mexican-American, apparently looks sort of Asian, so she wasn’t pushed into the photo. It was the most enthusiasm I have seen during my three and a half weeks in this country. I’m not saying that Koreans don’t get excited. I’m saying that this woman was very excited. We all had a good laugh later.

But for some reason, on Saturday, the friendliness and foreigner fascination wasn’t contained to the open air of nature, where people are generally less reserved. When we got to the subway station, a man noticed that Ashley and I were trying to figure out which line we needed to board, so he asked us where we were going (in perfect English) and told us the answer.

A minute later, an old woman came up to us, not quite as excited as the photo woman from the mountain, but still with joy plastered on her face, and handed us some bookmarks. She traced the cross symbol that was on them, so we knew right away what she was doing. She talked to us in Korean and was about to turn away when I gave her back her bookmark.

No, I wasn’t being mean. She had mistakenly given me two, so I returned one, using both hands per Korean custom. She smiled and said 감사합니다 (gamsahamnida), which means thank you. And then, of course, she continued to talk to us in pure Korean. I think I recognized the Korean name for Jesus, so I responded by saying, Yes, Jesus, in Korean (I have forgotten the name exactly and am not sure on the spelling). Ashley and I were both pretty sure that she had said something like, “Jesus bless you.”

A man on the subway train itself was passing out cards that advertised some church service on one side (in Korean), but the backside was the Ten Commandments. In English. He gave one to everyone and said something in Korean. To us, he spoke in broken English, reciting Genesis 1:1 and telling us to believe Jesus. I checked both the bookmark and the card for any references to the Korean words for Sunday or Saturday, while wondering if the high amount of witnessing going on had anything to do with it being Sabbath. Probably not, but I would have been amused if I had seen 토요일 (toyoil/toh-yoh-eel, or Saturday) anywhere on the bookmark or card.

Anyway, Ashley and I arrived at our apartment probably seven hours after we left it. We took a bit of a rest before heading back downtown for some well-deserved food!

(by Ashley)

Being waygookin (a foreigner) in Korea means being different from almost everybody else here, and it’s quite an interesting experience.

In the United States, I’m not different. Now, there were cases growing up where I felt very different, like during black history month and I was the only black person in a class full of Caucasian and Mexican Americans who turned to look at me whenever the teacher mentioned the term “African American.” However, in America, most of the time, I was not that different. When I walked down the street in a big city or in Berrien Springs, people didn’t stare—well, not usually unless they were male.

In Busan, South Korea, I’m very different because in Korea, most everyone is Korean. And, unlike in America, you can tell whether a person is Korean by looking at them. Americans all look different and come from various backgrounds. They can be Black, White, Mexican, Asian, painted or tattooed or whatever, they’re American. In America we do our best not to notice differences; we generally don’t stare at people of other ethnicities, hair colors or hairstyles. We don’t stare at people who have tattoos, unless it’s some strange design across their face. In Korea, however, they do stare at foreigners and the tattoos of anyone who dares show them.

And I may not have a tattoo, but I am decidedly not Korean. So when I walk down the street, I get various responses. Some people ignore me, or at least pretend to, which I do appreciate. Some people stop what they’re doing and stare openly—in some cases mouth agape. And some people talk to me, ask questions, or make small sounds of surprise.

Being ignored is fine. It’s a lot like being back home.

It’s usually the older generation who stares mutely. But this stare is generally not uncomfortable for me, just interesting. When I notice them looking, I just smile and keep on with whatever I was doing. It doesn’t bother me because they don’t look angry or upset, they just look–sometimes rather intently. And I kind of understand where they’re coming from, too. After a few weeks in Korea, I find myself doing double-takes at other foreigners myself; it’s just a little surprising to see one, after so many Korean faces.

Anticipating this scrutiny, however, does have some side effects that I’m sure Brian does not appreciate. I find myself taking a lot of extra time in the mirror before going out. As a cultural ambassador of sorts, I feel it is my duty to look good.  I don’t want to misrepresent America to the Ajummas (visor-wearing older women–who may push you** out of their way with no remorse) and Ajushi (older men–very likely to be your local taxi driver or apartment security guard) of South Korea. Not all older people stare, though. Some try to help me if I look lost, others try to witness to me about “Jesu,” while others greet me and say nice to meet you in Korean.

Younger people greet me most often, usually in English, and they might even change course to follow me. Sometimes they just run up stand in front of me to stare wide-eyed and smiling. Sometimes they ask me where I’m from. The other day a small girl I passed while walking down a busy part of the city said, “Hello, nice to meet you.” I said, “Nice to meet you, too,” And her mom made an approving sound. Most of the time, they say “hello” or “hi.” Last week, as I was walking home from school some tween boys even shouted, “You are beautiful.”

Yesterday, when Brian and I attended the Busan I’Park soccer game at the Asiad Stadium, the ticket guy looked extremely surprised to see me. He exclaimed, “Wow!” and then proceeded to sell me two tickets (one for me, and one for Brian). I get the impression that many Koreans in Busan have never seen a black person, except on movies and TV. Some of them, like the enthusiastic woman Brian wrote about in his hiking post, seem to equate being foreign with celebrity. I heard that woman coming from a few yards away and thought “Oh no.” She spoke loudly and excitedly (pardon my adverbs) in Korean, rushing over to take a picture with the foreigners, and shoved me front and center—That picture probably makes me look terrible, as I had just popped in a big mouthful of kimbap and was frantically trying to cheese my way through it (although in Korea they say kimchi instead of cheese).

The strangest thing so far about being different in Korea, has to do with my hair. All of the girls at my school seem fascinated by my locs. They sometimes stand near me and stare, not at my face, but at my hair. They say lots of things in Korean and I hear the word “hair” or “hairstyle” often. On the way home from school one day, a sixth grade girl asked me “Teacher, hair why?” several times. I didn’t have a good answer for her, of course, because the language barrier prevents me from explaining to her about genetics, dominant traits, hair texture, and the problems (psychological and technical) I’ve had with using heat or chemicals to straighten my hair.

Today in class it was no different, several girls asked if they could touch my hair, and I let them since they had asked so politely. After getting a closer look, or touching a loc, students generally make the thumbs up sign and say something like “hairstyle good.”–Though I’m sure at least one student must have said my hair was weird or strange in Korean, since one of my co-teachers translated it to me as “unique.” I chuckled inwardly, because there’s no way for me to know, nor do I care.

Now that I’ve talked a little about some things that I’ve noticed about being different in Korea, let me tell you about some things that are different about Korea that I really enjoy.

  1. It’s different to go to work, and change into slippers. My slippers feel especially comfortable after walking to work in the mornings. I generally hate to put my “regular” shoes back on at the end of the day.
  2. It’s different that the students have to bow to teachers and say ‘annyeonghaseyo.’ Although most of the students just say “hello” or “hi” when they see me, some of them bow and say “annyeonghaseyo.” I really love when the students don’t want to speak English in the halls so they bow and say “annyeonghaseyo” to me instead. It seems so respectful, even though I know they do it because they have to.Today, I was really surprised when one boy had to go to the restroom shortly before my class. The boy came up to me, stood in front of me, bowed deeply, then  asked if he could go before he turned to go out toward the restroom. It’s also very cute when I see tiny kindergarten students bowing to their teachers. I also like to bow to the other teachers and say “annyeonghaseyo,” so I like when they greet me in Korean instead of just saying “hello.”
  3. Brian mentioned this before, but they often deliver your food with real dishes and silverware, which they come back later to pick up. That’s different, and I like it.

Anyway, I’m glad to be here.

**Although a lot of foreigners in Korea say they’ve been pushed out of the way by ajummas, I have not yet had the privilege. Usually, on the subway I feel a slight nudge, and then I move out of the way as quickly as I can. I’ve heard people say that Koreans are rude and bump into you etc., I haven’t been treated “rudely” yet.

(by Brian)

Very early in our Korean experience, Ashley posted a list of things she liked about Korea. Now that we have been here for a little more than a month, I would like to add to that list. Here are more things that makes Korea cool, in no particular order.

1: Design

Maybe this item is on my list out of ignorance of other cities, but I enjoy the design of cities in Korea. Or at least the design of Busan. Because Korea is so small with such a large population, and with a majority of the land area mountainous, Koreans have mastered the concept of space efficiency. An observation I made early on about “downtown” areas of Busan was that most establishments were stacked on each other in sections of a city block. Within one side of a city block, therefore, you can easily find an assortment of restaurants, shops, and service-based establishments (such as pharmacies and doctors’ offices).

There's a sign against the wall that you can see if you are too close to the building to see the sign above the entrance.

My favorite part is the staircase. Most blocks will have several staircases leading directly into the building from the sidewalk. These staircases will usually have signs to tell you what is available in that section of the block. Some signs are flat against the building above the staircase, while others run up the side of the building, and some are on sandwich board signs on the sidewalk. Some are even on the steps of the staircase. Many times you can find the signs in at least two locations. You might not find this general layout pattern to be very interesting, but for some reason I really like it. It appeals to my appreciation for efficiency and user-friendliness.

2: Dental Health

In Korea, most people brush their teeth after every meal. I even saw a man brushing his teeth in the restroom of a restaurant we visited as part of our orientation activities. He had his toothbrush with him and a cup he used to collect water for rinsing.

It’s no different at school. After lunch on my first day of work, Mr. “John” Park, a math teacher I mentioned before, showed me a cabinet in the men’s staff bathroom and told me I could keep my toothbrush in it. He said this with no suggestion. His tone implied that I already brushed my teeth after every meal and that now I knew what to do to continue that practice. After lunch the following day, Mr. Lee showed me that cabinet, telling me the same information with pretty much the same tone. So good teeth-brushing habits are one of the customs of Korea that Koreans aren’t aware aren’t practiced so thoroughly in other countries.

A cabinet in the men's staff bathroom at my school. My mug is not in the photo because it's in a rather empty area of the cabinet. This photo shows more dental hygiene glory.

A few days later I finally brought in one of the mugs from our apartment plus a toothbrush. It actually seemed providential that Ashley had packed a value 4-pack of toothbrushes, so that I could have one at home and leave the other at work. The previous tenant of our apartment also left lots of unused tubes of toothpaste, so hooray! Now I brush my teeth an extra five times a week, which is probably an improvement of 100% or more beyond what I used to do in America. (Please don’t do the math. It will embarrass me.)

3: Self-Awareness

I mentioned above that two of my teachers seemed to not recognize the cultural difference between dental hygiene habits in their country and in others. (I did, though, have another teacher recently ask me if I found that habit surprising. I told her I appreciated it for what it has done to my own dental care.) This observation can be applied to much of my experience in Korea. I will admit that any culture other than the one I grew up in can provide this third item, but it’s happening in Korea, so Korea gets the credit.

Anyway, something I learn often in Korea is that we take a lot more for granted than we think, including what seems to us like obvious right answers or standard ways of doing something. In Korea, I’ve learned that, hey, other people think differently. We all know that, but seeing just how different their thoughts are, in an entirely different context, is one of the biggest learning experiences I have had, and I will be encountering more during my stay here. Yeah, almost everyone knows or guesses that people bow to each other here, but did you know about…

4: Service?

Most likely not. “Service” in Korea is a Konglish word (meaning it is a word that Koreans use to express something in English that either is pronounced or spelled differently or has a different meaning) meaning “free” (and “free” in Korea often refers to “one size fits all”). So in a way, it’s proper that I have a question mark in the subtitle of this item. (I actually think it is service to provide for something free, so it’s not entirely Konglish, but some people think it is).

Now that I have made a tangent with three too many parenthetical phrases, I’ll get to my point. In Korea, there’s a thing called service, and it means getting stuff for free. I’ve heard about it a lot on foreigner forums, but didn’t really experience it until just a few days ago. Ashley and I went to the local grocery store. We bought the equivalent of about 45 dollars of groceries, and halfway through ringing up our purchase, the cashier reached beneath the cash drawer and pulled out a 1.5-liter bottle of Chilsung Cider (“cider” being another Konglish word meaning “soda pop”). She set it with the groceries she had already scanned and said, “Service,” with a smile. Apparently, this is not an entirely rare occurrence, nor is it limited to grocery stores or even large purchases.

5: Sharing

I’ll tell you upfront. You probably won’t like this one. You might think to yourself, “Why, that’s a reason to not like Korea or want to go there!” But I appreciate it nonetheless (maybe only because it’s different, but I think there’s more to it than that).

Here is what I mean by sharing: Koreans share their food. During orientation, one lecturer, a young Korean man who was responsible for telling us a bit about Korean history and culture, told us about the time he was in Starbucks with an American friend. They both ordered a coffee and the friend also asked for a brownie. Our lecturer told us, “I was thinking, ‘Oh, we’re going to share the brownie. I am kind of hungry.'” Because in Korea, people share food. He thought they would each have their coffee and they would split the brownie. Then the American friend ate the brownie alone, and the Korean was a bit surprised and sad. (See? More cultural differences.)

About a week ago, during a meeting for English teachers, one of my co-workers gave me half of his 떡 (ddeok, which sounds almost like the word “duck” and which is a generic term for several kinds of rice cakes). Normally, I politely refuse when people offer me things because I believe they’re politely offering. But in Korea, it’s not a polite offer. You almost have to take it, because it’s important to share.

And onto the part you won’t like. The part where things get messy. Here it is: Koreans not only share their food, but they share bowls. If you go to a restaurant in Korea, you will usually receive an assortment of side dishes with your meal. Everyone eats from these side dishes together. You take your chopsticks, you grab a piece of food from the dish, and you eat it. You might go back to your own plate of food for a while, but then you’ll take your chopsticks and grab another bite of a side dish item. And if there is a big bowl of soup for everyone to share (which is often the case if you’re eating 비빔밥, or bibimbap, a bowl of mixed rice and vegetables), you share one spoonful at a time. You take a spoonful, you eat it, and you get another spoonful or return to your dish. There’s no worry about sharing germs or anything (unless someone is actually sick, and that person will probably portion out their own separate serving). For some reason, Ashley and I like this. We’ve embraced it. It’s easier, for one, and it makes the bond between meal companions even stronger. So what if the spoons of five different people have been in that bowl? Stomach acid kills most bacteria anyway.

Hey, while we’re on the subject of restaurants, let me tell you about item number…

6: Restaurants

I wanted to have an item for the button alone, but I think it makes more sense to tell you about it with two other things: prices and menus. So at Korean restaurants, you’ll probably get a menu you don’t understand at all. You could be brave and pick something at random. Ashley and I did this once and we were thankful that what we ordered wasn’t still-squirming octopus, but a dish of grilled fish. Some menus will have English, too. But some menus…ah. Some menus are just plain awesome. They take up a lot of space, but they tell you everything you need to know. Take a look at it, right here:

Some restaurants have menus that are made of replicas of the menu items. These are all made of plastic but look pretty close to what you’re actually ordering. So you can know if a certain dish has tentacles or not, or if this particular establishment puts onions in their bibimbap. I think that’s pretty helpful.

Restaurants are also (usually) very affordable. Sometimes you might be slightly overcharged because you’re a foreigner. (So I can’t wait to know enough Korean to dissuade street vendors from taking advantage of my ignorance. Until then, we pretty much stick to places that list their prices, which is already most of them anyway, including most street vendors.) But for the most part, eating out is fairly cheap. If you eat at a Western restaurant, you might pay a bit of a premium, but most places are reasonable. Look at these pictures, for example:

 

 

 

 

 

 

Looks pretty fancy, right? I didn’t get a picture of it, but this place had a ballroom-type feel to it. Very elegant. And each booth had fancy drapery partitions. The atmosphere alone made me feel like I should be spending $30 a plate. But it was actually closer to $16. Total. And remember, there is no tipping in Korea. (By the way, that is indeed a couch Ashley is sitting on. A big one. And a comfy one.)

Okay, now you can finally learn about that mysterious “button” I mentioned earlier. What was that about, right? The button is a device that is on your table at many restaurants. Instead of having waiters come by your table every 5 minutes, interrupting your conversation, or not showing up when you want them to, you get a button. You press the button, a waiter comes to your table. It’s that easy. (Okay, so sometimes we don’t press the button and a waiter still comes, but we figure it’s because they think we don’t know about the button, being foreigners, and we have been taking a rather long time to decide what we want to eat, which reinforces the idea that we don’t know how to get their attention.)

The button, in all its helpful glory.

Before I leave you, I’d like to tell you about one more cool thing Korea has to offer:

7: Puppies

"AWWWWWWWWWWW!" - At least two or three readers of this blog.

What? America has them, too? Oh. Oh well. They’re still here, and they’re cool. And everywhere. We saw at least half a dozen puppies hiking with their owners at Geumjeongsan.

This weekend I’ve had a blast with being able to use some of my Korean skills. It’s been a real adventure. I’ll  tell you about some of these experiences.

One of our co-workers, Linda, has family visiting her in Korea. Her mother and her younger sister. Linda took them to a meat buffet restaurant Saturday and invited her friends. So Ashley and I went. So did Katelyn, the new teacher at our school. Linda’s family is quite nice and I’m glad we got the chance to not only meet them, but also to spend some time getting to know them. Anyway, we went to this restaurant, and Linda also invited a teacher who is new to the area. She came to Korea just weeks ago and wanted to meet people. She had been unable to attend the Friday night “Welcome to Hongseong” party that many of the foreigners in our area had gone to. So she was there, and Linda also has a few Korean friends. They were there, too, although they arrived later than everyone. This will be a factor for a later part of the story.

And what do you know, that later part of the story is now. After we had finished eating, Linda planned to show her family what a 노래방 (noraebang, or “singing room”) is like. The Koreans told us to go ahead to the noraebang. They’d come when they were finished eating. So we went. There were ten of us total, four staying behind to finish eating (three Koreans and the new teacher). That left me more or less in charge. I led us to the noraebang that our friends had suggested (after we declined their first recommendation because we’d been there, and it was not heated). There, I told the attendant, “네 명 더 올 것입니다.” Four more people are coming. Then his response made me think he didn’t have any big rooms. Eventually I realized that that’s precisely what they’re called in Korean: big rooms. “큰 방 없어요?” There are no big rooms? He assured me that there were. So we paid him and he showed us to the room. The six of us started singing some songs for a while, and finally the other four showed up. We had a lot of fun. There are a few Korean songs I can sing at noraebang, although this particular noraebang didn’t have all of them. But I sang one of them and the Koreans were impressed. I sang an American rock song called “I Walk Beside You,” and one of the Korean women brought Ashley to the singing/dancing area (she always did this whenever one of us was singing, to bring the other to the singer). So I turned to Ashley as I sang the chorus (“I walk beside you / Wherever you are / Whatever it takes / No matter how far,” and so on).

Eventually there were more Korean songs to be sang, and I was roped into joining. I did better than I expected. It was a lot of fun, and quite dangerous for the ego when the Koreans told me that I was 최고 (“the best”). Eventually noraebang ended. We went home. The Koreans didn’t need help. That left seven of us. Six of us wanted to go back to Gwangcheon (Linda, her mom, her sister, Katelyn, Ashley, and I), while the new girl in Hongseong (Melissa) wanted to go to, well, her apartment in Hongseong. The area we were in wasn’t really a downtown kind of area. The buses had stopped running and taxis weren’t exactly lined up waiting for fares. We walked to a nearby bus stop. One taxi waited there. On the way to the bus stop, I had typed Melissa’s address on her phone from her registration card, because Melissa can’t read Korean yet to tell the taxi driver where to go, and the font for her address on the registration card was super super tiny.

Back to the cab. It’s possible to call a cab, and I’ve done it successfully once in life, but it’s a very uncertain thing when you don’t really know what’s being said on the other end of the line. Here we didn’t really have a good marker for telling our location. So I did something else. I approached the taxi and opened the front door. I said to the driver, “많은 사람입니다. 그래서 택시 2 대 더 전화하세요. 괜찮아요?”  We are many people, so please call two more cabs. Is this okay? There were a few more exchanges between us to figure out exactly what we wanted (such as where we were going and a clarification on the number of additional cabs needed). Then he took Linda and her family back to Gwangcheon. A second cab arrived and Melissa took that one back to her apartment. Finally a third cab arrived and we took that to Gwangcheon. When I told the driver we wanted to go to Gwangcheon, he asked us where in Gwangcheon. I don’t really know how to say that, so I tried to say “광천에 갈 때는 더 말할 거예요.” At the time we go to Gwangcheon, I’ll say more. But toward the end of my sentence I kind of stumbled over the Korean syllables that were being formed by my mouth. He understood anyway (praise the LORD). So we arrived in Gwangcheon and I said, “광천오거리에 왼쪽으로 가주세요.” At the Gwangcheon five-way intersection please go left. (I realize now that I used the wrong particle, 에 instead of 에서.) He took us home and Linda’s cab was in the parking lot turning around. The driver realized that we were all together and he laughed. We had enough money to pay the fare seen on the meter, but I was trying to find a 1,000 won note so he wouldn’t have to break a 10,000 won note. He reduced the price for us and insisted on it, so as we got out of the cab, I said to him, “행복하게 오래오래 사세요.” Please live happily for a long, long time. He seemed to appreciate that.

The next day the six of us went to Seoul. It was Katelyn’s first time, and we also went to show the Seoul Grand Park Zoo to Linda’s family. This is where the story takes a turn. We were going from Yongsan Station to Seoul Grand Park Station. It was a journey of eight subway stops, including one line transfer. Halfway to our destiny, when the train came to Sadang Station, many people got off the train. Hey, plenty of seats, let’s all sit down, eh? So we sat down. Then we remarked how there were lots of seats. Then I stood up and looked up and down the train. There wasn’t a person on board. “Oh, I think we have to get off and get on another train,” said somebody. So we made our way toward the doors in an effort to get off the train. That effort was 83.3% successful. If you’re really good at math, you know that means five of us managed to get off the train before the doors closed insistently.

As I pulled my bag from the doors – not at all like elevator doors – I looked for an emergency open button. None to be found in the few seconds I had before the train resumed its journey to just-where-does-the-train-go-when-it’s-being-swapped-out-for-a-different-one? I looked at my friends through the window. The looks on their faces. Like I was on a wrong plane taxiing down the runway to another country. Like I was being sent to the slaughterhouse. Like I was too late in reaching the airlock on a spaceship before the pod bays were to be automatically opened.

So by God’s grace, I smiled and waved at them as the train began to move, in an effort to encourage them. I thought, “Well, I suppose this is going to the train garage or something. Might be a while before I see them. I’ll just text them telling them to head to the zoo and I’ll meet them there whenever I get there.” Before I could finish the text, though, Linda called. I don’t remember what we talked about. I think it had to do something with the sudden situation I was currently in. An old woman with a broom and dustpan went from car to car sweeping up trash and dust. After she passed me I started to follow her. I started to say “어떻게” (“How?” as in, “How do I leave?”), and she promptly told me to sit down and many other things which I couldn’t understand. So I sat. The train stopped. I couldn’t see a single speck of light beyond the windows of the train car. A man without a broom passed through the cars. The old woman came back through. She spoke to me again and this time she pointed at the map. I recognized 나가면 (“if you go out”) and wondered how that could fit into anything relevant to this situation. “IF I go out”? She also said something about Sadang. We had just left Sadang, though. She said a lot, and so I tried to ask her in my own words to see if I understood correctly (which was less of me really understanding and more of just making an educated guess). “사당에 도착할 때는…” I couldn’t finish the sentence before the woman affirmed that that was right. Which is good, because I hadn’t prepared the rest of that sentence in my head, or I might have stumbled over some more syllables. The sentence, by the way meant, “At the time of arriving in Sadang…” with the unspoken half being, “나갈 수 있습니까?” (“I can go out?”)

I called Ashley back, because she had called while I spoke with the woman. I told her what I knew, and by now the train had reversed directions. We were going back to Sadang. So this is weird, I thought. The train went forward empty and now it’s returning to the station we were just at. Instead of people having to get off and wait for another train, why not stay on this one and wait there instead?

Except that was the wrong thinking. When I arrived at Sadang Station, I walked out of the train and saw that the signs now read that this car was going away from Seoul Grand Park. I felt like I was in the Twilight Zone, which is what I said to Ashley on the phone (we were still on the phone). Somehow I went forward, stopped, went backward, and suddenly I’m on the other side of the platform. I think I know now what happened (writing it out makes it so obvious if I hadn’t figured it out by now), but at the time it was very strange. Of course, the entire experience was very strange.

Anyway, I crossed to the other side of the platform and waited for a train. I was two stops behind Ashley and the rest of our group. Ashley said she’d wait for me at Seoul Grand Park Station. In fact, everyone decided to wait for me. There I met with my wife and friends again. I learned that Linda’s mom had had a bit of an anxiety attack for my sake, which, while I really didn’t want anyone worrying about me and certainly don’t like that I caused a mild panic attack, did make me feel touched.

This blog is full of successful Korean usage, and that streak made me feel really good, and praise God for it all. Without Him I wouldn’t be able to learn, and my errors would prevent any fruitful communication whatsoever. But He got me through it. Perhaps I nonetheless still had too much pride. When we got to the zoo, I tried to buy tickets for us. Katelyn had already gone to the ticket counter for the tram car to take us to the zoo entrance. There was that counter and a counter for a package ticket (tram car, zoo, and sky lift). We didn’t want the sky lift, though (a combination of people that seemed not keen on heights and a previous experience of the sky lift having very long lines). We only wanted the tram car tickets and tickets for the zoo. When I tried to buy only zoo tickets at the package counter, the woman said it was for package tickets only. When I tried the tram car ticket counter, one of the two women working there said some things to me, but even though she spoke through the microphone, the other sounds in the building drowned her out completely. I only saw her making an X with her arms. Was the zoo not open today? The six of us tried to figure out what was going on. They were selling package tickets, so obviously the zoo was open. Where were the tickets? So I went back to the ticket counter and went in the other line this time. There were fewer people nearby so I could hear this time. But the woman spoke in rapid Korean, and I couldn’t catch a thing she said. I didn’t recognize any of it. I tried to rephrase my questions and do all sorts of things but…why did she have to speak so fast? I know she wasn’t yelling, but speaking through the microphone and speaking fast and speaking unintelligibly to a person in a vulnerable situation made it feel like yelling. It didn’t help when she looked at her co-worker to see if she could help address my concerns, or maybe to telepathically share, “What is up with this 외국인?” I thought, “Maybe the ticket counter for the zoo is after the tram car ride, even though it’s strange that you can buy package tickets here, including a zoo ticket, but not just a zoo ticket.” So I tried to ask, in broken and intimidated Korean by now, if that were so, but all I received in response was more quick and unintelligible speaking. I have to admit that for about ten minutes afterward I just felt so defeated. I wasn’t really bothered by the whole ordeal on the train (other than being slightly embarrassed initially), but for some reason I felt…”traumatized” is too severe a word…by the experience at the ticket counter.

But at least, in the end, we decided to just get on the tram car. And yes, at the zoo entrance was the ticket counter for “zoo only” tickets.

Overall, I was quite happy this weekend to use my Korean. I’m thankful to my Father in Heaven for giving me the ability to learn the modest amount of Korean I have gained so far, and for giving me the opportunities to practice using it in real-life situations. I’m even thankful for the awful experience I had at the ticket counter. Perhaps I can learn a thing or two about how my students may feel at times. Or at least it can encourage me to fill in the gaps of my Korean skills (though the metaphor would be more accurate if I said the gaps were in my ignorance–I’ve got a lot to fill.)

(by Brian)

“Do you know what this means?” Kristina asked. “This is the first time I’ve seen you two as a married couple!”

And it was true. More than a year ago, our friend Kristina graduated and left Michigan to go back home. A few days ago, she came all the way to Busan, South Korea, to see Ashley and me for the first time since she left Andrews University.

Okay.  So I’m making Kristina out to be an amazing friend who traveled halfway around the globe to see us. Only the first part of that assumption is true. Kristina is currently living in Gumi, South Korea, so she only had to take a train for two hours to get to Busan. I played the same trick, inadvertently, on a co-worker at work. She asked if I enjoyed my weekend, and I said I did because a friend of ours came to visit.

“All the way from the US?” she asked with disbelief and a bit of awe.

“Oh, no,” I replied. “She’s been living in Korea for nearly a year, up in Gumi.” My co-worker said she was in Gumi for a wedding on Saturday. So I guess Busan and Gumi traded residents for a couple of days.

Kristina arrived a couple of hours after we got off of work. Although we do not live near a subway station, I can walk to one in about ten minutes from my school, and Ashley’s school is near a stop for the same bus I take to work. So Ashley and I met each other after work to meet Kristina at Busan Station. It made more sense than going back home and then turning right back around. We finally met her around ten to seven, even though her train came in a quarter-hour before that. We had waited at the wrong platform.

But then we found each other near an in-station Burger King. Yay! We spent quite some time trying to find a place to eat. The whole ordeal was very awkward. Not because we hadn’t seen Kristina in so long and it was therefore weird (it wasn’t, except in the standard, everyday wow-we’re-meeting-each-other-in-Korea-after-all-this-time feeling, but you know how that is). It was because of two things. First, we spent quite some time choosing a place, which involved walking by what must be an area aimed at foreigners, including a woman, dressed like someone who isn’t very dressed, who emerged from a restaurant to ask if we wanted something to eat.

Nope. We kept walking.

We eventually found a place that serves 샤브샤브 (syabeu-syabeu, or shabu-shabu). Kristina told us about this food and wanted us to try it. So we did.

The second thing that made our meal endeavors awkward was being fed by the restaurant. Let me tell you something else about Korea. At many places, you cook your own food. The table has a built-in grill, and the server brings you the food, turns on the grill, and comes back only to give you refills of side dishes or to give you more meat to cook, etc. It’s pretty neat, actually.

With foreigners, though, many servers will come back, especially if they notice you just sitting at the table dumfounded, to cook the food for you. We weren’t quite dumbfounded, but we weren’t sure when to put the thinly-sliced squares of beef into the vegetable-filled broth. We waited for the broth to boil, but the server beat us to it. She came by and started placing the beef squares into the broth. She let it cook for a few moments, then took it out with some vegetables, and placed it on my plate. Then she placed a bite on Ashley’s plate, and finally one on Kristina’s.

Okay. Thank you, kind Korean food server, for showing us how to enjoy our shabu-shabu. Now we know how to do it oursel—Wait. What are you doing? Putting more on our plates but first insisting that we eat what you have already given us? Okay, I’ll eat this first bite, and then you’ll refill our plates once and, feeling confident that the 외국인 (oegukin/waygookin/foreigners) know how to cook and eat shabu-shabu, leave us to our meal and company.

I was wrong. This woman served us, bite-by-bite, for half of the meal, only relinquishing her awkward imposition after some other customers arrived.

I made sure every time she came by to have the tongs in hand to put a piece of beef in the broth, to discourage a repeat performance. It was very considerate of her, but we ate half our meal in silence instead of conversing with each other.

And that’s how we spent our first meal. Then we came back and showed Kristina the apartment. We had spent the day before cleaning it, including, for me, finally emptying my last suitcase of the clothes still in it and waiting to be put away. (In my defense, to do that I first had to wash a very dirty plastic clothing drawer set that had sat out in the laundry area.)

Kristina gave us a gift when we got to the apartment. It was a pack of flower cards, which are used to play Go-Stop, a type of “Korean poker.” Apparently, you can get arrested for playing with them if there’s a bet involved (because gambling is illegal outside of casinos). Or even if the police think there’s money under the table. We played that game until we started being so engrossed in conversation that we couldn’t pay attention to the cards anymore. And it was a pretty fun game. And that’s how much of our weekend went. We wandered around, looking for food or a coffee-and-tea house or just something to see, and then we would talk with each other. She told us about her school, we told her about ours, and we talked about things back home and things in Korea and the past, the present, and the future.

I will tell you about two things we sought out specifically before I finish. The first is the aquatic show at a certain Lotte Department Store. (Do you recognize Lotte from my second post? Lotte is huge. Lotte owns GE. Okay, that’s a lie, but Lotte is seriously huge.) The show is pretty cool. It’s the second time Ashley and I have seen it, and when we mentioned it to Kristina, she wanted to see it too. And when you read about it, you will want to see it, too.

The aquatic show is the “world’s biggest indoor audiovisual fountain.” The fountain runs constantly as a basic fountain, with a few jets of water always bursting upward from the surface. But every hour on the hour, the department store plays a few songs on loudspeaker, and the fountain goes nuts. You’ll see color-changing lights. You’ll see jet-bursts of water blasting straight upward in varying heights. You’ll see arcs of water criss-crossing the fountain basin. And you’ll see letter-shaped water falling from the ceiling four stories up. Yes. There are two or three rings in the ceiling for water to pour down, and sometimes the water is timed just right to form letters. I’ve made out, so far, the letters for “Busan” and “Lotte,” in both English and Korean.

The second thing I want to tell you about is 호떡 (ho-tteok), an awesome fried pancake that is filled with a sweet sugar-cinnamon sauce and topped, often, with pumpkin seeds or nuts. Kristina heard that Busan had the pumpkin seeds (she was used to plain ho-tteok with only the pastry and the filling), so we found some ho-tteok to enjoy. And later we found some more. On Facebook, I posted “호떡 맛있어요,” which means, “Ho-tteok is delicious.” I wish I could buy you one so you could try it. (If you come to Korea, I will buy you one. Or even two. Come on, you know you want to!)

Eventually Kristina had to get back on a train. We had fun. It was good to see her again, and we told her we would try to visit Gumi before she goes back to North America at the end of next month. But today at work I realized that Kristina’s visit did something for me regarding how I think of Korea, and how I think of Busan. Kristina had never been to Busan. In a way, I felt somewhat responsible for being her guide (although not entirely, because she only expected to see us and not pack in an itinerary…and we’ve not been here long enough to be so responsible). Busan was our city, in my mind. Plus, we had our first visitor. Someone came to stay at our apartment. Our home. I’ve said it over and over, that I live now in Korea, and I’ve changed my location on Facebook to Busan, but Kristina’s visit seems to have really affected and settled that association.

Or maybe it’s only because I finally unpacked the rest of that suitcase.
