(by Ashley)

So apparently being an elementary school teacher in Korea is fun. At least it is at my school. Not only do you have free reign to craft creative punishments for unruly kids (the last couple of days my co-teacher has made the entire monkey-acting class do squats until they were sweating and silent), but every month we, the special teachers, get together for dinner. And by special teachers I don’t mean special ed (though we do have special ed students in some classes, but this is another issue). By special teachers I mean teachers of non core-curricular subjects. So our group is made up of the PE, music, English, Chinese, and a science teacher.

Tonight was one of our monthly dinners. After school we went directly to a traditional Vietnamese restaurant. We took off our shoes, sat on the floor and were served very delicious somethings. The first course involved duck that we grilled ourselves at our table, and soup also cooked at our table. We rolled the grilled duck and assorted vegetables (shredded beets, lettuce, cabbage, cucumber, carrots, onions, bean sprouts etc.) in round sheets of rice-wrap. But first we dipped the rice-wrap in hot water to make it soft. After putting in the meat and veggies, we dipped the wrap into a sauce of our choice (there were three) and took a bite. Om nom nom. The next course involved putting noodles into the broth from the soup and eating the noodle soup. The final course involved putting bibimbap style rice (mixed with veggies) into the broth and eating this new rice soup. Needless to say, I was stuffed and wanted to go home and flop across the bed.

But I couldn’t go home because I was about to learn another one of the perks of being a “special” teacher. Every month, we also get to go out on “cultural” outings. This may not sound too exciting (although to me it does) so let me explain. Our normal work hours are 8:40 to 4:40, but normal classes (actual school) end at around 2. Cultural outings are times when we can leave after normal classes and go out to do a cultural activity such as watching a movie, having a picnic, or attending a cherry blossom festival! So, the reason I couldn’t go home was because the teachers were checking their schedules to pick the best date for our trip to the cherry blossom festival, which I am absolutely excited about.

I love cherry blossoms.

(by Brian)

Learning another language is very hard. Today I told a few of my co-workers that I was jealous of them because they are bilingual. Somehow, sometime, they learned to speak English, and they speak it quite well. Sometimes they don’t understand certain idioms or phrases, but who can blame them? And sometimes they struggle for the right word, but so do I. (We just have different reasons: I’m trying to find the perfect synonym, to fit in some alliteration, or to make the sentence seem powerful; they are simply trying to communicate.) Overall, however, their English skills are very impressive. Some people I know have co-teachers who can barely speak English. I guess that’s one benefit of working at a high school. English teachers in high schools had to major in English.

Here’s a confession: I often think about other people’s brains. Specifically, I think about what is going on in their minds. Sometimes, I wake up from whatever it is that I am doing and realize that everyone else also has their own thoughts. At these points, I start to wonder what other people are thinking. I start by thinking of people I know who are closeby but not in visible range. Then I wonder about people in other countries. I wonder about people who are sleeping because they are on the other side of the world. I wonder about people who are eating, or playing, and I sadly think about people who are probably at that time dying or being raped or burying a loved one. And for all of these things, I wonder what people think about them.

But even though I’d often thought about people having experiences that were different than the ones I’d been having, I didn’t often consider that they way they thought about these things was probably not in English. When I walk down the street in Korea and look at any given person, I sometimes think to myself, “Wow, that person is thinking in Korean.” It’s significant because, for one, it’s another language. They do not think, “Oh, I hope I catch the bus on time.” No, they think something else. For another, languages have different grammars and patterns, and with those different grammars and patterns come different ways of thinking.

When I was younger I used to think speaking another language was impressive. I don’t mean speaking one language, and then speaking another language on top of it. I mean speaking another language. I used to think, “Wow, they have to translate that into/from English and then say it.” I know that is absurd now, but I still have to remind myself that to people who don’t speak English, what they say and hear makes sense. And of course we studied this stuff as English majors, but it’s different to experience it first hand.

Part of learning a language is thinking in that language. There’s a difference between knowing words in a language and knowing the language. It’s very difficult. We get so used to asking, “How do you say, ‘I want some nachos’ in Korean?” The answer is you don’t. If you say, “I want some nachos,” you are not speaking Korean. You might say, “Duh, Brian, you typed that in English.”

No. What I am trying to say is this: 안녕하세요 does not mean “Hello” in Korean. It means 안녕하세요*. The same goes for pretty much anything else you can say in Korean. So it’s very difficult to learn a language if you constantly compare it to another one. Yet how can you learn it without doing that? Sometimes it’s necessary, but it cannot work by translating an entire vocabulary.

It’s hard. But I’m glad to say that, with a few words and phrases, at least, I know only what the Korean means. Okay, somewhat. For example, we learned how to tell time in Korean. You say the hour in the pure Korean number system, followed by 시, which means hour. Then you say the minute in the Sino-Korean number system, followed by 분, which means minute. After only a few days at our apartment, I noticed lots of convenience stores and other places had “24 시간” on their signs. I eventually realized that it means they were open all day long. I don’t know the exact translation, and I’m glad. It has helped me adapt my understanding, so that when I saw 시간 in another context, I could realize it didn’t only mean “hours a day.” And I see 분 enough that I don’t even have to think about what it means.

I’ve also learned dates without having to translate in my head. Of course, half of it is numbers, but one day I saw “3 월 25 일” and knew instantly that it meant March 25.

I think my greatest internalization of Korean is what they say to express gratitude. To say thanks, Koreans say 감사합니다. A few weeks ago, I sat at the cafeteria lunch table, inclined my head, closed my eyes, and the first word that came to my mind, instead of “Thank you, Father…” was 감사합니다. Took me by surprise. A student also handed me a sheet of paper one day and I automatically said 감사합니다, which made her and her nearby classmates laugh and gasp. Of course, I apologized for speaking Korean in English class….

But all of this is very small. I still have a long way to go.

*No, really. 안녕 “means” well-being, peace, etc. 하세요 “means” do you?, you do, please do, etc. Not one of those words is “hello.”

(by Brian)

Some things are different in Korea. Most of them are neutral, although you or I may have opinions regarding the superiority of one way or another. Ashley and I have both written blogs about why we like Korea, and now I’d like to tell you some things that are different, but that aren’t necessarily advertisements for Korean tourism. I like some of the differences, but I wouldn’t say they’re reasons to visit. They are simply things that Koreans do that Americans and other Westerners don’t, or vice-versa, such as…

Using Chopsticks

Yeah, yeah, yeah, big surprise. You know this already. Pretty much any East Asian country uses chopsticks for eating. But Koreans use a different kind of chopsticks. Although chopsticks are made of various materials (especially when people start getting fancy and make them out of ivory or silver), most of them are wooden or bamboo. Koreans, however, use metal chopsticks, and they are the only people who use metal chopsticks as the norm.

Not only are the chopsticks metal, but they are also flat. While you might see round bamboo chopsticks or square-sided wooden chopsticks, the metal chopsticks of Korea are relatively flat.

Notice the metal chopsticks in the middle. They are flatter than the other pairs. So not only is Korea different from Western societies by using chopsticks, the country is also different from other Asian countries by choosing a different material. And also by…

Using a Spoon

You probably noticed the spoon in the above picture. That’s because Korea is also the only Asian country to eat rice and soup with a spoon. Every one else uses chopsticks for rice, and I think that they bring their bowls to their faces for the liquid part of soup. In Korea, though, it’s impolite to drink your soup directly from the bowl (at least traditionally, although I think I’ve seen people do it more often now, especially for the last sips), so you can use a spoon. Also for the rice, too.  So this one isn’t so different at all, except in the length of the spoon. I think the picture above does not adequately represent a typical Korean rice-and-soup spoon. The ones I see and use here have very long handles, maybe 2 inches longer than the one in the picture. Probably for all of the side dish-sharing that goes on at traditional Korean meals.

I used to think using a spoon was chosen as the “easy way out,” but it’s probably more likely just because it makes more sense (and, again, the soup thing). It’s not that Koreans can’t eat rice with chopsticks. They can. I’ve seen them do it. And I’ve also seen them eat fish with chopsticks. I’m talking about whole grilled fish, and they use the chopsticks to remove the head and the tiny little bones. Sure, sometimes I see a co-worker hold down the fish with one hand while tearing it apart with the chopsticks. But many don’t need to. My primary co-teacher, for example, only uses one hand, and before I can blink, she has removed the bones from her bite of fish. Once I can eat fish with chopsticks, I will consider myself a chopsticks master.

There’s one more eating utensil that Koreans use. It might shock you to find out about…

Using a Pair of Scissors

Yes. A pair of scissors. I don’t know the exact reason for it, but I’m going to guess that it has something to do with Confucius. The ideas of Confucius are still very popular in Korea, and he said that it was dishonorable to have a knife at the dinner table. The idea is that knives are for fighting and slaughter, not for dining. This idea is a large reason for the use of chopsticks in Asian countries, and I have a feeling that it also influenced someone, at some point, to cut food at the table with a pair of scissors rather than with a knife.

Anytime you go to a restaurant and they bring you a plate of meat to grill on your table’s barbecue grill, they will also give you a pair of scissors to cut the meat as or after you cook it. You also use it to cut up any vegetables you may have or even the noodles in your soup (if they are the kind of noodles you need to cut right away, lest they stick together in one massive ball of noodles).

Or maybe Koreans just use scissors because, hey, no cutting board required. It’s pretty easy. I think a lot of things in Korea are designed to be easy. Except…

Doing Laundry

Most Koreans don’t own a dryer. I’ve heard that some Guest English Teachers have washers that double as dryers (how cool is that?), but most people have to hang their clothes up to dry. I don’t know if it’s an energy conservation thing, or a money-saving thing, or if Koreans just like clothesline apparel, but they hang up laundry on racks for drying. Our rack hangs from the laundry area ceiling.

Hanging stuff up to dry is nice in a way, because once it’s hanging, you can leave it there and not have to put the clothes in their proper places right away. With dryers, you have to fold and put away the clothes as soon as possible. The downside is, you still have to hang up the clothes right away. And it’s a time-consuming process, especially with socks and underwear. But sometimes, if the clothes need to be dry sooner, you can put them on the floor, and the ondol heating system will speed up the process, if you have it turned on.

You’ll notice now that my transitions are getting weaker. So I’m not even going to pretend I have a good one this time. I’m just going to jump to…

Using Toilet Paper

Oh, no, what am I going to say now? Koreans do use toilet paper, right? Yes, of course they do. But it’s a bit different, mainly for two reasons. The first reason is what to do with toilet paper before using the restroom. Here is the answer: obtain it. If you’re going out in public, it’s a good idea to carry some with you. Not all bathrooms are well-stocked, and I’m sure you would hate to learn that the hard way.

Sometimes, though, there might not be toilet paper in the bathroom stalls themselves, but near the sink there will be a toilet paper dispenser. One of those ones that dispense the 1-ply, non-perforated rolls. I think at first, many foreigners I know thought that Koreans had a strange concept of drying hands. But I think the answer is actually that you pull a few feet from the dispenser before going into the bathroom stall. I guess that makes checking and changing the roll easier. Oh, and you can use it to dry your hands, too.

The other difference, which I’m sure you could guess if you caught onto my clue earlier, regards what to do after using the restroom. Here is the answer: throw away your toilet paper. You don’t flush toilet paper in Korea, especially in public facilities, where the higher volume of waste means pipes are more likely to clog.

I could tell you an advantage to this practice, but it might be a little bit too much information. So I’ll spare you and move onto another difference, which is…

Not Wearing Sunglasses

Koreans hardly ever wear sunglasses, from what one of my co-teachers told me. Apparently some students were asking her why I wear sunglasses. She told me that only certain people wear them at certain times and that it’s not very common. I often forget that my glasses change tint in sunlight, and even after my co-teacher provided that piece of cultural information, I still forget. I wonder sometimes if my dark shades keep Koreans from seeing my eyes and, thus, from thinking that I’m a respectful American. I’d better be, because in Korea, people are concerned with…

Keeping a Reputation

Most countries, including America, have slander and libel laws. Basically, a person or organization can sue you if you tarnish their reputation with spoken or written words, unless you can prove that your words were true. In Korea, that last part doesn’t apply. You could be found liable to pay the plaintiff even if everything you said was accurate and without exaggeration, but still highly damaging to the plaintiff’s reputation. I’ve read that foreign teachers have gotten into trouble because they did not know this law before making public statements regarding the unprofessional practices of certain hagwons (private, after-school academies). The teachers thought of the public statements as warnings to potential job applicants. The hagwons and the government thought of them as reputation destroyers.

Why? Because in Korea, reputation is important, and it’s reflected in the country’s slander and libel laws. (But it’s also reflected in positive things, don’t get me wrong.)

Well, I think that’s it for now. I feel like there should be more. There probably will be more.

(by Brian)

It’s time to discuss a touchy subject. I did not want to write about it because I did not want people being scared.

Japan.

I was surprised to find out, when I came to Korea, that Japan and Korea aren’t exactly the best of friends. Before coming, I thought that they were friendly nations. The United States likes both of the countries, overall, and there are so many things that the two countries have in common, that they have shared with or borrowed from each other. For example, sushi, from Japan, is popular in Korea and influenced the creation of Korean gimbap. And ferries between the two countries promote tourism and weekend visits between both nations.

And gosh, they’re just so darn close to each other.

But apparently there is still some resentment remaining from the time Japan occupied Korea, from 1910 to 1945. And also from the Japanese military’s use of some Korean women during that time as “comfort women” (I’m sure you can guess what it means). I wouldn’t say that Japan and Korea are enemies, but there is definitely tension. Today, it is best shown by their argument regarding the ownership of some very small islands. Japan says the islands belong to them. Korea claims them for itself. Who really owns them? I haven’t really looked into it. But it seems to be a fairly big deal to both countries, at least politically (ownership of the islands indicates what part of the ocean can be fished as domestic and what parts require international trade).

So I was quite shocked to find all of this out. But I was also warmed by the general Korean reaction to the triple catastrophe in Japan nearly a month ago. According to the news, organizations and clubs that normally met to vent emotions regarding the Japanese occupation or the comfort women, either met to pray for Japan or postponed their meetings. Some of these groups are made of survivors of the occupation, or former comfort women, so it was kind of a big gesture. One night I saw a large gathering of very sad-looking people holding candles and signs reading “Pray for Japan.” So the animosity isn’t too deep.

Anyway (yeah, the above was me getting off-topic before I even began), nearly a month ago, Japan got hit by a 9.0 earthquake, which is pretty strong. And by “pretty strong,” I mean, “OH LORD SAVE US!” strong. That earthquake created a tsunami, which, guess what, headed right back for Japan. And those two disasters struck a few nuclear reactors on the East coast of Japan.

So people have naturally been worried about us. Heck, I’ve been worried about us too. But I think we’ll be fine.

A lot of foreigners were expressing concerns on Facebook and Waygook.org (a site for foreigners in Korea and other Asian countries, usually the foreigners who happen to teach English) about the potential for a nuclear catastrophe affecting Korea. People were basically asking, “Should I be ready for a midnight run?” There was chaos for a while. Different people were providing their opinions. Sometimes they actually knew what they were talking about, too. The Korean newspapers (the ones I can read, the ones in English) were filled with reports about citizens in a general panic about what could happen. (Oddly, I never saw it in person until today…more on that later.)

And yeah, I was in a bit of a panic, too. Inwardly, of course, but I worried nonetheless. Would we have to leave the country to flee from the possibility of getting so much radiation poisoning that staying would be stupid? I did not want to do that. I like it here. Plus, leaving would mean violating our contracts, which would have some pretty bad consequences for us.

So I kept reading the news. Everything looked relatively okay. Most experts reassured everyone that Japan’s reactors were safer than the ones in Chernobyl. Even if the worst happened, it would be confined to a relatively small area. A few experts disagreed and said that it could be terrible, but I think even then they were talking in terms of the survival of Japan (as in, the worst case scenario would be, “Oh wow, Japan is DEAD”). Even when the reports said that the nuclear plants were having radiation levels beyond the legal limit, places ten or twenty miles away were barely feeling any differences, so the drop-off rate is pretty good at the moment. And the most popular opinion was that, even if Japan’s reactors melted down to the worst scenario, the seasonal wind patterns would blow the radiation to the Pacific Ocean, and not toward the Korean Peninsula.

But apparently, increased levels of radiation have been found all over the world, but it’s still not enough to pose a serious threat. People are exposed to radiation every day. It comes from the sky, it comes from the ground, and it even comes from our bodies. And that amount that Japan gave to the world is still fairly small in comparison. It’s only the area immediately around the nuclear plants that will probably see some long-term damage.

I saw a site that displayed the radiation measurements for Japan and Korea. In Busan, the measurement was .0025 mSv/hr (millisieverts per hour). That is .9125 mSv/yr. And that number is still lower than the average yearly exposure.

Two days ago, people started saying on the news that today’s rain (Thursday) would include radiation from Japan. Even though the prevailing winds are going toward Japan (and not the other way around), air weather forecasters predicted a current from the nuclear plants to go southeast today. What was southeast of the plant? A clockwise current that was headed west, in our direction. So the fear was that the radiation would travel southeast and then west, along a clockwise pattern, into Korea. And if it rained, that means the radiation would pour down on us.

So, many people were afraid. But by the time I heard about it and looked online for the reports, the weather data had been merged with the radiation data to show that the amount of radiation that would actually still remain by the time it arrived would be almost nothing. Not nothing, but almost nothing.

Still, I wore my biggest jacket and took an umbrella to work today. It was only drizzling, which would diminish the effects, but still.

And when I got to work, I checked the news. The forecasters were wrong. The air from the nuclear plant headed northeast. So it didn’t come near us at all. So in the first few classes of my day, some of my students were expressing fears. I asked them how they were feeling this morning, and they said, “Not good,” or, “Bad,” and so on. Some said, “Rain bad.” Some said, “Japan rain.” And so on. So I told them what I had learned on the news and we started class.

I think the most concerning thing is the oceans and the effect of radiation on the food chain. Fish, seaweed, and seafood are primary parts of the Korea diet. Japan had to dump some radiated water into the ocean to prevent some worse consequences (if I understand correctly, they needed to make room to store even more dangerous water, or to keep water flowing to cool down the reactors…or something). So that’s not cool. But again, this is on the side of Japan opposite Korea, and it’s several hundred miles away. Also, even before this dumping took place, Korea started checking radiation levels on the food being brought into the country from the waters.

So for now, I think we’re alright. Of course I will let you know if we aren’t (and in that case, you will probably know when we’re suddenly back in the United States).

In Korea I see and hear many things that are strange and interesting to me. Some things I like quite a bit.  For instance, I like the way that you can buy fresh fruits and vegetables on street corners.

One Sunday we visited Mr. Lee’s church, and afterward he took us to his home for tea and snacks. On the way there, his wife rolled down the driver’s side window and shouted “Ajumma, ddalgi juseo” or something like that. So the woman working at the little corner shop rushed over, around some other cars, and brought the tray of strawberries to us. Mr. Lee’s wife handed the money out the window and we continued our drive. The whole process took less than a minute. I also like the sound of the fruit and vegetable trucks. These trucks are equipped with loud-speakers and they drive slowly down the street chanting their wares until, presumably, someone hails them to buy some produce. I think the chanting of these trucks is an excellent way for me to remember the Korean names for fruit and vegetables. I’ve already got cabbage (baechu) and strawberry (ddalgi) down pat.

And speaking of strawberries…they taste sweeter in Korea.

I took my own pictures, but something happened to my camera files!

I thought they were in season, because you can buy them anywhere and everywhere. Apparently they’re not. I’m told they will be cheaper when the season comes (ignorant me thought they were already well-priced). Korean strawberries, however out of season they may be right now, taste amazing. They are sweet and delicious. Even the strawberries that have less red coloring are juicy and sweet. For some reason, too, the strawberries all have an elongated shape. In the US, we have many strange and different shapes of strawberry, in Korea, there is only one.

In Korea, many older married women (ajumma) sell the strawberries. They also sell melons and persimmons at fruit stands, and, in the fish market, they sell fish. Interestingly, on one of my trips to Jagalchi fish market, which is a wonderful experience, some actually ajumma came out from behind their booth to touch my hair and say things about it in Korean that I didn’t understand. I was a little surprised. Anyway,  I see them on almost every corner sitting with their vegetables, roots and herbs on the side of the street, or in the subway station.  I see many grandmothers (halmeoni) and grandfathers (halabeoji)  climbing the steep stairs out of the subway.

In Korea it seems, slow and steady wins the race. Even young people approach an incline with slow, steady pacing.  Korean people, young and old, often clasp both hands behind their backs when they walk this way, which gives the appearance of stateliness and determination.

In the morning, on my way to work, I see children running. Korea is a safe country, for the most part. So, even I feel safe walking alone in the city and that’s a first for me. In the mornings, the children often walk alone to school or in pairs. Sometimes I see a mom watching from the top of a hill shading her eyes with her hands as her child makes his way to school. I love it when the children walk in pairs. The older sibling clearly was told to keep hold of their younger brother or sister. I see them gripping their sibling by the backpack or by the hand, as the smaller one tries earnestly to get away from them.

Another thing I notice here in Korea is how Confucian thought has really impacted this country. As Brian has mentioned before, in Korea image is very important. So, too, is status. One type of status comes from age, and this status marker is very respected and  ingrained.

Growing up, I was taught the importance of respecting my elders, asking “May I vs. Can I” answering “Yes” instead of “What” when an elder called my name from another room and the list goes on. One specific way that I was taught to respect my elders was by calling them Mr. and Mrs. SoandSo, or Brother and Sister SoandSo (at church), or Pastor or Dr. Soandso, Aunt and Uncle Soandso for aunts, uncles and family friends; even Cousin Soandso if they are 2nd cousins of my parent’s generation. This upbringing remained deep within me until I was about 20 years old. So much was it a part of me that I felt uncomfortable calling adults by just their first name, even after their insistence that that was what they wanted. It was a strange and painful thing for me to get used to. And I still want to, and still will, call people by the title’s I’ve called them all my life…until they tell me otherwise.

In Korea, they have a similar method of paying respect to elders. In fact, you can’t even use the same words when talking to elders. And, in Korea, they even expand the definition of elder take it a bit further than I’m used to. This is how it goes: Everyone born in the same year is the same age, and so these are your casual “friend group” type people. My orientation Korean class teacher (Amy Teacher) told me on the last day that we were friends because we were both born in 1986. Anyone younger is your subordinate, or younger sibling type and anyone older than you is referred to by title. Even older siblings and schoolmates.

In my case, I am a firstborn child, so I would have the privilege of calling my siblings by their given names . In their cases, however, they would have to call me “Older sister”–Eonni for Ang, or nuna for Jon since the titles are based on gender of the younger sibling. If they called me by name, or even if they called my school friends by name, it would be very shocking and frowned upon. ((I think maybe my brother, Jon, is a pupil of Confucius at heart. When he was young he always called me and Angela, “Sisters”  instead of saying our names lol)).

Anyway, I knew about the name thing before I came to Korea, but I was able to realize it more fully one day in class when we were watching a video for the 4th grade lesson. I teach several different classes of 4th graders and for some reason each time we watched this video all the kids gasped in shock and surprise when the little cartoon girl said to her older brother’s friend “Hello, Anne.” Thus, I have heard younger students calling older students “Eonni” even if they are not sisters, and even adults do this with their friends. As an older sister, I don’t mind this practice.  I do, however, think it’s strange that young women will call their boyfriends “older brother” (Oppa).

All in all,  I really like my new title of teacher (seonsaengnim). I like being called Ashley Teacher–more phonetically, “Eshulee Teach-uh” or even “Eshulee Sun-seng-nim.” I especially enjoy the “nim” honorific at the end.

Because in Korea, being a teacher is an honored and respected position. Call me crazy, but I like being honored and respected.

Actually, just call me Ashley Teacher.

In Korea, my age is 28, and I’ve been 28 for more than 80 days. By American standards, I just turned 27 from 26 a few days ago. That means I had a difference of two between the different age reckonings for almost three months. This kind of thing has made me hesitate whenever someone asks my age. I think, What’s my age again? I’ve thought about it enough that now I know my age, but for a time I was confused.

It’s kind of peculiar, the way Koreans count ages. When you are born, your age is one. When the next calendar year comes, you’re two. And when the next calendar year comes, you’re three. This is how all of the students in a grade are the same age (usually). One day I asked some students how old they were. When I asked the other students in the class, they said, “Teacher, we are all nine years old.” Or maybe it was ten. It didn’t matter if they’d had a birthday already or if they were waiting for one. They were the same age. Of course, many Koreans today still celebrate their birthdays and have small parties and eat cake (although traditionally, the important birthdays in Korea were the 100-day, one-year, and sixty-year birthdays). It’s just that their ages don’t change at that time, unless a person’s birthday is January 1. I think that traditionally, the age changed at the lunar new year, but nowadays it seems they count it by the solar new year.

This way of counting ages makes it possible for a one-day-old baby to be two years old. Born on December 31? You’re one. January 1 comes along and now you’re two. It sounds like an offense to numbers and it’s hard for Westerners to wrap their minds around it, but I’ve come to think of it not as cardinal years, but as ordinal years. When an American says he’s 30 years old, he has completed 30 years of life. I suspect that the reasoning behind Korean reckoning is that a 30-year-old man is on his 30th year of life. A six-month-old baby isn’t one year old yet, but is living in the first year of life. Then tweak the definition slightly more. The man is 28, but he’s on the 30th calendar year of his life. If you count how many calendar years he’s lived in, from 1984 to 2013, you’d count 30 numbers, even if he only lived four months in 1984 and three so far in 2013.

I don’t know if my assumptions are valid, but this is how I make sense of the Korean system.

So I turned 27 (while remaining 28) three days ago. And my students were so nice to me. I had a great two days. Even before my birthday, some of the students were excited. A student in one class had his birthday yesterday, two days after mine. He said every day, “Teacher, your birthday is 21 and my birthday is 23.” A student in another class’s birthday is on the 31st, and he also reminded me in a similar fashion.

Ashley gave me a good idea that I should give all my students a small treat, like a chocolate, for my birthday. I liked that idea, so I went to the store and bought packs of individually wrapped chocolates. Actually, I got a pretty good deal.

At the beginning of class, after I asked the class what day it was and wrote it on the board (“Today is Thursday, March 21, 2013″), I asked them if they knew what today was. In some classes, the students all knew. They had asked me my birthday before (because I had all my students write their birthdays and favorite colors and favorite foods on a chart a couple of weeks ago). In other classes, the students probably only suspected that I was pulling another corny joke. A few times in previous classes I had asked the students if they knew why today was a special day. When they had finally given up, I told them it was because “Today is today.”

But this particular “today” was my birthday. So I told my students, “Today is my birthday. So I bought myself some chocolate. And I’m going to eat it.” The students groaned and expressed their hungry jealousy. In one class I actually unwrapped a piece and ate it. But then I told them, “But I want to share it with you.” So I gave every student a piece.

I have four classes on Thursdays, plus “After School Program” (ASP, or, as we sometimes call it, ASB for “After School Babysitting”). I teach first, second, third, and fourth period on Thursdays, and eighth period for ASP. And I really enjoyed those classes. The students participated well and were generally well-behaved.

In my first class of the day, when I said it was my birthday, one of my students said, “Really?” Then she opened her pencil case, took out a pen, and brought it to me.

In other classes, students gave me Hershey’s kisses or suckers.

And I really enjoyed my birthday. A few days before, a student who knows I can solve a Rubik’s Cube asked me to solve one for her, so I did. I suspect it belongs to one of her relatives. She came to me on my birthday and asked me to solve two more cubes. One was normal, but the other, well, the other looked like this:

Not my picture.

So when I had some free time in the afternoon, I attempted to solve that one. I was dumbfounded for quite some time, until I realized that it does indeed take the shape of a cube when solved. I tried to solve it on my own and made small progress. If it were my cube, I probably would have taken a few more days or weeks before breaking down and reading tips on the Internet. But I had to give this back to my student the next day. (Of course, when I gave it back to her on Friday, I didn’t tell her that I cheated.)

Some of my students on Wednesday had said to me, “I’ll bring you a present tomorrow,” or they said it on Thursday. I told them, “Oh that’s so nice, but you don’t have to.” There’s one who is new to our school and who lived in Berrien Springs for the past two years. On Thursday after school (she doesn’t have my class on Thursdays), she came to me and said she was going to bring me a gift the next day. When I said I didn’t expect that, that she didn’t have to do that, she cutely said, “I NEED TO!” On Friday she saw me in the hallway before lunch and had me follow her to her main classroom so she could give me the present. She said, “There’s two, but one’s in Korean.” I thought, “Oh, how nice. She knows I like learning Korean.” So she gave me some children’s devotional books. Actually, I think the Korean one will help me learn more Korean, and the English one might be good for Sabbath school and whatnot.

On Thursday morning, two of my students, sisters from the second and third grades, came to the English teachers’ office before classes started and smilingly gave me this:

The roll cake and the plaid stuffed rabbit. (The pen is the same one from before, not part of these particular students’ gift.)

I was very touched. Teacher Heather said the students must really love me, that the other teachers don’t get such nice gifts. But they do. Ashley got quite a few gifts and cards on her birthday. She got a nice ceramic cup that has a smiling face and says, “THIS IS NOT A PAPER CUP” But it does seem like they were a little excessive for me. Maybe it’s because it’s the beginning of the school year, so they’re full of energy.

I also gave a piece of chocolate on Friday to the students who didn’t have classes with me on Thursday. A student from one of these two classes wrote me a nice little note, although it was full of lies:

She says that she doesn’t study in class but only plays, but that’s not true. She’s not one of the smartest students in her grade when it comes to English class, but she’s in the low-level classes, she’s one of the smartest students. She participates more than the average student. She’s also very polite and friendly.

Finally, for my last class of the day, sixth period, I had the most intense birthday class ever. First, I was in the English teachers’ office switching books and materials from fourth-and-fifth-grade conversation class to third-grade language arts class. As I was about to leave the room to go to class, one of my students stood in the doorway and told me not to go to class. Sometimes the students do this so they aren’t considered late by reason of being in class before the teacher is. But when she continued to block my way I saw what she was up to. Nonetheless, I played along. I walked, with her putting her hands out to keep me from moving forward. I walked, and she slowly slid backwards. We neared the water dispenser and she told me to have a drink. “Well, I am kind of thirsty,” I said, and took a drink of water. Then some other student down the hall called out something and then my student said, “Okay, you can go to class now.” So we went to the classroom, where the students jumped out from behind the TV and from under desks and from behind the door and said, “Happy birthday!”

And they had things drawn on the white board.

When I went to take a picture of it, most of the students ran to the front of the classroom to be in the picture. Of course, they wanted me in it, too, so one of the boys who didn’t want to be in the picture took it.

My students made me feel so special.

On Thursday nights, we go to Korean class. Our friend Linda surprised me by meeting us at the bus stop with a cake. That turned out to be why Ashley said she didn’t feel like bringing snacks to class, like she had previously suggested. So for the last thirty minutes of Korean class, the five of us (four students and the Korean teacher, although sometimes there are more students who show up) ate cake and drank Milkis (a Korean milk soda that I’m quite fond of).

And when we came home, toward the end of my birthday (by Korean time), my sister got on Skype so I could talk to her and two of my three nieces for a few minutes. (At the time, it was Friday morning in Michigan, so I suspect my eldest niece was at school.)

And they made a birthday cookie:

I hope they ate it. ^_^

(by Brian)

Ashley and I went on our second hike today. There’s a mountain next to our apartment complex called 백양산 (Baekyangsan), and it has a nice hiking path. But just so you don’t get disappointed later, I’ll tell you now that we did not reach the top. So, lower your expectations.

Done? Good. You may continue reading.

First we ate a couple of packets of instant oatmeal that we brought with us to Korea. We were low on groceries (we had some frozen vegetables, of course, but not much else), so we settled for a bit of oats. We also did some laundry so that our clothes would have plenty of time to dry before tomorrow (remember, we only have a drying rack). And then we left. First we stopped by a convenience store to get a few snacks so we wouldn’t feel starved. We also had bottles of water. So then we set out for the mountain.

The cherry blossoms outside our apartment look nice.

Which means that our journey was pleasantly beautiful before we even started the hike proper.

After a few minutes, we were at the start of the path. It was a much easier path than the one at 금정산 (Geumjeongsan). Of course, Geumjeongsan has multiple paths, and so does Baekyangsan.

I know you want me to get on with it and get to the pictures, so here you go. Ashley is walking up the slope.

The side of Geumjeongsan we hiked had lots of boulders and trees. This place had lots of grass and trees and flowers.

I think a lot of the lower parts used to be farms. This looks like a former rice paddy.

I wanted a picture next to some of the cherry blossoms. So here it is.

And here is Ashley in front of some nice flowers.

After a bit of hiking, Ashley and I came to a clearing with several different paths. There was even a dirt road. I don’t think many, if any, cars drive on it, but we saw a bike. An old man near a tent in this clearing (I think the tent is the equivalent of a park ranger cabin, but that’s only a guess) tried to talk to us. We didn’t understand what he said except when he pointed up at the looming mound of earth and said, “Baekyangsan.” Ashley and I had been awake for several hours and had eaten one packet of instant oatmeal a piece, so we decided then that we would try again some other day. We needed to eat more than the trail snacks we had. And it’s not like the mountain was far away.

So we headed back down the mountain. We took a slightly different path, and at one point an elderly couple talked to us and (we think) told us which of two paths was the better one to take. I think we followed their advice (unless they told us not to go that way). It was good advice.

So we’ll be up that mountain again a few times at least, and you’ll get to see more of it if you keep checking this site.

After that, we went back home and then to a local 김밥천국. There are a few types of restaurants in Korea that are staples of Korean cuisine. Two of these eateries are the 김밥천국 (gimbap cheonguk) and the 김밥나라 (gimbap nara). They’re essentially the same thing: small homestyle restaurants with a few hardcore Koreans who serve up some great tasting Korean food at very decent prices. You can find many of the most famous and common Korean staples at these places. Ashley ordered the 참치찌개 (chamchi jjigae, or tuna jjigae/stew), and I got a boiling bowl of 욕개장 (yugkaejang, a very spicy beef stew).

Yummy food pictured here. Total price: ₩8500, aka $7.85.

The food is very good. We paid the equivalent of a trip to McDonald’s or Taco Bell and had food that both tasted better and was better for us. And I wasn’t lying about the boiling bowl, either. Koreans serve you soup so fresh it’s still bubbling. I tried to take a picture but it only fogged my camera lens!

After this we went to a relatively local HomePlus to get some groceries (remember earlier that I said we had no food). HomePlus is like a department store, in a way, that also has an entire floor devoted to being a supermarket. So while the local grocery store will work for most occasions, it’s nice once in a while to drop by HomePlus. We have to take a cab back, but it’s very cheap and close to the cost of both of us paying the bus fare, because the HomePlus is not much farther away than the maximum distance the base cab fare (about 2 dollars) can take us.

We’d been to HomePlus a few times. We’ve even bought a few things, but only a few. But today we learned a lot of lessons on what to do at a HomePlus next time we go.

We got two baskets to fill with groceries because we didn’t think about carts until we were on the second floor (the grocery floor), and the carts are on the first floor. Oh well, I said, we’ll use baskets. We did our shopping and then got to the checkout counter. The clerk asked if we wanted bags and I said we’d just use boxes. (In Korea, they charge you for bags, and I figured it would be sturdier to pack our groceries in recyclable boxes like I saw everyone else doing.)

But of course, I hadn’t thought of how to get our groceries to the packing counter. Apparently, the baskets are tagged so you can’t take them beyond the checkout counter. And I had already denied bags. This moment was when I noticed that everyone at the packing counter also had carts. Carts which were, I remind you, on the floor below. And HomePlus is always a pretty crowded store. And also, for the purpose of finishing this thought regarding the boxes and bags, I skipped something else that had happened.

The clerk pointed to two bottles of juice we had, one aloe and one grapefruit. He said, “Buy one get one free.” The store was very crowded and we also considered saying, “It’s okay, we don’t want to back up the line,” but that was impossible. Plus it was nice to have four bottles of juice for the price of two. So Ashley went to get two more bottles of juice. And then I finished the transaction and paid for the groceries.

And, uh, then I waited at the end of the counter with the groceries piled up against the rail. Finally Ashley came back and the very nice clerk added the two bottles of juice to our groceries. Then Ashley and I tried to figure out how to get our groceries to the packing counter. Hmmmmm, I thought. I could guard the groceries while Ashley goes to pack them trip by trip. But that would have been a nightmare.

So Ashley went downstairs to get a cart. She was followed the whole time, I learned later, by an annoying Korean woman who was probably also certifiably insane. She assumed Ashley was Libyan (probably because of the current events, but that’s pretty dumb if you ask me) and, when told that she was incorrect, asked which part of Africa Ashley came from.

“I came from America,” Ashley responded.

“Well what part of Africa are your parents from?”

“My parents were born in America. My grandparents were born in America.” Seems kind of stupid, and it probably was (as I said, the woman was probably insane, as she told Ashley all sorts of crazy things including about her attempts to build a Lotte Department Store). But since Korea is pretty homogenous, it’s easy for them to imagine that other countries have similar traits of uniformity. Americans are white, Koreans are Asian, and Africans are black, and so on. It’s kind of ignorant, but at the same time, pretty much every culture, no matter how “multicultural,” is ignorant about other parts of the world or even regions of their own nations. That includes you and me.

Finally the woman went away and Ashley figured out how to get a cart. You have to put a 100 won coin in to get the cart to unlock it, and you get that coin back when you return the cart. But it wasn’t obvious, of course. Which means I had to wait quite some time for Ashley to return. Long enough, in fact, for the clerk to feel sorry for me and give me some bags for free. I thanked him and said 죄송합니다 (joesonghamnida), but I’m not sure if he heard that last part, which means, “I’m sorry.” Then I waited for Ashley to come back with a cart. I waited a few minutes, and then we finally left. We learned a lot of very important things during that trip. We probably won’t go to HomePlus again for a few weeks or so.

But next time we do, we’re getting a cart.

(by Brian)

Languages are strange. I can’t help but realize more and more each day just how strange they are, especially once you look at them from a foreigner’s perspective. When we speak, we don’t say what we mean. So languages follow one of my favorite principles, the gestalt principle, in that the meanings of the things we say transcend the meanings of the words we use to say them.

Wait. What?

The sole solution to such a conundrum, I think, is to communicate eruditely, like this, figuratively separated from casual communication. (The only way to not do it is to speak with big words that aren’t slang.) But that also has its disadvantages.

At work, I have to speak simply, and I find it very hard. For much of my life, I thought that my vocabulary level was low. I learned, therefore, how to better understand the meanings of words. Through essay-writing for college courses and having discussions with my friends, I learned differences in the connotations and uses of words that the thesaurus claimed meant the same thing. And so I often choose my words carefully, and sometimes that means also choosing the most impressive word that would fit the occasion (not because I’m trying to be a show-off, but simply for reasons of verbal economics). See? “Verbal economics” was a way of putting into two words what I could have said with 23: choosing the words that I speak in order to let me speak the fewest number of words and with the most precise meaning.

Now that you’ve finished counting the words in that last sentence, allow me to continue. I’m finding out more and more just how difficult my job is. When I first came to Korea and started teaching English to high school girls, I thought I would have to slow down my rate of speech a bit. And I do have to do that. But I also have to choose my words carefully so that my students will understand. I even have to avoid phrases that are made of words they know but that mean something different when you put them together. Which, as I’m learning, seems to be probably three quarters of the English language.

Earlier in this post, I said, “I find it very hard,” but it doesn’t mean that. I’m not finding anything. Even if the word “find” is in the dictionary for meaning “realize,” it’s there because of common usage. We say all kinds of things that use words having little to do with what they mean. “It dawned on me,” for example, would go over my students’ heads (and maybe even some of my co-workers). We have internalized that metaphor and we take it for granted. Even things that don’t require metaphors provide difficulty for language learners. One of my students, who seems to be well beyond her peers in English proficiency, asked me what Justin Bieber meant when he sang the phrase, “You know you love me.”

If you look at someone, that person might ask you, “What?” as in, “What are you staring at me for?” or “What do you want to say to me?” In Korea, if you stare at someone, that person might ask you, “왜?” which means “Why?” as in, “Why are you looking at me?” But it means the same (for the situation) as “What?” Here’s another one: I just taught some of my students the phrase “take up” as in, “If I had more free time, I would take up the piano.” The words “take” and “up” have little to do with the meaning of the phrase “take up.” We have hundreds of phrases like this in English.

So do you see the problem? If you were a foreigner in Korea and a Korean started staring at you (which is not at all implausible and is, in fact, rather likely), you could not look in your English-Korean dictionary to find the word for “What?” Because even though 뭐? means “What?” in Korean, saying 뭐? does not translate to “thing to say to someone who is staring at you.” You couldn’t tell them about figuring out an answer by translating “dawned.” Heck, I think even “figure it out” is not quite clear because “figure” is a shape or prominent person. “Shape it out”? What do you mean?

That’s why people say you have to be able to think in a language in order to be fluent. You can’t translate words. You have to translate phrases that have similar purposes, not equivalent meanings.

*Lost in Translation (using words that don’t quite mean the same as “lost” or “translation”)

Last week I posted about my birthday. I had meant to include a few more things in that post, but I forgot them. I was going to make a new post the next day, but this week was one of my most intense and stressful work weeks. I had no time for a post, and I’m quite glad it’s over. I’ll briefly tell you about the things I neglected here, and I’ll add a couple of other things.

One thing I meant to say in my post was that in addition to the students treating me so nicely for my birthday, some of my students even treated me well before and after that. With a few exceptions, in a class including some fourth-graders and some fifth-graders, I don’t teach fifth grade. I teach all of fourth grade. So the fourth-grade students I taught last year, for the most part, don’t have me as a teacher this year. A few weeks ago, while erasing the whiteboard at the end of a class, some of the fifth graders came into the classroom for their next English class with another teacher. One of the students groaned, “Teacherrr.” The tone suggested that he wants me for a teacher again. And he said as much, too. “Teacher, I like you. Come back.” Or something like that. Perhaps he doesn’t really think I’m a good teacher, but maybe in comparison to his new teacher, or his harder curriculum, he has fond memories.

And it’s not just him. I went into that classroom to retrieve my materials before a class started one day and some of the students said, “Teacher, come back!” I don’t think it’s the whole class at all, and again, maybe it’s because of the new subject (fifth-graders exchange their science class for social studies, but the books we have for “social studies” class are more like language arts books*) or a stricter teacher, but such things make me feel good anyway.

And now for those other things.

만두

Almost every civilization has some sort of dumpling. In Korea, it’s called 만두, or mandu [mahn-doo]. Everyone loves mandu. I love mandu, Ashley loves mandu, we all love mandu. The problem is that all mandu available at the store includes pork, which Ashley and I don’t like to eat. I remember how upset Ashley was when I learned the word for pork (돼지고기) and saw that the package of mandu in our freezer had that word on it. I went to the store and looked on various packages of mandu to find one without 돼지고기 in its ingredients. After I learned more Korean, I asked a store worker if there were any porkless mandu available. The answer was no.

This means we have two ways of eating mandu. One is to go to the noodle house in town, owned by a Seventh-day Adventist, which serves delicious pheasant mandu (and delicious cold noodles, one of my favorites). The other is to make our own mandu. So we learned how.

A couple of weeks ago some of the English teachers at my school organically decided to have a Korean-themed potluck-style dinner party. I thought that 참치찌개 (tuna kimchi stew) or mandu would be a good choice for us to make, but one of our friends, because of her love for cows, doesn’t eat beef. So I considered some kind of meatless mandu and found a good recipe for cheese mandu on YouTube. I’m pretty sure cheese mandu is a Westernization. But oh, is it a delicious Westernization.

We made three big plates of it. That red stuff on the left is 떡볶이 (ddeokbokki), a somewhat spicy kind of chewy rice cake snack. The green bottle on the right is Milkis, a delicious milk soda. So it wasn’t exactly the healthiest of dinner parties.

We had a lot of fun making mandu with our friends. In fact, the next week we went to the store and bought more ingredients to make some, and we made a massive batch. So massive that we couldn’t even fry them all, but put them in bags and into the freezer for later cooking (which was the plan anyway).

Everyone in town must have decided to make mandu that weekend, because when we went to the store to get some 만두피 (mandu skins), there were only five packages left. We only used three or four, but we thought we would make more and bought all five. The next day I told my students that I made mandu and one of them said, “Teacher, did you buy at 농협 mart?” I said that I did. Had she seen me there and I didn’t say hello? My student sighed and said that she and her friend went to the store to find mandu skins, but there were none, and they went to another store, and another store, and another store, and they were all gone. And apparently at the store we went to, the clerk told her that some foreigners took the rest of the mandu skins. Uh-oh, did she think we cleared the whole town of 만두피? I said that there were only a handful of packages left when we got to the store, and that seemed to make her feel a bit better. I asked her the next day if she could find 만두피 yet and she said that Harmony Mart had some (which I thought it would, because Harmony Mart is one of the biggest supermarkets in town and she hadn’t mentioned it in her list of 만두피-less stores).

좀비

Ashley was teaching a class about the word “please.” The students had to make posters with “Please” or “Please don’t.” Of course they made things like, “Please don’t shout” and “Please don’t jump.” But here’s my favorite:

Seriously, knock it off.

After we cemented all of the decisions and had made the orders, we discovered an actual social studies book, a sample copy, in one of the Korean teacher’s classrooms. It must have been sent to the wrong room and the teacher didn’t know what to do with it. Teacher Heather was quite sad when she saw that book. We looked through it and it looks awesome. (by Brian)

We saw Kristina again. She will be leaving in less than two weeks to go back to the North American continent, so we met her in Seoul. Because she came to Busan a few weeks ago, we originally planned to visit her in Gumi. However, plans changed. Or should I say, Cirque du Soleil came to Seoul.

Hmmmm. Cirque du Soleil. Seoul. Cirque du Seoul, eh? Not funny? Okay.

So, yes, we met in Seoul to see Cirque du Soleil together. And I’ll tell you about the show later, but first I have to tell you what happened before the show.

We got lost.

It’s a good thing that we took an early train to Seoul to get the most out of our weekend, because if we had only arrived in time to see Cirque du Soleil, we wouldn’t have. We left Busan at 10 am on Saturday and arrived in Seoul around 12:30. Two and a half hours to cross the entire country. The KTX, I must say, is awesome. What happened after we got off, however, was not.

Ashley and Kristina had found a hotel somewhat close to the show. Before we left Busan, I used Google Maps to tell me how to get to it from the train station. This was our plan: Get off the train, get to the hotel to check in, then explore the surrounding area until Kristina arrived. We had to check in before the show because the check-in time ended an hour after the start of the show. So on a piece of paper I wrote down what subway stations we had to stop at to get to the hotel.

But apparently I wrote them down wrong. We had to take two lines to get to the area near the hotel (and then, after that, the map looked simple enough). We got on the first line and then I got a bit confused. I wrote down that we needed to go four stops, to 당고개 (Danggogae). But Danggogae was at the very end of the line, about 16 stops away. At the fifth stop, I realized that we should have gotten off one stop before, so we got off and got on the opposite direction subway train. The name of the fourth stop was the name I had written down as “Walk to [this place].” So instead of getting off at Danggogae and walking to another stop to transfer, I was simply supposed to transfer by getting off at the actual stop. Okay, sounds about right.

So we got on the second line. And I only had one more name written down: 마천 (Macheon). And it was, you guessed it, at the end of the line. But I did not, unfortunately, realize what that meant. With the case of Danggogae, I had written down the other station’s name. With Macheon, however, I was aware of no other station. So we went a few stops beyond our actual stop and then we left the metro entirely. It was a dumb mistake, and now I definitely know to check whether the directions say, “Take line X to Y,” or, “Take line X toward Y.” We got out in what looked like the poor residential area of Chicago. I was expecting Seoul to be massive, with high rises everywhere. This place must have been on the very edge of the city. I couldn’t imagine the hotel being nearby, but we took a walk anyhow. It was supposedly 15 minutes by foot, so we headed in the direction we thought we were supposed to go.

Nope. Nothing. “Well,” we said, “at least we’re getting in some exercise today.”

And we got a lot of exercise that day. We walked for quite some time before deciding to go to a PC 방 (PC bang, or room) to recheck our facts. And Ashley had been right. We saw a stop called Olympic Park, and she thought that was near the show and wanted to get off there. It wasn’t near the show, but it was near our hotel, and it was our actual stop.

So we went back to the subway station and went to Olympic Park. And it’s a nice park, but we wanted to get to our hotel so we could stop searching, feel relaxed, and get something to eat. According to Google Maps, the hotel was actually in the park.

It wasn’t. But some nice information desk woman pointed us in the right direction and said that we weren’t far. As it turns out, though, there are numerous hotels and motels in the direction she pointed us in. We couldn’t find it. We called Kristina to find out how close she was because, well, by now, it was almost time for her to arrive. We had been lost for hours. Kristina was almost at her last train stop, which was one stop over from another stop we were now near (but not the one Google told us to end at).

So we just went to that stop so we could all find the hotel together. She knew how to get to it from that stop, so that’s what we did. And finally we all got to the hotel and checked in and got something to eat. And the hotel was quite nice, actually. Korea has things called “love motels,” which, from what I hear, are considerably luxurious for the price. They also have a reputation, which I am sure you can guess by the name. The placed we stayed at, The Hotel Cello, was apparently a former love motel that tried to reinvent itself. I’m not sure if it did or not, and to be honest, I don’t care. Because this is where we got to stay for the night:

I have never been in a hotel that provided a big screen TV plus a computer with Internet service.

I just like where the sink is, for some reason. I just do. Also, notice all the stuff they provide at Korean hotels. We had, if we wanted it, lotion, shaving cream, toothpaste, bug spray, a water kettle, and so on.

A very nice shower. You can actually set it so that the large overhead nozzle runs at the same time as the moveable handheld shower head. And Ashley liked how the mirror covered an entire wall of the bathroom.

Is that a--No! It isnt! - Actually, yes it is. A two-person whirlpool tub next to the very comfy bed. I think a room this nice could easily cost, in America, two or three times what we paid.

And now, finally, the show. We saw Cirque du Soleil’s Varekai show. I honestly was not expecting much. Ashley and Kristina were the more excited of us three, and I simply hoped that the show would be decent. I hoped that it would live up to the hype that Cirque du Soleil has in general, but I feared that Cirque du Soleil might have been so popular just because it seemed like something that should have been popular. I was afraid that people walked away from shows saying, “It was fantastic!” only because dissing Cirque du Soleil would be akin to blasphemy. Or to convince themselves that the show was worth the time and money.

And while my two favorite stage shows remain The Blue Man Group and JUMP, I did absolutely and enthusiastically enjoy Cirque du Soleil. We were not allowed, of course, to take pictures, but let me tell you about it. Just a bit.

When the show was starting to start (it was hard to tell when it actually did), I thought, Oh no. It was just a bunch of people in strange costumes crawling around on stage or doing “interpetive dance.” This is going to get acclaimed simply for looking strange and maybe for having a shallow thematic blanket, I thought. But then the show was definitely in motion, and it was funny. There were all kinds of acts. Sometimes comedy or (obviously fake) magic acts, sometimes unbelievable acrobatics, sometimes even something with a “volunteer” pulled from the audience. Quite fun.

Kristina took this picture of us before the show outside the circus tent.

What I enjoyed most about the show was the timing of the music that fit nearly every move perfectly. I did not realize that the music was live, so I thought that every move was timed perfectly to match the music. But the music was indeed live, meaning the music was timed perfectly to match the moves. It was very intense.

And then it was over, and then we went for drinks at a coffee shop. (Sound familiar to our last visit with Kristina?) I got a mint hot chocolate that was mighty tasty. And we talked about all kinds of things, from Korea to God to food to the show we just saw and more. And finally, we went to our hotel rooms, deciding on the way what time to meet each other again in the morning.

On Sunday morning, we got up and met for breakfast at a local gimbap restaurant. We thought the menu was a bit expensive compared to gimbap places we were used to, but we quickly found out the answer: larger portions. We got stuffed. It’s something that doesn’t often happen to me in Korea unless I eat Western food. Korean food is so reliant on vegetables that, while I often eat enough, I rarely eat to the point of feeling overwhelmingly full.

Then we took a walk over to Olympic Park. It was very nice, but Ashley and I could not enjoy it when we passed through the day before because we wanted to find our hotel. One nice thing about the park was seeing the cherry blossoms. They bloomed in Busan a few weeks ago and have started to fade away. Seoul’s spring started a bit later, so the blossoms were still fresh while we were there.

I think these and pink magnolias are my favorite flowered trees.

More cherry blossoms. Youre probably getting tired of them by now.

Ashley and Kristina walking toward whatever Olympic monument that thing is.

The view was better on the other side of the bridge, but thats also right where the sun was at, meaning taking a decent picture was near impossible for me. Anyway, the view on this side was still quite nice.

We went to the Express Bus Terminal so Kristina could get her bus ticket. (Ashley and I had our train tickets already, but even if we missed the train, we could get new tickets for free because we bought the foreigner-friendly Happy Rail Pass, which gave us a certain length of time to ride the trains rather than a certain number of rides.) And you can probably guess what we did next. We went to a coffee/bread shop in the bus terminal. It was nice to chat, although eventually we all realized that we should get something to eat. Breakfast a few hours previous and the bread treats at Paris Baguette made us feel relatively full, but we all decided that we should eat something just before leaving so that we wouldn’t be hungry on the train.

So we ate some kimchi mandu (Korean dumplings). They were good. Then we went our separate ways.

This dragon was waiting for us outside Busan Station when we got home.

Note: After I talked to some co-workers about my trip to Seoul and about how massive the subway system is in that city, at least three of them, in separate conversations, mentioned that even they have difficulty navigating around Seoul and get easily confused by the massiveness of the subway system. It made me feel a bit better.

(by Brian)

 

Ashley and I have met a lot of people since yesterday and we’re having a great time getting to know many of them. But there’s one new friend I would especially like to introduce you to: the vending machine.

I met the vending machine very soon after my arrival at Pukyong National University. I already mentioned one drink in my first post of this blog. Now I’ll tell you a bit more about them, and you can learn what kinds of fun and exciting culture shock I’ve run into already.

The three cans above are the Korean drinks I’ve consumed since my arrival. In fact, I consumed them in order, from left to right, starting with…

Janchijip Sikhye

This is the rice drink I mentioned above. It’s made by 롯대 (Lotte), a name that I expect to see attached to products, signs, and places all across Korea. In fact, all three beverages in this post are made by Lotte.

It tasted quite like I expected it would based on the can’s design, a sweet rice drink flavor. What I didn’t expect was the level of sincerity the can’s design conveyed. There really is rice floating around in the drink. Once in a while I would get a grain, which would be all chewy from sitting in liquid. At the end of the can, there was a lot more rice. I should have shaken up the can to more evenly distribute the rice.

The rice drink was good (I did mention before that it was yesterday’s breakfast), but not as good as…

 

Milkis

밀키스 (milkiseu, but known in English as Milkis) is my favorite of the three drinks featured in this post. I was confused at first because it was called Milkis but the can says “New feeling of soda beverage.” I thought for a second that the line was just a mistranslation that occurs with lots of foreign products.

No. The can is not misleading at all. With a name like Milkis, you’d expect it to have milk. And you’d be correct. And with a slogan like “New feeling of soda beverage,” you’d expect it to have  corn syrup and carbonation. And, again, you’d be correct. Milkis, my friends, is a dairy soda.

And do you know what my assessment of dairy sodas is after trying this drink? I’ll tell you: it’s positive. I said to Ashley after my first sip that it “tastes like a rice drink but also a lot like an Orange Dreamsicle!” (Apparently, they’re actually called Orange Creamsicles and I keep thinking it’s Dreamsicle.) She took a sip and told me to take it away before she drank all of my soda.

So Milkis was good, and because of our medical exam today, we were told to fast starting at 9 PM last night. So to make sure my fast was as short as possible, I visited my mechanical beverage-dispensing friend for a third time yesterday around 8:45, and I tried…

Koko Podo

코코포도(Koko Podo) is translated pretty clearly on the can as “Coco Grape.” And that’s pretty much what it tasted like: a cross between coconut and grape juice. Maybe more grape, which is to be expected.

What wasn’t expected was the manifestation one of the ingredients I was able to read on the can. In the picture to the left, on the top right of the visible portion of the can there are some red letters. The top line reads ,”백포도과즙 10%,” (baegpodoguajeup) meaning “White grape juice 10%.” I had to use Google Translate to figure that out. I did not, however, have to use it to figure out the bottom line, which reads, “코코넛젤리 8%.” The transliteration of that is “kokoneotjelli,” which sounds pretty much like “coconut jelly.”

After I drank a few ounces of this stuff, something semi-solid touched my lips for just a split second before descending back into the can. Now imagine it yourself. You’re drinking something that has the constant consistency of juice. Then something touches your lips and retreats. Wouldn’t you suspect some bug might have moved away from being eaten by a human?

No? Oh. Well, I did. So I poured the can into a cup and, well, it was just a chunk of coconut jelly. There were several of them in the can, now in my cup, and they were pretty good.

Praise the LORD, because we’re still living well in Korea. We have our days, but who doesn’t?

In high school, one of my friends remarked, upon seeing me with yet another novel supplementing my official school materials, that I read books “like normal people read newspapers.” Actually, I was never much into newspapers. Is that a normal-people thing? But if a month ago you had asked me about what good books I’d read lately, I would have cast my eyes down in shame.*1 A book every four or five months, give or take? I know that my priorities in life have changed in the years and that I won’t even think of putting READ EVERYTHING on my bucket list, but I have to make at least some time for a good book.

And it’s looking up. I read two books this week. And I read another a few weeks ago. That one, Cloud Atlas,*2 was for the book club I recently joined (oh, update: I joined a book club last month, the same book club Ashley joined last year), but the two this week were for my own pleasure. Just typical-length, page-turner science fiction novels that I bought at the used section of What The Book?, but I have plans to get around to that patient copy of Dostoevsky’s Demons that has been waiting on our B&N nook.

So what’s with all this balderdash about books? I recognized one of the reasons that I haven’t been reading much lately. Or writing. So I dealt with it and managed to, I think, decrease a major part of that obstacle. So maybe, just maybe, a month won’t pass without an update on this blog, as April did. And January. And last August. LORD willing, of course (James 4:13-15).

This week was rather strange. Because of scheduling and field trip reservation issues, we only had one normal day of work this week. That day was Monday. On Tuesday, the third and fourth graders went on a three-day-two-night field trip. So they came to school today. On Wednesday, the fifth and sixth graders went for the same duration. They weren’t in school today. The first and second graders, all who remained in school on Wednesday and Thursday, went on a day trip yesterday (Thursday). So we teachers went with them. We went to Pinnacle Land, a lovely garden about an hour away from Gwangcheon. It really is a beautiful place.

Last weekend was a three-day weekend. Friday was Buddha’s Birthday. Our upcoming anniversary is on a workday, so we went to Seoul for the weekend as an early celebration. We met and went to church with Sister Maxine from Ashley’s church back home. She came to Korea to work for Sahmyook University as a professor of public health (if memory serves me correctly). As it turns out, Sahmyook University is not on the same campus as the Sahmyook Language Institute. And I’m sorry to say it if you’re reading this from Our Dear AU, but 삼육대학교 is the most beautiful Adventist campus I’ve set foot on (a grand total of three). I won’t diminish the elegance of the campus with amateur cell phone photos, which is a synonymic phrase for “Sorry, I was too lazy to take pictures.” Some of the people there said we just visited at a lucky time of the year, though.

We also ate some delicious food. Two standouts among our dining experiences that weekend were On the Border, the best Mexican food we’ve had yet in Korea, and 서래불고기-한상차림 (Seorae Bulgogi – Hansang Charim), a place where you can eat high quality Korean beef cooked over charcoal right at your table.

Finally, we saw Umoja, a South African production that consisted of various South African dances and music, traditional and modern, structured around a loose narrative. I enjoyed most of it.

Then we ate dinner and came back to Gwangcheon to go back to work on Monday. That reminds me that I was wrong earlier. Monday was not the only normal work day this week. There was no normal work day. The first three periods of Monday were canceled for the annual English competition semi-finals. Each English teacher was assigned to judge a different classroom, where students had gathered according to what activities they had chosen to do for the competition. Singing, storytelling, giving a speech, writing a letter, writing a book report, writing an essay, and translating a small document. Students had to pick two categories (one spoken/sung and one written). Teachers had to give scores and choose the top six students in each age bracket, who will perform in the final competition this coming Wednesday, where all the teachers will judge every category. Should be fun.
