It’s been a while. What have we been up to?

Well, for one, we just got back from a field trip with our Sabbath school group to Gunsan. Normally, English Adventure Club ends at 11:30, but today we ended at 3:00. Our school booked an entire train car and we went to Gunsan, about an hour away, to have a picnic at a dam. It was good that, even though our group left some of the seats empty, we had the whole car to ourselves. The students had a lot of fun on the train and they were not afraid to let everyone know it. Train rides are usually quieter than that. I can only imagine what other passengers would have felt if they had been stuck with us. :-) Just so you know, I loved hearing all that excitement and screaming. In the classrooms it’s not fun to hear, but I loved spending time with the students on the train and outdoors, with no curriculum to get through.

I really enjoy my job. English teachers in Korea often worry that they’ll be stuck here in a job that isn’t their career, but for the time being, I’m not worried about that. Actually I was just telling Ashley last night that even though this semester has been the hardest semester at our school (for reasons related to scheduling, government interference, student placement, and a few other issues I should not express so publicly), I’m actually having some of the best times of my life overall (praise God). For one, I think God has blessed me with better teaching skills. I still have a long way to go before I become a true super teacher like our friends Linda and Courtney, or like our school’s fifth grade teacher, but I’m getting better and I won’t belittle myself with false modesty on that point. I think one of the keys has been getting to know the students more.

One of the things I dislike most about living in South Korea is being away from my family, especially the people in it who are growing the fastest and therefore have leaps and bounds of growing up done between visits home. By that I mean my nieces, who are growing up so fast. The longer I’m here, the less of them I get to see (I’m glad Skype exists, though, and I should use it more often to see them). I’ve realized, though, that what Jesus said about leaving family and receiving it a hundredfold in this life is true. I miss my family back home, but for now I have such a large family. Everyone at work gets along super great, and the children…I love our students. When I first came to this school, it was a job. I did not know these children and I did what I could for the students because that’s what I’m supposed to do. As time has gone by, however, my care for the students has multiplied, and I’m glad that God has blessed me with the chance to know them and to, I hope, be a positive influence for them. And I think that this is one of the reasons I’m a better teacher now.

Another thing that has made life great despite the hardships of crazy work situations is that God has blessed me with more peace than I’ve had. It took me a long time to realize that I wasn’t always accepting the peace God was trying to give me. Lately, I’ve been feeling that peace more often. A large part of it stems from a simple decision to not dwell on negative thoughts unnecessarily, but to submit them to Christ and choose to think instead of things that are better. So if there’s a problem I have no control over and so thinking about it is a waste of my time, or if I’m annoyed, or if I’m tempted to think some other evil, I have to let Christ deal with it instead while I pray for my family, pray for my students, thank God for my blessings, think about my stories, think about what I’d like to do for my next vacation, or even just look forward to the meal Ashley and I had planned to eat. I’m not some expert at this kind of thinking, but even doing it a little is so much better than dealing with the stress that comes from negative thoughts and feelings.

I mentioned my stories, and that’s something else that has made my life great and for which I can thank God. Early this year I decided to add two things to the list of required daily activities (things that are required every day are, for example, breathing, drinking water, praying, reading the Bible, and telling my wife I love her). I added playing bass guitar and writing short stories. I have missed a few days of playing my bass guitar (when I’m away from home for the weekend, for example, or that day I was sick and simply forgot), but I have not missed a day of writing, even if it was only one sentence (which is the daily minimum; five minutes of playing is the minimum for bass guitar). These hobbies have given me more joy in life, especially the writing. I take this hobby seriously. I want to get better at it. And I find, as I said, that thinking about my writing helps improve my mood.

Finally, my wife and I feel like our marriage has been tightened and strengthened over time, and it was already great to begin with. We can only thank the LORD for that.

That was kind of a big tangent. What else have we been up to? We visited some of the tour sites near the DMZ, which is the four kilometer-wide buffer zone that runs along the border between North Korea and South Korea. (A common misconception is that the DMZ is the border line, while it’s actually a zone that takes two kilometers from each country along the border line to make a buffer where no one can go.) One point along the tour was an observation building that was meters from the DMZ. So at that point, we were a little more than two kilometers away from North Korea. It was only too bad that the sky was hazy that day, so we couldn’t see very far into the country, even with the coin-operated binoculars. One of our friends managed to see a Korean farmer walking home, though!

Probably the coolest part of the tour was going into two of the four tunnels that were discovered a few decades ago. These tunnels were dug from North Korea into South Korea in an apparent attempt to plan an attack on Seoul that never happened. It was cool not only because it was neat to see these tunnels and learn about their importance in Korean history, but also because it was underground and therefore much cooler than the hot air there was outside.

We didn’t go to the most famous sites, such as Panmunjeom, which is probably the only place where you can be within meters from the border, where the guards stand watch from both sides all day, and where some people even cross, technically, onto North Korean property in the rarely-if-ever-used conference room set up along the border for meetings. That tour is more expensive and takes more time than the tour we went with, but that’s okay. It’s also much stricter (wear nicer clothing and no pointing, for example, or you might arouse the suspicions of a North Korean officer). We learned quite a bit about Korean history and the DMZ just from the smaller tour sites we visited, and I’m glad we went. Like I said, the only disappointment was the visibility that day. 

Also, we went to a science museum with our school a couple of weeks ago. This field trip was held at the end of May instead of in late April or early May because of the Sewol ferry sinking. Many people in Korea at that time called for an end of all school field trips forever, but thankfully it didn’t come to that. Most schools simply postponed their trips. We’ve also noticed an increase in safety awareness on field trips. Field trips in Korea are very carefree, but now there are more head counts, more buddy systems, and more double-checking. In addition to the field trip postponements, our school’s sports day competition was postponed. It’s usually on or around May 5 at our school, but now we’re having it in October. May 5 was considered too close to the national tragedy to be having fun and games. It was unfortunate and made a lot of people, students and teachers alike, upset, but it’s done now, so it is what it is, I guess.

And finally, one of the things that stressed us out about work was that, to deal with some of the government-mandated transitional curricula changes, our school had nine hours of English-language classes when it advertises ten in its English immersion program. It decided to fill that tenth hour with “musical class.” At first I thought it meant we were getting ready really early for the English Cantabile (an English program in winter that sort of misuses an Italian word as its title and which sometimes involves the students performing a musical). Then we thought it was just a class period of singing English songs with the students. Then, it turned out, “musical” class is “drama” class, so we all had to pick a short play and have our students practice it for an upcoming event on June 27, in which parents will be invited to watch the twelve performances (two for each of the six grades at our school, since grades are divided into high and low level). There were more changes to this class than I’ve mentioned here. The most recent one was actually a relief: parents will no longer be invited to the event, so Ashley and I, who have more musical classes than any other teacher, at three each (it’s just how the scheduling worked out, I guess), won’t have to look incompetent in front of our students’ parents when they see how poor the plays are. We only have this class one forty-minute class period per week, so there’s not much time to prepare, especially when some days are holidays or classes are canceled for other reasons. Also, directing a play in a language your students aren’t 100% comfortable in is not easy at all. So now only the rest of the students will see the plays and it won’t matter as much if the students didn’t memorize their lines or anything. Our head English teacher was rather upset about the news though. He put a lot of effort into his play and now the parents won’t be watching, so that’s a bit of a bummer.

Those are some of the notable things that have been going on in our lives lately. I’m sure there’s more but I can’t think about it right now. And I don’t want to make this rambling blog post any longer. So here’s the end:

The End

Today our school had its first* Drama Day. Now in the winter we always have what they call “Cantabile,” which is an Italian word that doesn’t really mean “Christmas English concert” or “winter English concert,” but that’s what it is for us. That is also a day with drama and/or music, but this Drama Day was something completely separate. It was actually for a class.

Owing to some rather complex circumstances in recent government legislation and our school’s curriculum, we found ourselves short one class hour of the ten hours of English immersion education our school advertises. Each student only had nine forty-minute class periods. Our school’s solution was to add “musical” class. So now the students have the standard English course (mandated by the government and using one of the same textbooks public schools in Korea use), language arts, conversation, and musical. After a few changes, this “musical” class turned out to be more of a “drama club” class. The school planned to have a day toward the end of the semester where parents could come and watch the students perform the plays. (First and second grade just sang songs, though.)

These classes were difficult to teach, and it was a nuisance for pretty much everyone involved. We all learned (and should have known) that directing children in a second language to perform a play in that second language as second-class teachers is a game played with a stacked deck, and we’re not the dealers. Remember, also, that this is the tenth class hour for the students, so we taught this class only once a week. If there was a holiday or a national test day, we went two weeks between classes. Finally, not all of our musical classes coincided with times when there wasn’t physical education classes going on. Some of us could use the gymnasium, and some of us could not. (And if we could, the students equate the gym with running around and having fun.)

Anyway, I don’t want to get too negative, so I’ll carry on. I just wanted to lightly mention some of the difficulties to explain some background.

So we all chose plays at the beginning of the semester and made copies of the scripts for our students to memorize. We spent the rest of the semester (well, until today) trying to get our students to memorize their lines, read the lines correctly, speak loudly, and perform the appropriate actions. Some of the students were excited about it, and some couldn’t care less. And it all culminated in today’s Drama Day.

The high level half of the fourth grade class was one of the classes excited about the program. Especially the girls. Last week a large group of them came to the English teachers’ office and asked me if they could wear 한복 (“hanbok,” or traditional Korean clothing). None of the classes had been given costumes or anything, so most of the plays were largely done with imagination. The play for my fourth grade class took place in an unspecified place in a pre-industrial time, so if all the students wore hanbok**, that would make sense. I asked them, “Does everyone have a hanbok?” They said yes. I thought about it, and I decided that even though I was hesitant, the students were really excited about it. So I agreed and said we’d talk more about it on Thursday, which is the day of the week we have our class on.

Thursday was yesterday. I went to class expecting to do one last run-through of the play and to clear up any last concerns. I found out that some of the students didn’t have any hanbok. Also, one student said, “Teacher, I bought hanbok yesterday.” (Now let me tell you something: These clothes are not like going and buying a T-shirt or even a pair of jeans. It’s possible, although barely, to spend around a hundred dollars for one, but it’s more likely to cost two, three, or even seven hundred dollars.)

One student said she wanted to make hanbok with her mom for the students who didn’t have one (out of paper or something, of course, but nonetheless, this girl is adorable and dedicated; she also took it upon herself to make some props for the play before I’d gotten around to the issue of props!).

Alright, this is where it gets really interesting. A few weeks ago, the school told us that Drama Day wouldn’t be an open-school event anymore, but that the students would just perform for the other grades and the school staff. So I told my students that in my drama classes. “Parents aren’t coming anymore. We’re just showing the play to the school.” We also thought that the Korean homeroom teachers had informed the students of the change. Finally, just a day or two before this, we learned that Drama Day wouldn’t even be for all the school. They wanted to minimize canceled classes, so they made a schedule that involved only parts of the school watching at any given time, so that some grades saw certain plays and other grades saw other plays.

So this is when I mentioned to the students the change. I asked them if they still wanted to go through so much knowing that they wouldn’t be performing for the whole school, but just part of it. In the process of explaining this, the issue of the parents not being invited anymore came up.

As it turns out, I either forgot to mention it to this particular class (I had three of these classes) or they weren’t listening when I told them. I really thought I had told them, though (and I felt less guilty when I learned that a few of the other English teachers hadn’t said anything, expecting the Korean homeroom teachers, who normally make such announcements, had covered that base).

Well, some of my students lost it. I had about five or six severely sorrowful students shedding tears left and right. Other students may not have been crying, and some seemed not to care much, but most were so sad. One girl in particular was so upset she could barely express herself in English, but kept switching to Korean (and her English is pretty darn good). She had stayed up late to make sure she had all her lines perfectly memorized. She was excited for her mom to come and watch her because it was the first time that she had a normal class that put on a performance and not just a competition or school-wide concert. And her mom was excited about it. She (the student) went to a city nearly two hours away on the weekend to borrow a hanbok from her cousin. The other girl bought a hanbok. And the girl who had worked so hard by her own meritable initiative, well, she worked so hard. And of course, there were other students who were so upset because they had expected their parents to attend and now they would have to go home and tell their mom and dad not to go to the school.

It was one of the worst moments I’ve faced in the front of the classroom. The students were so distraught that we didn’t get anything accomplished, and I went to get Teacher Heather so they could have a Korean to talk to in their native language. I felt terrible. I apologized to them in case I really had forgotten to tell them, but they said it wasn’t my fault, as they cried their way out the classroom. I didn’t feel any better.

But when I saw them in the hallway later that day, one of the girls said her teacher was planning to film the plays and post them online for the parents to see, so now everyone was happy again. (Praise the LORD that most children know how to bounce back from disappointment!) Then the students made me a little bit upset by apologizing to me. “What for?” I asked them. “For crying in your class.” Sigh.

So today we had the performances. My low level first grade class sang “Peace Like a River“(not the same version my students sang because I can’t find that one) and “Bingo” (yes that version) very cutely. My high level third grade class performed “Little Half Chicken” pretty well. My high level fourth grade wore their hanbok, had lots of props they made themselves (I’m not really that great of a director), and they did an excellent job performing “Mount Semsi.” I was proud of them and still am.

Some other classes did well, too, and some read their lines straight from their scripts. That included a majority of the sixth grade students. When the sixth grade finished, our principal went to the stage and told them that they didn’t take this day seriously. Some of the third, fourth, and fifth grade classes had memorized all their parts, but most of the sixth grade students hadn’t. So she couldn’t praise them for a job well done, she said. And I was really glad she said that. Not because I want the children to feel bad, but it was good for her to be honest with them so that they will know in the future what’s expected of them, and they’ll know that the principal’s praises are always genuine.

Anyway, we’re all glad that Drama Day is over. It was pretty stressful. I can’t even imagine how the kids felt yesterday.

One more thing. The following is a complete change in topic. It could go in another post but then it’d probably never show up. Yesterday I went to a blueberry field and picked a bunch of blueberries. It was a ton of fun. By the end of it, the stress from the terrible time teaching was gone.

Picking blueberries. Photo by Teacher Heather.

Beautiful blueberries. Also by Teacher Heather.

I went with our vice-principal, Teacher Heather, and a couple of other people I didn’t know. Ashley didn’t want to go. Mr. Mun (pronounced “Moon”; the vice-principal) decided to speak Korean with me instead of English, so it was a little difficult, but I was surprised by how much I could understand him. Usually when he switches to Korean to make us practice, it’s too difficult. He said I learn Korean well because of my beard. He said in the Bible, Samson had long hair and a long beard, and God made him strong. I was glad he said that because I’ve been letting my beard grow (I bet you wouldn’t find such a thing in an American elementary school) and I’ve wondered what the school administrators think of it. Aside from the occasional student who isn’t used to seeing facial hair on men, no one has asked for me to shave or trim it, though (and I keep it clean and tidy), so I didn’t worry that much. But now I have a sort of indirect approval!

In the car before we went to the field, the vice-principal gave me a piece of 떡 (“ddeok”; Korean rice cake). But then he said, “But don’t eat it now. Don’t be a fool like me, who ate a piece. You have to have room for the blueberries.” When we got to the blueberry farm, Mr. Mun told me that for every ten blueberries I pick (to put in the basket for purchase) I should eat one. Then he said, “But I’m going to eat ten blueberries for every one that I pick.” I felt really good because I understand all of that in Korean (not every word, but I was confident of the content).

I don’t really know how many blueberries I picked or ate, but both were “a lot.” I planned to buy one kilogram of blueberries, but I don’t really have good skills at estimating how much things weight. And it was too much fun. I ended up having two and a half kilograms in my basket. Oh well. Now we have a lot of blueberries in our freezer for our smoothies!

Oh, boy, did we have an exciting summer vacation. We had so greatly looked forward to it in the hectic and stressful weeks that led up to the end of the semester, and we were not disappointed. We spent some time in Michigan with my family and making the rounds to see various people.

But before that, we had to get into the country. That was an interesting set of minor scenarios. The visas in our passports are expired (being for just the first year of our stay in the country), so every time we travel to or out of Korea on round-trip tickets, we also show our Alien Registration Cards to the attendants so they know that we are indeed qualified to re-enter the country. The ARCs have the updated dates of our permitted stay written in with permanent marker and taped over to prevent smearing. The attendant who checked us into our flight out of Korea saw Ashley’s card and exit date, which checked out. Then she looked at mine.

Uh-oh. The most recent date on mine was not April of next year, but April of this year. Yes, as in three months before the events of this story. But after five or six seconds of panic, I looked and saw that it was clearly a clerical error, as the previous date box also listed an exit date in April 2014. So the attendant called immigration and confirmed that my card should have read 2015. Phew.

Fast forward to going through customs and immigration on the American side of things. Remember how I picked blueberries about a month before the start of my vacation? On my immigration card, I checked that I had visited a farm. Well, hey, it was a blueberry farm. In context, the question seems to be worried about livestock and whatnot, but it asked if I visited a farm and I did. So I checked Yes. Well, that made the immigration officers ask me a few extra questions. I explained what kind of farm I visited and how long ago. Since you only need one card per family, Ashley was also interrogated. She just pointed to me and said, “He went to the blueberry farm. I didn’t.” But then we had one more step, and another man, at the very end of the customs process, asked me if I had brought soil back with me from the farm. I told him no, that in fact it had rained so hard a few days ago my shoes were soaked through and I’d washed them.

So that was the hardest it’s been for me to return to my country, but it still wasn’t that bad. Actually, that was the quickest we’ve ever been through the customs and immigration process. I think they’ve streamlined it. Also, there are more self-process kiosks to speed up all of the preliminary procedures.

Well, anyway, we got out of the airport, where my parents were just in time to pick us up and take us home. The rest of the week was great. First we went to the DMV to get Ashley a Michigan drivers’ license and to renew mine, but after that, it was no work and all play. We went with our nieces to Michigan’s Adventure, an amusement and water park. We also went last year, I may have mentioned, but this year we stayed with our nieces for most of the time. They’re tall enough to go on quite a few rides, so we went on several rides with them. The lines were great, too, so that sometimes, our eldest niece told the ride operator, “We’re going to stay on and go again.” And because there was no one waiting, that was okay! Our nieces had a great time and, so did we.

We also went camping. Not in-tents camping, but we went–Mom, Dad, our nieces, Ashley, and I–to a state park campground just beyond the border in Indiana in my parents’ camping trailer. So what if we weren’t “roughin’ it”? We spent some quality time outdoors, eating fire-cooked food, riding bikes, going on paddle boat rides, and enjoying the outdoors with family. That was probably the most relaxing part of my vacation.

We saw lots of my extended families as well. My aunt and uncle in Texas timed their visit well, so we got to see them for a few days before we carried on over to California. We had a few family gatherings here and there. In one of them, I played tag with all the children, including some of the children of my cousins, whom I barely knew before, so that was good.

Who else did we see? We saw our friend Serenity, and that was lucky. We sent out a message to our friends in town and she replied immediately, saying she was about to leave to go to the airport to visit her father for a week, coming back the night before we would be leaving. We had about an hour to visit her, so we quickly did. A couple of our other friends had a baby while we were gone, so we got to meet her for the first time. Also, Justin makes some pretty darn good kimchi, I’d say!

Our friend Tony wanted to see us, so we went to a Japanese restaurant with him with his girlfriend and had a good time. One the way back into town, he mentioned in passing that a particular apartment complex, which we were passing, was where his brother lived. His brother, André, is another good friend of ours, and one we hadn’t had the chance to see in a few years. So we called him and arranged to see him before we left. That was fortunate. I think it may have been the first time we’ve seen him since we moved to Korea. He was the same hilarious, friendly, autumn-loving André we know and love.

We visited the English Department at the university we attended together to say hello to some of our beloved professors. We actually had to make two trips there because our timing wasn’t so great the first time around. We talked to one professor and then no one else was around. So we returned the following day and spoke with a few more. It was great to see them all and hear their encouragement for us. I really appreciated learning from them, and I continue to appreciate them because they really care about their students, past, present, and future. We haven’t attended their classes in over four years, and I imagine I could add another four or more years onto that and still they would know us just as well as the students who visit them three times a week for classes. I guess that’s one of the perks of attending a smallish school.

Oh, and I nearly forgot. My high school’s ten-year reunion happened to take place while we were in town, so we went to that. Not a lot of people showed up, but it wasn’t bad. I was actually worried I’d forget a lot of my classmates’ names, but it didn’t turn out to be a big problem. One guy was talking to us and I couldn’t remember who he was until someone else came up to him and greeted him by name. “Oh yeah!” I thought. I didn’t feel too bad, though, because we’d actually been having a pretty genuine conversation (I was surprised by my social skills in that instant), and I didn’t know him all that well back then. But I got to catch up with a few friends whose names I did remember, so that was awesome, too.

Anyway, eventually, we had to leave. I felt bad. The night before we left, our nieces said goodbye to us and gave us hugs. Hayden, the middle one, said, “I don’t want you to leave!” over and over again, but she wasn’t too shook up about it. The youngest one, Abby, just said goodnight to us and gave us a hug. She was just a baby when we moved away, so this year was probably the first year she’s really known and liked us. Our eldest niece, however, was several years old when we left, and she understands more of what’s going on. She broke down in tears while she hugged me, and didn’t let me go for probably a good eight to ten minutes. I felt bad.

And then we got to visit Ashley’s family in California for a week. That was great, although it was not at all what we expected. We expected to go to her grandparents, where her aunt, uncle, and two youngest cousins live, and also visit her sister and best friend, doing low-key things. Well, the day before we flew to California, Ashley’s aunt informed her that we’d better keep our schedule clear for the day after our arrival. Ashley’s grandparents, aunt, and uncle bought us park hopper passes for Disneyland and California Adventure (so we could visit both theme parks), and they reserved us a room at the Disneyland Hotel (so we could enjoy Disneyland until it closed at midnight and get some rest afterward)! It was such a delightful gift. Unfortunately, we only saw Ashley’s aunt, uncle, and one of the two cousins for a few hours (they left the next day on their own trip, which was already planned before we announced our upcoming visit). Then it was time to sleep so we could wake up and get an early start for the fun-filled day awaiting us. Ashley’s aunt and cousin enthusiastically drew up a plan for us so we could efficiently enjoy the best parts of the parks, and it really did help. We went on thirteen rides (four within the first hour and a half), saw three and a half shows (we went to the wrong one and walked out before it was over; it was for little children), and enjoyed a few other attractions as well (such as the Innoventions building, which featured all kinds of cool, futuristic stuff, and also had on display some of the suits from the Iron Man movies).

It was great to see Ashley’s family. It had been two years, I believe, since we’d last seen her maternal grandparents. They don’t go out much these daysbut we all went out together one day for a drive to see various places in the area. It was Monday, so a lot of stuff we closed (apparently), but it was nice to drive around and hear their stories about these places. If they weren’t going out with us, they were sending us out. Especially Ashley’s grandfather, who knows his stuff when it comes to good food. His active involvement in the restaurant business gave him great insights in where to suggest we eat. I’ll tell you what: I’ve never had soup as good as that of a place, located just a hop away (not even a skip) from Ashley’s grandparents’ house, called Little Flower Candy Company. We ordered extra food to take home, and we went a second time before we left. If you’re ever in Pasadena, I strongly recommend you try Little Flower if you’re in the mood for soup. Their salads and sandwiches are good, too, but their soup will soothe the broken heart of a stomach that didn’t know why it was broken. (The answer, of course, is that it had never enjoyed Little Flower’s soup.)

Anyway, I’m trying to be brief. I’ve gone on for nearly 1900 words and I’ve yet a few more. We saw Ashley’s younger sister, too, when we went to her local church. We also caught up with the pastor who officiated at our wedding. That evening, we went to an expensive movie theater (I think all movie theaters are expensive, as I grew up near a theater where the most expensive tickets cost $5, and I normally pay $8 or $9 in Korea) to see Guardians of the Galaxy. I’ll tell you something else: That’s my favorite Marvel movie. I don’t care how much action The Avengers has. Guardians of the Galaxy has some of the best film characterization of super heroes I’ve seen (although I can’t discredit the other movies on this; it’s just that I especially loved the characters in Guardians of the Galaxy).

I digress again. The next day, we went with Ashley’s sister to see Ashley’s friend Janelle at Manhattan Beach. Ashley’s godson (Janelle’s son) was there, too. Parking at Manhattan Beach is no joke. I wish it were, but it wasn’t. We spent a great number of minutes searching for a lot with a space, but when we finally found one, a hidden little strip of cars about half a mile from the beach, there were no meters! The sign said FREE ALL DAY PUBLIC PARKING. I entered that one-line parking lot hopeful but without true expectation, and after passing a couple dozen vehicles, there it was: a parking spot with my rental car’s name on it. (Here’s an interesting story. Later, when Janelle had to move her car from the two-hour spot she’d found, we tried to see if there would be something in the free lot where we’d parked. While everyone doubted a space would be available, I confidently said, “There’s one spot open, and it’s the spot three spots to the right of where I parked!” We got into Janelle’s car and drove to that lot. We passed the rental car. I counted one. I counted two. And did I count three? No, because that spot was empty! Okay, maybe I wasn’t so confident in my prediction, but it was still fun to pretend that I’d foreseen it.)

Well, anyway, our vacation came to a close. We got on a plane in Los Angeles, had a layover in Tokyo, had more layover in Tokyo as our plane was delayed in order to remove the luggage of no-show passengers and then to reclaim a spot in the takeoff line, and finally arrived at Incheon International Airport.

At the mall with my family on our last day in Michigan.

Ashley poses with some of the Iron Man suits. (Not the actual suits, I think.)

We’re not good at selfies.

We really enjoyed going on kiddie rides with our nieces.

In this one, you can see the castle, too.

Good times with Ashley’s best friend and godson.

So we came back to Korea on the 7th of August (a Thursday), rested for the weekend, and went back to work on the 11th (a Monday). Actually, I didn’t have any jet leg. It was amazing. Because of the delay for the final leg of our flight back to Korea, I felt good and tired when we arrived at the airport hotel around eleven Thursday night. I went to sleep and woke up around seven or eight in the morning, so I was set.

We worked that week of the 11th, but only for four days. We had what is known in Korea as “summer camp.” For us, it means teaching a handful of students for four hours and then going home after lunch. August 15 is a national holiday, which means that for most years we only teach four days of this week. This year, August 15 was Friday. When we finished work on Thursday, we boarded the Saemaul train to Cheonan and then the ITX-Saemaul train to Busan.

We’d made plans to meet some of our friends we’d met when we lived there in 2011/early 2012, and the time and cost of going to Busan compared to other cities in Korea means we prefer to go when we have 3- or 4-day weekends.

Well, we went, and I think we had a pretty good time. I was a bit late in purchasing tickets, however, so the KTX tickets were sold out for the time we wanted. I had to book the slower ITX-Saemaul train instead. We also had to leave at 10 in the morning on Sunday. It was alright, though. Getting back in the early afternoon meant we had several hours to rest and relax before starting the second semester of the school year on Monday.

For a while, we just enjoyed our time away from our place in Korea. Sound strange after only being back in the country for a week? Maybe, but it doesn’t change that we spend nearly every day while in Korea in small-town Gwangcheon. Also, it had been a long time since we’d been in Busan. We enjoyed a nice Korean BBQ meal Thursday night and went to a buffet for lunch on Friday. The name of that buffet is Ashley. We also decided to catch a movie, one we’d never even heard of: Begin Again. We really liked it. The movie was character-driven and basically a feel-good flick about musicians.

On Saturday we met our friends, Brian and Kathleen, at Songdo Beach. Although we lived in Busan for a year, we didn’t visit all the beaches. Songdo is closer to where Brian and Kathleen live, while we usually went to Gwangalli Beach. Actually, Songdo Beach is nice. But the greatest part was seeing our friends. We all brought various things to eat and we had a picnic on the beach until we were sun-tired and ready for supper. We went to an American-style diner and the food was pretty good, although Brian and I both were disappointed by the size of the burger patties (if the bun had been the same size instead of twice the diameter, maybe it wouldn’t have been a big deal).

So it wasn’t much. We just had a picnic and dinner with our friends, but it was great to be on this mini-vacation. I don’t remember the last time we saw Brian and Kathleen, but I think it was a year ago or even more. The problem is that going to Busan takes more time and money than going to Seoul or Cheonan. Going for just a day or two doesn’t usually feel worth the effort. But it’s nice to go there once in a while, and I’m glad we did.

(by Brian)

Will Smith goes to a Korean restaurant with some friends. He claims he wants kimchi. One friend asks, “Is that it? You’re only getting kimchi?” Will Smith responds, “Nah, I’m gettin’ jjigae with it.”

- joke of unknown origin

Kimchi (김치) is famous. It is without a doubt the most famous distinctly Korean food. And I think a close runner up would have to be kimchi jjigae (김치찌개). Kimchi jjigae is a type of stew that is very popular in Korea and one food that seems to be pretty inoffensive to foreigners. Although kimchi is sometimes sour and overpowering to people who have not tried it many times, kimchi jjigae has a completely different flavor. Whether it’s from the cooking process or if the other ingredients can take credit for the balancing act, I don’t know. All I know is that “김치찌개 맛있어요” (kimchi jjigae is delicious).

Yesterday, I decided to try to cook kimchi jjigae. People told me that it is one of the easiest Korean dishes to make. One Korean student in my composition class at Andrews University even wrote an essay about kimchi jjigae that included a recipe. I never tried that recipe, but now, after almost three months in Korea, I have made kimchi jjigae. Ever since we got the rice cooker, I have been buying ingredients to make Korean meals. Until then, we normally ate stir fry, ordered chicken, cooked some ramen (although now we call it ramyeon), or went to a restaurant. But now we not only have a rice cooker, but I have also learned some things about Korean food and Korean ingredients that I didn’t know before.

So over the weekend I tried to make a few simple things. I made a simple seaweed soup a couple of times, and I also made a variation of kimchi fried rice. It’s great that there are so many ways to make some of these dishes, because it helped me to relax while making the kimchi jjigae. Some people use onions? Some add fish paste? You can put mushrooms in it? I saw lots of different recipes, so when I decided to make it myself, I knew that I could do pretty much whatever I wanted as long as the key ingredients were there and as long as I made them into a stew.

And as long as certain ingredients were left out.

And here is how I chose to make it. First, I cup up some vegetables to put in all at once at a certain point (there’s limited space in the kitchen, so I have to give a bit more concentration toward ingredient preparation).

Bowl contents: a few cloves of fresh minced garlic, a small bit of freshly shaved ginger, some green onions, a bit of mushrooms, gochujang (pepper paste), gochugaru (pepper powder), sliced gochu (hot pepper).

I also prepared the kimchi. On the right is kimchi, and on the left is a small bowl of some of the juice from the bag of kimchi.

Next time, I think I will take more juice. I was worried that I would take all of it and leave none for the leftover kimchi, but Wednesday's jjigae could have used some more of it, I think. And there was plenty remaining.

I had a thick coating of sesame oil on the bottom of the pan warmed up before I added a drained can of tuna and the kimchi. Sometimes, kimchi jjigae is made with pork. It can also be made with tuna, and then it’s called 참치김치찌개 (with the added chamchi, or “tuna,” at the beginning, as it appears at the top of this post). Of course, it’s possible to make it without meat at all if you wish. Or, if you don’t like tuna and have objections to swine flesh, I don’t see any reason against substituting with beef. It should match the stew quite well, actually.

A bit later, of course, I added the bowl of additional ingredients.

Is anyone else starting to feel a bit hungry?

Then I filled the pot with just enough water to cover the food, added some tofu cubes, and let the stew simmer for a good 30 minutes. If you don’t like tofu, you can leave it out. Or if you want a vegetarian meal, you can add more tofu to replace the meat (although why you would want to do anything like that is beyond me).

Alright, now I'm starting to regret not writing this post while I still had some jjigae leftover.

It's quite tasty to dip a spoonful of rice into the stew before eating it. Actually, at restaurants in Korea, they prepare this dish in stone bowls that keep the soup sizzling hot for a long time. I kind of HAVE to use rice to cool it down!

A really good kimchi jjigae is spicy, of course, with all of the pepper-based ingredients that go into it (although some people only use one or two, depending on the desired consistency of the broth and whatnot). It’s also savory and soul-warming. I can’t really describe it very well, because I need to work on expanding my taste-description skills. This kimchi jjigae that I made sure was spicy, and it was savory, but it was missing something in the soul-satisfying department. It was delicious, and Ashley loved it, but I think I made it too thin. (I later read that gochujang, the paste, thickens it, while gochugaru, the powder, thins it. I did kind of add a lot of the gochugaru.)

But I’ve at least nine more months in this country. I will figure it out.

My time in Korea has its ups and downs. Some of these ups and downs are emotional, most, however, are products of me trying to get from point A to point B. I’m literally going up and down hills every day, on foot and while riding public transportation.

But whether we are going uphill or downhill, here in Busan, the public transportation system makes me smile. It’s not just the availability of transport itself, but the personalities of the bus passengers, and the personalities of the bus and taxi drivers that improve the day. Last week, I was touched when an elderly woman who was getting off the bus told me to take her seat (in Korean that I didn’t understand and gestures that I did understand). Another ajumma helped me extricate my sweater from the chair handle, so that I could get off the bus safely rather than rip my sweater. (God bless those kind women).

Brian and I take the "ship-chil" bus to get home. Although we could take the "pal ship pal" if we wanted.

If you want to catch the bus, go to the bus stop and wait. At the bus stop there is a sign with a list of the busses that stop there, and a list of locations that they have stopped,  and where they will stop (the previous locations are greyed out). Then you wait for the bus with the appropriate bus number. When you see the bus on its way, step into the street to let the driver know that you are indeed wanting to get on that particular bus.

Oh, look it's the "chil-ship" bus.

Bus drivers in Busan are cool. They wear special gloves and sometimes greet you when you get on the bus. They are always honking at cars and other buses,  and they all seem to enjoy listening to the radio.  A lot of the bus drivers like to listen to Korean oldies that have a very distinct sound. In fact, I would say that bus drivers listening to that kind of music is a Korean stereotype. When one of my co-teachers asked if I’d heard the type of music that was playing on the speakers at the park, I said “Yes, on the bus.” And she laughed and nodded her head as if I had made a joke. Some bus drivers break the mold, however, by listening to American music. I once heard country music while riding the bus here in Busan. Another time, a young bus driver in dark sunglasses bobbed his head to some American hip hop.

Apart from the music, the bus ride is like a rollercoaster. If you don’t have a seat, hold on for your life! The steep slopes and sharp turns are jolting. I’m often worried when I see Brian wobbling as if he’s about to topple over. But, as one fellow EPIKer put it, “It’s great for your arms.” And your whole body too, I should think.

Watch me ride this bus.

If you want to catch a cab. Just stand near a corner or bus stop and make the Korean “come here” signal. It’s the same as the western one, except palm down. Sometimes westerners mistake this signal for being shooed away. Luckily this gesture was something I researched on Youtube before I coming to Korea, so I haven’t had the embarrassment of that. Although Brian and I have had the experience of waving down cab after cab, only to watch them pass, until finally a kind Korean man waves a cab down and points it in our direction. (God bless that anonymous stranger).   It’s usually much easier to get a cab since they are usually waiting at every bus stop.

All cab drivers have GPS systems hooked up in their cars and some even have TVs. It’s a little disconcerting to watch your cab driver multitask. Some of them greet us warmly when we enter the cab, one driver shook our hands. One of them joined in the conversation and then commented to Brian: “Your mustache looks good on you…like Osama bin Laden.” That really came out of nowhere.

I was laughing about it for the rest of the day.

(by Brian)

오늘 우리의 결혼 기념일입니다 (oneul urie gyeolhon ginyeomirimnida). It means “Today is our wedding anniversary.” One year ago today, Ashley and I made our commitment to each other legal by the power vested in a court magistrate by the State of Michigan. And today we decided to celebrate in a very proper way, I think.

The way our engagement started, which seems now so long ago, was Ashley and I went with our school to see a Shakespeare play. It was the bloody tragedy Macbeth, and before it was showtime, I asked Ashley to marry me. We sat through the play and on the bus ride home without revealing to anyone what we had just done. It was, for the night, our secret.

Today, to celebrate our anniversary, we saw another Shakespeare play. Yes, there is a production of Shakespeare going on in Busan, South Korea. But of course this was not the first thing we did today. No, earlier today was Sabbath. Ashley and I got our rest. We ate some cold noodles (비빔냉면, or bibim naengmyeon, which are pretty good), sat around in our apartment, and read stuff on the Internet and in our Bibles about the end of the world and Bible prophecy. It’s a very daunting task, and I don’t imagine I’ll ever be done. Until I’m dead. But that’s not the point.

The point is that later in the afternoon, Ashley and I got dressed and ready and we went to the other side of the city, to Haeundae Beach. We left early to get good seats for this evening event. From the beach we walked, according to some directions on the Facebook page that invited us to see the production, for probably 30 minutes or more. But the view was incredible. We walked along a tree-lined sidewalk and eventually came to a clearing where we could see the beach and the city in the same view, because we were beyond the beach, toward the end of the bay. But I couldn’t get a good picture with my camera. Sorry. Maybe we’ll go another time, at a different time of day or with different weather.

Eventually we arrived at the Dalmaji Amphitheater, which looks like this:

As you can see, we didn't need to be worried about seats.

It's a very beautiful place.

Ashley thought the place was pretty, too.

So...they make a good match.

Later the play started. It seemed that several English teachers, like ourselves, formed an amateur acting club of sorts. I think there were also non-teachers in the group, because a few of the actors seemed older than the preferred age range for Guest English Teachers. And I also don’t want to assume that every young foreigner in Korea is a teacher. The director of the play, who also appeared as a couple of minor characters, told us that this was the second production so far and that they hoped for two more this year. And we hope, of course, to go.

The play that the club performed was the comedy As You Like It, and we enjoyed it. Some of the actors were pretty good. Some of them, however ([cough] the director [cough]), had troubles projecting their voices. We missed a few words here and there, but everyone with a major role had few volume errors. I kept wondering, sometimes, if the people toward the back could hear. We sat near the front.

I think the volume of some actors was the only detriment to the play. I genuinely enjoyed watching the performance, and the only reason I wanted it to end was because the weather turned cool and windy. The production was even customized to fit the audience, which was mostly expats but also, surprisingly, included some Koreans. I think learning today’s English is hard enough for Koreans, but to follow the fast-paced, pun-filled speech of Shakespeare characters, or even to try, is impressive.

One character in the play, a wrestler named Charles, arrived on stage followed by fans who cheered him on by saying, “Charles-eu! Charles-eu!” Many Korean words end in a sound that is similar to uh, except more forward in the mouth. Especially words that are borrowed from English. So everyone got a good laugh out of this adaptation of speech. During a fight between Charles and the main character of the story, some other characters yelled, “Fighting!” which is, in Korea, similar to saying, “Good luck,” or “I’m rooting for you!” or “Go Bears!” It’s a cheer. Another good laugh. And finally, later in the play a character said that something was “so-so,” and the actors emphasized their reaction to this word. It was funny because many Korean students say “so-so,” and some English teachers try to get them to say words that are more common, like “Okay.”

After the play was over, Ashley and I looked for a place to eat. We almost went into a Vietnamese restaurant near the amphitheater, but we quickly discovered it was a reservations-only place. So it’s probably a good thing that we didn’t go there. We walked back toward the city and found an Italian bistro called Il Massimo, “Since 2011.” The food was very good, if not a bit pricey, since Italian pasta isn’t as cheap in Korea as it is in the United States. But I was very impressed.

Finally, we went back home. Our stop on the 17 bus is up the hill from our apartment on the opposite side of the group of apartments, about three or four minutes from our apartment by foot. Right at the stop is a small collection of shops. One of them is a Tous Les Jours, which is a popular bakery chain (Paris Baguette is the other one, and both chains are seriously everywhere in Korea, although there are also a few smaller chains or one-ofs). They sell all kinds of wonderful baked treats, including small, beautiful cakes.

Ashley and I decided a while ago that we would not be able to eat our wedding cake’s top layer on our anniversary. And that’s okay. It’s a tradition we can live without. The cost of having Ashley’s mom send us the cake, doubled with the uncertainty of its safe, customs-processed arrival, influenced us to simply let Ashley’s mom and siblings enjoy the cake. On our anniversary, of course. So we decided that for our anniversary we would buy one of the cakes that we often see in Korea, which look so nice everywhere we go. Here is our cake:

Yes. Yes, that is a bear. Despite the beauty of the competing cakes, there was no other choice.

Did it taste as good as it was cute? Yes.

(by Brian)

Our second trip to Seoul (서울) was just as eventful as the first, but without all the wandering around, helplessly lost bits.

There were only some of the helplessly lost bits.

Ashley and I took advantage of the Korean holiday on Monday (Korean Memorial Day) and spent three days and two nights in Seoul this time, a full day longer than our last trip, when we met Kristina in Seoul to see Cirque du Soleil. This time there was no Kristina to meet. She has been on the North American continent for more than a month by now. No, we didn’t see Kristina or any other college-days peers.

We saw our professors. Specifically, we met Dr. Closser and Dr. Greig, who are currently in Seoul to teach a couple of short English courses. We had talked often of visiting whenever they came to this side of the world, and the three-day weekend presented us with a great excuse to fulfill those intentions. And our professors graciously offered to let us use one of the spare rooms in their campus apartment, which meant that there would be no monetary guilt in staying the extra day.

On Saturday morning, we left our apartment. We packed our bags, turned off the heat (which was already on its lowest setting ever since winter ended), and caught the bus to Busan Station. We took the Mugunghwa (무궁화) train to Seoul this time. Last time, we took the KTX both ways because we took two trips in two days. A special foreigners’ rail pass allowed us a discount, but it’s based on time. A three-day pass with two train trips would be a waste of money. So we decided to take a leisurely ride to Seoul on the slowest train and, after a weekend of who knows what (we really didn’t know what), to take the fast train back home. After all, we would have to teach the following day.

And we sure were glad we took the slow train on the way to the country’s capital. Yes, it took nearly three hours longer (more than five hours), but the scenery was wonderful. The scenery on the KTX isn’t bad, but that train travels through tunnels as often as it shows its passengers the Korean countryside. The Mugunghwa brought us between forest-covered mountains and shimmering rice fields that I would love to visit someday on foot. Ashley remarked to Dr. Closser and Dr. Greig that whenever she would awake from a doze, she would see lovely sights from her window.

Sorry. I didn’t take pictures. They wouldn’t have turned out anyway.

Finally, we arrived at Seoul Station, about 10 or 15 minutes later than our tickets had promised. We took a rest at the station for a bit and then picked up our return ticket. I had it reserved already, but I didn’t know what Monday would bring. I would hate to get to the station with 10 or 15 minutes until departure and have just as long a line to get my ticket.

With our tickets retrieved, we followed Dr. Closser’s instructions for finding the apartment. Ten stops on the Seoul metro and a few city blocks later, we found the place. Okay. There was some confusion involved, but only on my part, I admit. Ashley wasn’t too engrossed in the words of Dr. Closser’s directions to forget to apply them to the real world.

We rang the doorbell. Dr. Closser’s directions said we could stay at the apartment if we recognized the tune. I was afraid of this moment. There are many tunes I cannot name. I relied on Ashley’s musical family background to save us. She guessed, “Beautiful Dreamer?” She wasn’t sure if it was the name or just a part of the lyrics. Fortunately, it was the title, and our former professors allowed us into their month-long home.

Okay, they opened the door before our answer, but I had to make it dramatic.

I have to say that I was very impressed by the apartment. Most apartments are kind of small. I think the single apartment alone could be classified as a house. There was a spacious kitchen, dining area, living room, and four bedrooms upstairs. There were also, of course, more beds downstairs, because at times the place fills up completely, when there are teachers/missionaries being trained and whatnot.

But this weekend, we had the place to ourselves. And it was nice. I had wondered how it would feel to see our professors after more than three months of being on the other side of the globe, and to see them on that other side, no less. I think it actually made us a bit nostalgic. Ashley remarked after we returned that she had forgotten how much she enjoyed listening to Dr. Greig discuss language theories. I didn’t say anything, but I agreed and had had similar thoughts.

Oh. And yes, there was some brief and leisurely academic discussion going on. I guess it’s not really that hard to readjust to such roles in the right environment. Here is a thought I did have while we were still in Seoul: “Ah, the joys of free education.” I really appreciated the discussions that Dr. Greig, Dr. Closser, Ashley, and I shared this last weekend. Paid courses were wonderful. You probably know of my excitement for a few of them, and if I didn’t tell you directly, you probably figured it out when you heard me list my courses each semester. But there was something about talking about (or, rather, listening to) these subjects we had recently paid for and stressed over, now in a relaxed and free environment.

And the environment was not only relaxed in that we weren’t expected to write anything or show up to class on time, but it was also relaxed in, um, well, I kind of mentioned it already. We weren’t expected to show up to class on time. Even on the weekends, I dislike waking up too late. I worried especially of losing time to see the city with our hosts, but I was mistaken. They took advantage of the weekend almost as much as we did.

Anyway, I’m guessing that you want to see pictures by now. Okay. Here we go.

This is outside the Seoul Tower.

This is also outside the Seoul Tower. Ashley poses in front of a Teddy Bear Museum sculpture and I take an ill-timed photo.

And here, my friends, is the Seoul Tower.

However, we did not go into the tower. By the time we got to the ticket line (around 9:00), a kind Korean woman told us and the nearby customers that there would be a two-hour wait. That meant getting into the tower around eleven. That meant probably leaving the tower after the buses and subway trains stopped running. Although taxis are pretty cheap in Korea, we didn’t know how far away from the apartment we were. It was probably for the better anyway. The night got hazier and hazier. We wouldn’t have seen much.

There are places like this around the world, where couples purchase two locks and lock them together on a bridge or railing.

The locks were probably 6 to 8 inches deep in some spots, not fastened to each other and the railing any longer, but to each other and...another lock. The locks are supposed to symbolize remaining together forever (the keys are thrown into a bin you can't collect them from). I wonder what it means, then, that the locks are locked to so many other locks.

A photographic experiment with a 2.5-second shutter.

I tried this shot lots of times (and it's still not perfect), until Ashley couldn't stand it anymore. It was quite difficult. Ashley had to stay still long enough for the camera to pick up the people behind her (otherwise the background was black). If I used flash and color, the background color was funky, and not in a way I wanted. So I had to accept a B&W image.

Dr. Closser and Ashley. Black background this time. Where are they? In the void, for all I remember.

I know it's not a professional quality photo, but I still kind of like it. At least the light.

Dr. Closser and I spent a lot of time this weekend taking pictures. I'm jealous of his camera. (Christmas hint, Christmas hint...haha, just kidding.)

All of that took place on Saturday night. Dr. Greig was very busy this weekend, so she did not go with us. Maybe that was a good thing, because remember how I said we did get just a little bit lost? Well, this was that time. And I’m sure all the wandering around we did would not have been well for her knee.

We took the metro and a bus to get here. The bus took us to the top of the hill, but we couldn’t figure out how to get on buses that went back down the hill. It was a one-way road. We had seen lots of people walking down the hill while on the bus, so we finally decided to follow suit. It was quite a long walk, but easy. At the bottom of the hill, we found out that our bus, number 2, did not have a stop nearby. The bus stop had bus 420 and another stop, and after a very nice young Korean man helped us out, we determined that bus 420 would take us to the subway station we wanted. We got on the 420 bus and examined the route line and determined further that there was another subway station, closer to our final destination, that we could go to at a certain stop.

Well, you probably guessed that it wasn’t there. It was, but not right there in the way we expected from the location label having 역 in the name (역/yeok can mean “station” when it’s at the end of a place name). But finally, maybe 15 minutes later, we found a station. It didn’t matter which station by then. Any station could eventually lead to any other station.

The next day, we went to a temple:

At Changgyeonggung (창경궁), a temple near Insadong (인사동) in Seoul.

Ashley. 'Nuff said.

You can see Dr. Closser taking lots of pictures while Ashley has a more passive way of admiring the location.

Break time. It was very hot and sunny.

Perspective.

Heading toward the shaded area among those trees.

Apparently the objects here had been somewhere else, but they got moved during a specific and bitter time in Korean history (i.e., the Japanese occupation).

We're near the end of our temple visit. Now Dr. Closser and Ashley are admiring a pond with an island in the middle.

I imagine someone takes this boat to that island on occasion.

A bunch of lanterns hanging from a tree outside another temple near Insadong. This temple was actually right next to the main Insadong street.

You can see the lanterns more closely here.

Ashley poses with the robot. Do you see the phrase "S-line" on it? It's Korean for "the sexy shape of a woman's profile." Yep, that robot is some sort of plastic surgery or exercise program advertisement.

Then we met up with Dr. Greig and went to supper together. She took us to a place called Everest, an Indian restaurant that was owned by what appeared to be an Indian family. Sometimes you can get curry in Korea, but it’s often bland and not very spicy. But this curry was some of the best I’ve eaten ever. Meet me in Seoul and I’ll take you there.

I don’t have any pictures from the restaurant. Dr. Closser had a member of the staff take a picture of the four of us, and maybe I’ll get the picture from him once his computer is working again. I should also say, don’t expect to see Dr. Greig in this blog. Because she could not join us very often, the only picture of her is that same one on Dr. Closser’s camera.

The next day, we visited a free museum. Most museums were closed for the holiday, but the National Palace Museum of Korea’s operating hours actually indicated “weekends and national holidays.” So we went there.

An awesome old scroll. We were told not to take flash photography. One woman watched our cameras the first time we took a picture to make sure we followed that rule.

Lots of cool pots. Each pot on the far side has its own use.

They admire the car.

The awesome self-striking water clock. It's almost like a Rube Goldberg machine (I'm not sure if it qualifies with all six simple machines, but pretty close). The cycle of water makes the clock sound at certain times of the day. Sometimes there is a bell, sometimes a gong, and sometimes a drum. We got to hear the gong.

Guards near a massive gate outside the museum. Some of them had cosmetic beards and goatees.

It was almost time to leave Seoul. Dr. Closser treated us to a very nice Italian place for salad and pizza. It was very good pizza. Korean style pizza is good in its own ways, but having a traditional margherita pizza was just what we needed.

Goodbye!

(by Brian)

My official job title in South Korea is Guest English Teacher (GET) or Native English Teacher (NET), or something along those lines. My practical job title? Rock star.

Here is a typical day at the girls’ high school where I work:

I arrive somewhere between ten and thirty minutes before I need to, depending on what time I leave the house, what time the bus arrives, and what condition the traffic is in. I get off the bus and walk through the gate of the school, where three or four students and one teacher (a different batch each day) stand to greet everyone with a bow and an 안녕하세요 (hello). For me, though, they usually wave and say Hi.

I go to my office (which is now the English Café; I got moved from the main teachers’ office to my own in the same classroom where I teach the 1st graders – the 2nd grade classes are too big for the English Café though, so I teach them in their normal classrooms). I either work on finishing up a lesson plan if I need to or I relax to calm myself before starting the class.

Then it’s time to teach. Each class is different, and the students in the classes are different, too. I have a few favorite classes, actually, where the students overall tend to either behave well in class or participate in my lessons. Heck, I have some classes where the students don’t really behave or pay attention to my lesson but they speak more English than other classes. And that’s pretty much my purpose here, to get students to speak English and thus practice their speaking and listening skills. Their reading skills are pretty good.

In some of these classes, the students talk to me a lot. In nearly all of them, they are big fans, although I suspect some might hate me because their English skills are too poor to understand even my easiest of tasks (“Just read the blue words: ‘It cost five dollars'”). If I put a picture of myself on a PowerPoint presentation, they get excited. Especially if that picture looks different than how I look on a typical school day. In a lesson on English exaggeration phrases, for example, I included the following photo:

The students, of course, got a kick out of this photo. Some of them complimented me on my “Photoshop” skills (even though I didn’t use Photoshop because Photoshop is expensive. I used GIMP, which is free). But I don’t think any picture has received such a strong reaction as this one:

I put this picture as one of the icons for a bomb game. Here’s some background. When we play a bomb game in class, teams have to choose a picture from the question-selection screen, and that leads to their question. So teams might pick a picture of a school bus or a soccer ball or puppies or an umbrella. Anything. So this last week, I changed some of the pictures on the question-selection screen, and one of the pictures I added was this one. Many students were supremely shocked to see me with long hair and such a scruffy beard. Even my co-teachers were surprised, and one of them went closer to the TV screen to examine it to make sure.

The best reaction, though, was when one team chose their question: “Jesus!” Everyone closer to the front, who could see my familiar facial features, started laughing.

So sometimes the classes are fun and sometimes they are not. I guess that’s just how it goes. In the hallways, all of the students greet me. They kind of have to, as it is a sort of custom for students to bow to teachers in the hallway, but only some students bow to me. The others say “Hi, teacher!” or “Hi, Brian!” or “Hi, Mr. U!” and they wave. Sometimes they give me a snack. One student gave me an Oreo-like cookie, except it tasted even better than an Oreo. I’ve received a throat lozenge, a chocolate Cheeto-like treat, trail-mix-type snacks, a little pouch of homemade walnut cookies, and even a Capri Sun-like pouch of soy milk. It was good soy milk, too.

After a few classes, it’s time for lunch. I eat lunch, and as I pass through the student side of the cafeteria to the teacher’s dining room, or from it, the students wave and say hi to me. Then I go back to my office, where students can come to talk to me during the remainder of the lunch period to practice speaking English. Sometimes I have as many as five or six girls who come to speak to me, but there are two girls who show up almost every day and sometimes they are the only ones who come to see me.

And then lunch is over, and it’s either time to teach fifth period or not, depending on what day it is. When fifth period is over, it’s time to clean. Well, for the students, it is. Although I think they must have a rotation of sorts, because not every girl cleans every day. Anyway, when it’s time for them to clean, I go outside and walk around the building. Many students are out there, either taking out the trash or, for those who don’t have to clean that day, getting some fresh air or running around on the “playground” (which is mostly a big dirt field, although there are a few pieces of equipment off to the side).

There’s something I’ve learned very quickly about Korean students. When they’re in class, they are study machines. And they are in class all day. So whenever they are not in class, they take advantage of every moment. When I first started going outside, I noticed that many more students would come to talk to me. So I continued to do it, because I wanted them to practice English. I love my students and I want them to do well. I sometimes see third graders (12th graders, whom I don’t teach) who talk to me, however briefly. But I also noticed something else: students would be very excited to see me. It doesn’t happen all the time, but often students will shout “Hi, teacher!” or “Hi, Brian!” from the classroom windows. Most of the classrooms are on the 2nd floor or higher, so I always have to look up to see who is calling to me, and usually I see a whole group of girls smiling and waving at me.

There’s something that I’ve learned about myself in Korea, something I probably would have (and probably did) deny in America: Not only do I have an ego, but I like it. I know that I’m popular simply because I’m different (or, according to many of my students, handsome) or because I’m a “fun” teacher (even though my classes aren’t always fun, they aren’t the academic classes they have to endure throughout the rest of their school days). But it still feels good to have such attention. Maybe that’s a bad thing, but at the moment I do not care. Okay? Okay.

Besides, it is attention like that that, I think, has allowed more students to become comfortable around me. I still have some students, on the other hand, who get shy to ask me a question or speak in front of me in class. Once, while walking around outside, a heard a few girls walking behind me. It sounded like they were merely walking in the same direction. Until I turned around. One of them started jumping and putting her hands to her face and shaking. Symptoms of nervousness. I guess she wanted to say hi but she was afraid. Every friendly word I spoke to her caused her to back away or blush. But a few minutes later she came back, nerves calmed and steadied, to say hi and to tell me that she was very shy.

It wasn’t always like this. I used to have many many more shy students. When I first came, the girls, as a whole, were very excited. They cheered and screamed and everything when the principal introduced me to the student body. They shouted, in the safety of the crowd of voices in the classroom on the first days, “Cute!” and “Handsome!” and whatnot. And they were very excited. But individually, they were shy. They wouldn’t say anything. After  a few weeks, I think they were not very shy any longer, but I think they noticed that I was not a good teacher, or at least not a very confident one (which means not being a good teacher). Or maybe they simply lost their initial enthusiasm for having a foreign teacher. But I think over the last month or two, I have grown more comfortable. In Korea, in my job, around my students. And they notice those kinds of things. So I think they are, once again, excited to be around me.

And then the cleaning period is over, and it’s time to go back inside and teach six period (unless it’s Tuesday, the only day I don’t teach sixth period but instead seventh period, the last period of the normal school day – I say normal because many students stay after for extra classes or self-study, and they are there long enough to eat supper at school!). Finally, my day is done, and it’s time to go home. On Tuesdays and Thursdays, one of my co-teachers who lives near to me takes me home (on the other days, she teaches eighth period, so she can’t). When I have to go home myself, I walk down the hill to the highway, where there is Naengjeong Subway Station (냉정역) and some bus stops. I can get on bus 6 and walk maybe seven to ten minutes uphill to get to my apartment (I haven’t really timed it), or bus 169 and walk maybe five to seven minutes downhill. I take whichever one comes first, usually.

On Friday, after I got done playing badminton with some of my co-workers after school (more on that later, I think), I started walking down the hill to go home. Mr. Lee caught up with me, as he was heading down the hill at that time, too. We walked together, and after a few minutes a bus passed us by. I wasn’t paying attention to the bus at first, so Mr. Lee told me to look. I looked up and saw three or four girls poking their heads and arms out the bus window and saying, “Hi, teacher!” “Hi, Brian!” They saw Mr. Lee and said hi to him, too, but then continued to wave at me. This last bit well tell you just how much these girls can affect my ego. As the bus turned a corner (so that now I could see the girls better and they me), a couple of the girls said, “I love you!”

And they blew me kisses.

(by Brian)

[Note: The pictures in this post are taken from the Creative Commons section of Flickr. I don't have a bunch of pictures of food right now and I'm not so good at food photography.]

We haven’t put up a Korea blog in a long time. I’m sorry about that. But tonight I feel like telling you about Korean food. I’ve had the opportunity to try lots of foods in the months that I have been here so far. (Side note: WOW. It’s already been more than four months? Also: WOW. It’s only been four months?) Anyway, most of the food I’ve tried here is very tasty, and I’d like to tell you about it. I also want to convince you to come visit us, because if you do, we will feed you some of these foods. And maybe you can help us escape.

Because here's the secret I haven't told you: When we're not teaching, this is where they keep us. Hurry, I need to delete this before they see it!

In all honesty, though, I know a few foreign, and possibly unappealing, meals aren’t enough to get you on a trans-Pacific flight. But I still want to show you what we eat on a normal basis. Let’s start with the obvious.

Kimchi

Kimchi is the most famous Korean food, easily. Everyone knows about kimchi. What most of us don’t find out until after we’ve stepped off the plane, however, is the vast expanse of kimchi. There are, apparently, hundreds of varieties of kimchi, and possibly more. Here is a sample of the kimchi I have tried: baechu kimchi (the most famous kind, the kind people envision when they hear the word ‘kimchi’), white kimchi (which is the same except without red spicy sauce), ggakdugi (spicy sweet radish cubed kimchi), some little white cubed radish kimchi that I don’t actually know the name of, sesame leaf kimchi, cucumber kimchi, whole radish kimchi,  kimchi made from leafy greens, and even water kimchi (it’s served in a bowl of cold, seasoned water and has a mild flavor). Kimchi has a lot of different flavors and the stuff here tastes much better than the kinds I tried back in America. However, people told me early on that it was not very good kimchi, and now I agree. The school’s kimchi is okay. I used to love it. But then I tried some homemade kimchi that had a perfect flavor. Now, everyday kimchi is still good, but…well, you now how it is. I tend to like kimchi that is more on the spicy side of the scale rather than the sour side. Although the sour kind is great for cooking with.

I've seen even bigger selections of kimchi at some outdoor markets.

Ssam

Ssam (which is pronounced ‘sahm,’ is spelled 쌈, and means ‘wrapped’) is not actually one food. It is a way of eating food, and I love it. The simplest way to explain ssam is to say that you take your food, add some sauce, and wrap it in a piece of lettuce. It only sounds sort of interesting, but in practice, it’s awesome. First, you can make it out of many things. It’s most often made with pork, but you can eat it with beef, with chicken, with duck, with fish (even raw fish), with rice and vegetables, you name it. The sauce is called ssamjang (쌈장), and it is slightly spicy with a flavor that I don’t know the word for. I can’t simply say ‘salty’ or ‘sweet.’ It’s very good, though. People will often also put a clove or half-clove of garlic in the wrap before eating it.

So inside the piece of lettuce, you have a piece of meat, some vegetables, garlic, and some sauce. Then you eat it in one bite, and it’s amazing. Usually the lettuce is a green leafy kind, not iceberg. Sometimes it’s not lettuce, though. My favorite is perilla. It is a leaf that has a flavor that is strong the same way that licorice is a strong flavor, and at first I thought it was very weird. Ssam can also be wrapped with seaweed or very thin slices of a daikon radish.

A very basic form of ssam, before being rolled into a ball and eaten in one very yummy bite.

Naengmyeon

Naengmyeon (냉면, pronounced ‘naing-myuhn’) means something like “cold noodles,” and the name is appropriate. After cooking the noodles, you rinse them in cold water until they are no longer warm. There are two main kinds of naengmyeon, both made with the same type of noodles (made from buckwheat, potatoes, and sweet potatoes): bibim naengmyeon (비빔냉면) and mul laengmyeon (물냉면).  Bibim means something like “mixed,” and this kind has a spicy red sauce added to the cold noodles. Ashley really likes this kind of noodles because of the taste of the sauce and because of the texture of the noodles. They are not too thick but they also don’t break too easily, she says. Mul means “water,” and so this second kind of naengmyeon is rinsed with cold water and then put in a bowl with an icy-cold broth made of water, vinegar, and other seasonings. It often actually has slushy-like ice chunks in the broth, so it is very refreshing on a hot summer day.

Both kinds often have other ingredients, such as thinly-cut vegetables or even Korean pears. And if you order a bowl of these noodles, you will get half of a hard-boiled egg that comes on top of the noodles. One of my co-workers told me to eat it first to keep the noodles from unsettling my stomach. Whenever Ashley and I make a bowl of instant naengmyeon, though, we don’t bother to cut up extra toppings or boil an egg.

Mul laengmyeon. You can see that the broth is a bit icy.

Ddeokbokki

Ddeokbokki (떡볶이) is a dish that is very popular among both Koreans and foreigners. In fact, The Korea Herald reported a survey that indicated ddeokbokki is the most popular street food among foreigners. So here is the street food entry for this list, although ddeokbokki (also commonly transliterated as tteokbokki) is not limited to street vendor carts.
