Restaurant and home versions of this meal are usually more complex, while what you can get on the street is, from what I can tell, more simple: ddeok, odeng, and the thick, gochujang-based sauce. Eggs, meat (chicken is popular), and vegetables are also common additions to this food. Now, I know a few recent words just went over your head. I’ll explain. Ddeok is ‘rice cake.’ Some are spongy snacks you eat by themselves, and many foreigners think that they are bland (some of them are pretty heavy on the flour or bland beans, but I’ve had some filled with chocolate or jam that were awesome). Some are rock hard and have to be cooked, and they become soft and chewy. It is this second kind that is in ddeokbokki. In the gochujang sauce (gochujang is a spicy, pepper-based condiment), they become sticky and sweet with a very fun texture. The last part is odeng, which is a kind of fish cake. It’s not as bad as it sounds.

Anyway, ddeokbokki is very spicy and it’s also a bit sweet. Sometimes people add it to ramyeon (ramen) for a super spicy dish that even I thought was almost too spicy. Ashley doesn’t care much for the rice cake part of ddeokbokki (which is good, I guess, because rice cakes aren’t exactly health foods, and, hey, more for me), but she likes the odeng and the sauce is good for mixing with other foods.

Usually, it's much saucier than this. But it still looks so good to me.

Chicken

Wait. What? Chicken isn’t Korean food. It’s everyone’s food. Well, in Korea, the chicken is great. I’ve seen comments on Waygook (the foreign teachers’ forum, where we discuss lesson ideas and life in Korea) that said fried chicken is one thing Korea does better than most places in America, and maybe it’s because I haven’t had American fried chicken in several months, but I tend to agree. The fried chicken (and other chicken) that I’ve had in Korea has not left me wanting. I can’t say I’ve had the best chicken of my life here, but I definitely haven’t had the worst.

There’s something interesting about chicken and kimchi that I’ve noticed. I mentioned kimchi already, but here’s something I didn’t say. Generally, kimchi is eaten at every meal. It’s a side dish, not an entree, but it shows up at nearly every meal. I think only at hamburger joints have I not seen kimchi. When you go to get chicken, you will get the white radish cubed kimchi, which has a mild and sweet flavor, and I expect that people repulsed by the idea of eating fermented cabbage probably wouldn’t object to this tamer variant. I think it’s a pretty good complement to chicken.

When we were new to Korea, Ashley and I went to a few chicken places. Before we had the basic food vocabulary that we have now, our strategy in all restaurants was to simply pick an item at random and hope it wasn’t live octopus. The risk isn’t so high in a chicken shack, but we still often didn’t know what we were ordering. The first two times we ate chicken, the server expressed concern and said, “Umm…is spicy.” “Okay,” I replied. And yes, it was spicy (and delicious), but certainly not cause for alarm. However, the third place, which expressed a similar concern, was completely warranted in its concern. I don’t think I have ever cried from spicy levels before that day. Okay, maybe my memory of the night has been exaggerated, but I do know that Ashley and I both felt the heat. And surprisingly, the chicken was chockfull of flavor. There’s always concern, when you make something too spicy, that the flavor will take the hit.

There’s a very small chicken bar (as in, there are maybe four tables crammed in 120 square feet or so, including the kitchen space) near our apartment. Actually, there are several all in the same building. But this one in particular is run by a friendly couple. Once, when we were looking for a place to eat, the woman looked at us and gave us a friendly smile and said we could eat at her establishment. So they got our vote. And as for the quality of that chicken, well, we’ve been back.

If you want a basic run-down of the differences between American fried chicken and Korean fried chicken, you can read this page.

If I didn't already eat supper, I think I might want to walk up the hill to that chicken shack I mentioned earlier.

This concludes the first five Korean foods to discuss. I will probably post another five later. In the meantime, you should go get lunch. I think that you should be hungry now.

(by Ashley)

So far, the Korean experience—and by Korean experience I mean my experience in Korea—has been rather positive. Korea is different from any place I have ever been, and some of these differences I find rather beneficial, especially having kimchi at every meal; in my opinion it is unsurpassed for assisting with digestion, but I’m sure most of you don’t want to hear about that.

1.        Koreans love to eat. When we think of Korean people we usually think of very slim, good looking folks who enjoy eating kimchi, at least I do. But although these stereotypes are generally true—I haven’t seen any obese Koreans yet–I’d have to say that I don’t know how Koreans stay so thin. They are obsessed with eating. Even their drinking culture isn’t like what we would think of in the West. One of our lecturers told us that at every pub they go to, they order a full meal with their drinks and on a night of drinking they might go to three or four different places!

Cafeteria food from orientation:

I don’t now what everything is called, but I think I love pumpkin porridge! That yellow stuff.

Kimchi, soup, peaches and things I don’t know what… 

Cafeteria Bibimbap, kimchi and tater-tots!

Anyway, since coming to Korea I have never actually felt hunger. Not because I couldn’t stand the food, because I like Korean food, but because during the orientation all of the meals were buffet style, and they just. Kept. Feeding us. Between meals there were cute little snacks, and there was always plenty, plenty to eat.  And anyone who knows me knows how I feel about eating food.

2.     Korea is convenient. I’m talking about the transportation system here. It’s so easy to get your t-money card and go from subway to bus to taxi and it all counts as one trip.  My t-money card is a little keychain that looks like a pink bear and I can charge it up with money at the subway station or convenience store, tap it on the subway turn-style thing and I’m good to go. I can also get on a bus, tap the “card” on a machine, and go. Some taxis even accept t-money cards. And I think it works in Seoul as well as here in Busan. That’s almost like being able to use your transit card in LA and New York, which seems pretty convenient to me. Also, if I wanted to—but I don’t want to–I could use my check card as a t-money card and skip the refilling stage altogether. It’s so nice!

My T-money "card."

3.    Korea recycles. This isn’t rocket science people. Ever since I went to Canada and saw all the recycling bins in public parks and pizza joints alike, I’ve wondered why the USA doesn’t have any similar initiatives. In Korea you can recycle almost anything for free; it’s throwing out trash you have to pay for. During the orientation, we couldn’t just dispose of our uneaten food in the garbage; we had to scrape all the leftovers into a bowl for composting. This, to me, is a good way to be responsible about our impact on the environment. Right now the United States as whole doesn’t care about the environment, and, in a global community that’s moving more toward solutions to our energy and resource problems, that makes me ashamed.

4.      Korea has heated floors. The ondol is one of the most wonderful heating systems I have heretofore encountered. The whole house or apartment is heated by the hot water pipes under the floor, and you can control the temperature via thermostat. I don’t quite understand all the functions yet, since they are in Korean, but I do like when I feel it start to warm up my feet, which are usually always cold. Dear Ondol, my feet thank you.

Some pictures of the Apartment (아파트)!

Kitchen

Bed seems bigger than the one back home...yay!

sliding door

5.    And finally, Koreans speak Korean. My brain, like most other people’s brains, is only interested in what it thinks is logically relevant or interesting. I think Korean culture and language is interesting, so I’ve learned to read the Hangul alphabet and a few phrases, but acquiring language takes use, and in America, there are so many reasons NOT to use Korean that I can’t even count them. Coming to Korea has eliminated these have been and would-be barriers to my learning. In Korea I am actually immersed in a culture that speaks an entirelydifferent language. In order to make myself understood I have to change and grow. Thank you Korea for providing me with the chance to do so.

(by Brian)

It’s been a while. Sorry. Sometimes I feel that nothing new has happened worthy of blogging about, but on the other hand, that’s completely false. Why, I’ll give you a brief update on things that have happened over the last several weeks (and maybe one of us will write some more on these topics later).

  1. At the end of the semester, my school went on a retreat. We got on two tour buses and drove to another part of Korea, first to a nearby city called Changwon (창원) to listen to the leaders of a Christian boys’ high school talk about their school (in Korean), then somewhere else in Korea to do some sightseeing. We were up in the mountains, secluded from pretty much anything except a butterfly museum and a cozy little hotel/lodge where we ate dinner and then stayed the night to resume some sightseeing activities the following day. It was very nice, although it was the first time I had been away from home overnight since I’ve been married. So Ashley was a bit sad, but she had gone to an orchestra and dinner with her school that evening. She came home pretty close to bed time, and I was back in Busan before she got off work the next day. A couple of times when I’ve been let early off of work, I’ve taken walks around the city until Ashley would get off work (I felt really healthy those days), so on that day, I waited outside Ashley’s school and sent her a text that read, without any untruth, ‘I should be home when you get there.’ Then she saw me outside her school, waiting for her.
  2. We’ve been slowly making more friends. We go on almost-weekly hikes now with some other foreign teachers (and even one Korean who usually goes too) on the weekends. It’s fun, although it’s pretty intense sometimes. I’ve posted about one of those hikes before. That hike was kind to us, but one we went on recently almost made us turn back. Ashley had to take a break and our friends had to wait for us to catch up.
  3. We’ve started ‘summer vacation’ which means, for Ashley’s school, that the students are out of school except some who signed up for special English classes. For my school, it means all the students have classes in the morning (for the first few weeks of vacation, then they actually get a break), but most of them get to go home after lunch or stay at school to self-study or take a special class (such as my conversation class with six students). So Ashley has a few hours of work in the morning, and I have a couple of hours of work in the afternoon (one hour with six students and one hour with five teachers). But we still have to be there the whole day.
  4. We’ve been learning Korean. And that is the main theme of this post.

Starting July 4, Ashley and I have been taking classes twice a week (Monday and Thursday) at Pusan National University. We’re not enrolled or anything like that. It’s just that a group students from PNU volunteer to teach Korean for free to 외국인 (foreigners) like us. Most of the teachers have one or two students, so we get very concentrated attention.

I said that one Korean goes with us on the hikes sometimes. Her name is JiHee, and she saw me post some sentences in Korean on Facebook, so she told me about the classes and invited us to join. The next ‘term’ was beginning, so we were just in time to take the placement test and begin the summer classes on July 4. Our teacher is named Hyeonseok (현석) and he’s cool. He’s our age (no, really, the three of us are all age 26 in the Korean way of counting age) and a very nice guy, but he does push us hard in class. He gave us homework to start a Korean diary, plus he assigned us to choose 10 new verbs and write sentences in the past and present tense. The next class period, he asked us to write sentences in the future and continuous tense. So it’s pretty intense.

It’s pretty good because I often listen to Korean lessons on talktomeinkorean.com (TTMIK), and I’m on the third level in that program, but I don’t really have in-person feedback on my learning. Hyeonseok gives that to us. He often tells me, ‘Well, the sentence is grammatical, but Koreans wouldn’t say it that way.’ And that’s the kind of help we need. It’s also good because TTMIK teaches a ‘middle’ level of formality, and Hyeonseok is starting us with the ‘high’ level of formality. He makes us read sentences out loud so we can practice pronunciation, and once he even wrote some dates on a piece of paper and had us read them as fast as we could. It was stressful but helpful.

Over the last few weeks I’ve really felt an increase in my motivation to learn Korean. Sometimes I’m lazy and don’t want to do it. But now I feel like, sometimes, I can actually understand a few things I read or hear. But usually only what I read. My ear is still rather untrained in hearing Korean, so I need to work on that. I listen to people talk to try to understand what they say, but mostly I just catch 진짜 (really?) or some other very common word.

The part of learning Korean that is the hardest is thinking of an end goal. Why are we learning Korean? And it’s a good question. We won’t be here long enough to become completely fluent in the language unless we’re here for three or four years, and then we’d be gone (unless we stay even longer). And outside of Korea, the Korean language isn’t very useful. People only speak Korean in South Korea, North Korea, and special Korean-heavy areas of China and Russia (I think). Once we go back to America, it will be difficult to maintain whatever level of Korean we attain (so I plan on finding some kind of webcam language exchange or something). And our jobs require us to speak English. So why are we learning Korean?

Ashley says I want to impress people. Which I guess is true. I’ve come to admit some things about myself I previously denied (see Of Celebrity), and one of those things is that I do like to impress people. But is that my only reason? I think not. I also know, from college and my professors, that knowing and using multiple languages is good for your brain. One benefit is the prevention of Alzheimer’s. And language has been shown to have an influence on the way people think and view the world. If I can learn a new language (especially one so different from English), then I can broaden my mind and think more deeply. If I learn enough Korean, I can also speak Korean to my children, and they will have a great headstart on multilingualism and thus will be geniuses who never get Alzheimer’s.

Also, I think learning one new language makes learning more languages even easier. I’d like to know Spanish, and if I tackle a difficult language like Korean, then learning Spanish will be a piece of cake in comparison. I’ve actually grown to adopt some Spanish phrases more deeply than English phrases over the years, and now that I’m in Korea, that fact is even bigger. I don’t know why. Maybe I’m in a country with a foreign language and Spanish is a familiar foreign language. So now, instead of ‘Are you ready?’ I often think of the phrase ‘Estás listo?’ Or instead of ‘Where?’ I think ‘Dónde?’

So why not learn Spanish right now? It would be an easy language to learn and it would be very useful back home in America or in one of more than 20 countries where it is the official or most dominant language. Well, I’m in Korea right now. It is the best language for me to learn considering the environment. I can’t practice Spanish at restaurants or at the street markets. I came to Korea for many reasons, but one of those reasons was to experience a completely different culture, and part of that experience involves the language. I don’t want to leave this country without learning a decent amount of the language.

Besides, how many non-Korean Americans can say they know Korean? Yes, I like doing things that are different, and maybe that is my biggest reason for learning Korean.

As for the language itself, here are some things I have learned about Korean.

People say the language is really difficult to learn. Many even say it’s one of the hardest languages to learn. Maybe it is, but I think it’s still possible. Here are the reasons they give for Korean being so difficult. (You can pretty much quit here if you want. It’s pretty technical from here on out.)

  1. Korean is an SOV language while English is an SVO language. The letters stand for subject, verb, and object. So in English, a typical sentence reads, ‘I ate food.’ In Korean, the same equivalent sentence is 저는 음식을 먹었습니다. The words in order are I, food, ate. It can be even more complex with things like ‘I went to the school.’ The sentence is 저는 학교에 갔습니다. I, school, to, went. So people say it’s difficult to learn to speak in a different order, but with practice, it’s not really so bad. With really simple sentences it’s almost not even a problem. You just have to get used to knowing first what is involved in the sentence and not what is happening.
  2. The Korean alphabet isn’t as easy as people say it is. First of all, yes, the Korean alphabet is different. But it was invented to be easy. It’s estimated you can learn it in an hour, average. But there are special rules for pronunciation. If a syllable ends in ㅌ (t)  and the next one begins 이 (ee), for example, then the two letters combine to form 치 (chee). And there are several rules like this, but they make pronunciation easier, actually. We have the same rule in English in a way. How do you say ‘Don’t you?’ We say, ‘Donchew?’ right? Because we took the ‘t’ from the first word and combined it with the ‘ee’ sound that ‘you’ starts with (say ee-oo quickly) and turned it into ‘ch.’ Another rule is that if a ㄹ (which can be R if there is one of them between vowels or an L if it is at the end of one syllable and the beginning of the next) follows a consonant instead of a vowel, it turns into ㄴ (n). In Korean, the R is actually a flapped R like in Spanish (not the rolled RR, but the single R, which is flapped). Saying that flap after a consonant is very awkward. A plain ‘English’ R is easy to say after a consonant because it’s a ‘liquid’ sound, but the flap is not so ‘liquid.’ So Koreans turn it into an N and it’s a piece of cake.
  3. Korean has built-in formality levels. The argument is that Korean is difficult because you have to learn several words just to learn one word, because you have to conjugate the verb based on whom you’re speaking with, depending on your age and the listener’s age, your title/job/status, where you are (home, work, etc.), and so on. The sentence I wrote earlier, about eating food? Check this out:
    1. 저는 음식을 먹었어
    2. 저는 음식을 먹었어요
    3. 저는 음식을 먹었습니다
    4. 나는 음식을 먹었어
    5. 나는 음식을 먹었어요
    6. 나는 음식을 먹었습니다
    7. 전 음식을 먹었어
    8. 전 음식을 먹었어요
    9. 전 음식을 먹었습니다
    10. 난 음식을 먹었어
    11. 난 음식을 먹었어요
    12. 난 음식을 먹었습니다
      These are all ways to say ‘I ate food.’ And there are even more ways to say it (I only used the three most common forms of the verb for ‘to eat'; there are seven levels of formality in Korean, but a few of them are rather rare). In reality, though, some of these are not very common. Sentences 4-6 and 10-12 use a form of the word for ‘I’ that is informal and usually not used with the polite form of ‘ate’ seen in numbers 3, 6, 9, and 12. And numbers 7-12 are only different because they use contractions of the word for I (sort of like the difference between ‘do not’ and ‘don’t’). All in all, yes, there are many ways to say the same exact thing in Korean, and you have to keep in mind the social situation in order to speak properly, but once you learn the endings that correspond to different formalities, it’s pretty easy to remember what the word is. And you’ll see that the difference between 1 and 2, 4 and 5, 7 and 8, and 10 and 11 is just one syllable at the very end of the word. You add that syllable to be more polite and you take it out if you are speaking to someone you’re close to or who is younger. Very easy. [Note: Ashley reminded me of another thing. It can be interpreted as something that is harder or easier about the language. I choose to think it's easier. In Korean, you can remove words if the context will provide that information. So I could take out the word for 'I' and people would still know that I ate food, even if I only said 'ate food.' If I spoke about a friend and then said 'ate food,' you would know it was my friend who ate the food.]
  4. Korean uses two number systems. Yeah, it’s true. There are two words for every number. At least up to 100. Beyond that, people just use the same system that money is counted with, which is good because it’s the easier system. We don’t really have two number systems in English, although we do have four different suffixes for ordinal numbers (st, nd, rd, th as in 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th).

Having said all that (whew, you read a lot), there are many things I appreciate about the Korean language. Some of the differences will take me some time to get used to, but once I know them, they will make the language so much easier. For just one example that I’ve learned so far, there’s a particle that means ‘also’ in Korean. It is -도, and you add it to whatever part is ‘also.’ Try this sentence: ‘Sam also went to get some food.’ What does also mean? Sam went, but Carl went, too? Sam went to get some water, but also some food? Or Sam did something at home and then he also went to get food? There are three possibilities in English. In Korean, you have to choose which one is true. You can attach -도 to Sam, which means someone else also went; or you can attach it to food, which means Sam bought other things; or you can attach it to went, and it means that Sam did multiple actions.

Well I fear I’m making this blog too long and too technical. Also, it’s pretty late here. 잘 시간입니다. (It’s time for bed.)

UPDATE: I nearly forgot. Here’s another reason I want to learn Korean, a big reason. Back in high school, maybe 9th or 10th grade, I learned about Hangeul (한글), the Korean writing system, and about how it was made to be easy. I decided to look it up. I learned it from the Internet, but it wasn’t much later that I forgot most of it (I did pick it up again here in Korea pretty quick though, and remembered a few things from that time, eight or nine years ago). I don’t remember every detail, but I probably stopped after learning the alphabet and learning that the actual language was very difficult to learn. Imagine if I had decided to spend just a few hours each week trying to prove those claims wrong. I’m sure I’d be fluent by now.

And there’s something I’ve known about myself for a long time now, and it’s that I’m a quitter. Well, in my life I’m trying to quit that (pun intended, and I would say sorry, but that would be a lie; I just really like puns), and I feel that finally learning Korean, no matter how long it takes, will be one great step toward reversing that terrible trait.

(by Brian)

Author’s note: Because our trip involved so much time and activity, a single post would be disastrously enormous. It will therefore be in sections. This first section deals with what happened just before our trip began.

Our six-day-five-night trip to South Korea’s volcanic island started on the wrong foot. I’m not even sure I would call it a foot. Maybe it started on a knee or an elbow. Yet we carried on.

We left early Sunday morning. Our flight was at 7:30 am, so, in keeping with the general rule of two hours, we wanted to arrive at Busan’s Gimhae International Airport by 5:30. As we would soon find out, it was a completely unnecessary motivation, and if we had not had it, I’m sure things would have turned out differently.

We woke up shortly after four, to be sure we could leave by 4:45 and ensure our arrival. I factored in the time it might take to find a taxi at such an early hour, the possibility of airport traffic, and, according to my usual methods, some extra time tacked on just in case. All of it, of course, unnecessary. We found a taxi in just a few minutes and it took us to the airport in less than 20 minutes and for less than 10,000 won ($9.20).

And then our vacation was ruined. A few moments after stepping out of the cab, I tapped my pocket in the same manner my father had taught me long ago. It’s an action I perform dozens of times each day without thought. The idea is to be sure your wallet is still there. The downside is that, if you touch your pocket and feel no wallet, the only difference is that now you know your wallet is gone. It doesn’t make the wallet any less gone. But it does help narrow down the possibilities of time and place of loss. After a quick scan of the sidewalk and road revealed no out-of-place bundle of leather, the instant conclusion was that I somehow dropped my wallet in the cab. Which was now well away from us.

There wasn’t a single thing I could do. If I had known I was going to drop my wallet, I would have looked more thoroughly at the cab driver’s information plate, so I could call him and ask him to turn around. (Actually, I would have just more thoroughly secured my wallet.) But as the driver had done no wrong (in fact, I was about to overpay him, because I thought the toll for the tunnel was more than it was, having misread the Korean signs, and he made sure to take no more money than what I owed), I had no need to write down his information to make a complaint.

Yet I called my co-teacher, the one responsible for taking care of me. I didn’t know what she could do, but nonetheless I tried. Of course, 5:15 in the morning is probably not her ideal time to receive phone calls. And she didn’t answer. Her phone is probably on silent in the night hours. That’s reasonable. I sent her a text: ‘At airport, lost wallet in cab. 어떻게?’ (That Korean word, eo-ddeo-ke, literally means ‘how’ but in context also can mean ‘What do I do?’) She would see it later.

After coming to terms, I was glad that I also learned another lesson from my father (thank you, Dad, for teaching me so much in my life). That lesson is to split your money. Don’t carry it all in one place. After withdrawing money for our trip, we split it between Ashley and me, and I further split some between my wallet and in a pocket in my messenger bag. So cash losses were very limited.

Which left only cards to worry about. The airport, luckily, had an Internet zone to use for free, although the computers were slow. I logged onto my credit card account and tried to send a message to stop the card, but I needed to call. I found out that my pay-as-you-go cell phone doesn’t allow international calls, so I sent a Facebook message to my parents to call and have my card stopped and to tell my bank to stop the debit card.

But that still left my ATM cards. Yes, I have two bank accounts in Korea because EPIK opened KEB accounts for everyone at Orientation, but many schools pay their employees through particular banks. In Busan, it’s usually Busan Bank. I had asked if it was truly necessary, and even my co-teacher, who had her own account already, had to open an extra one to be paid. If she had to, I knew that my foreigner self would have to as well. And although no one who could find my wallet would know my PINs, they could still make purchases at the check-out counter.

I briefly considered canceling our trip, but given the timing, we wouldn’t have received a penny in return. That deadline was two weeks ago. Also, what could I do if we didn’t go? Absolutely nothing that would in any way help me retrieve my wallet. I counted on stopping cards and hoped that it was unnecessary because of the generosity of Koreans. I’ve heard several stories about losing things in Korea, thinking that they’re forever gone, only to find that, for example, someone used your cell phone’s contact list to call people until finding out your address, and then mailing your phone to you. Or checking your ID card’s address and mailing your wallet or purse there. So I hoped for that, but I knew it was also possible for my wallet to fall into the wrong hands. Thus the precautions.

So we went through check-in and security. We had to wait to check-in, because counters didn’t even open until maybe six. And security took five minutes. I was thankful that we were going to Jeju because, without my foreigner card (which was in my wallet), I’m stuck in Korea. Our visas are single-entry. The foreigner card allows multiple entry. So if I leave without the foreigner card, I can’t get back in with my passport alone. I need the foreigner card. So choosing a South Korean island rather than one in the Philippines, as we had considered, turned out to be a good decision.

In the terminal, we saw two fellow English teachers, twins Genessa and Anushka, who are stationed in Daegu. We knew that they were also going to Jeju, but as it turned out, they were on our same flight. We told them about my lost wallet and they offered some encouragement. Much appreciated. They also told us about someone they knew who just withdrew $50,000 and then lost it. Ouch.

So we went to Jeju, but I was in a miserable state, worried that I had put my family (that is, Ashley and me) into financial ruin by the chance that someone would manage to ruin my good credit before I could do anything to stop it.

I’ll put a stop to your worries now and tell you that eventually I got the bank cards deactivated. It wasn’t easy. My co-teacher thought that I would need to talk to the banks myself, but I mentioned how I couldn’t speak Korean. Not to mention, it was Sunday. Could I do anything about it then? And the next day was a national holiday. It might be Tuesday before anything was fixed. That’s two whole days of opportunity for any would-be identity thieves.

Thankfully, I have a very kind and awesome friend named Gloria. She is Korean but was raised in New Zealand. She’s also an EPIK teacher, but one who knows Korean. And she’s the one who invited us to the Jesus Generation Movement church meetings we attend. So if I can’t count on a fellow Christian, colleague, and friend, who can I count on? I really hated to bother her, but this was important. So I called her and explained my situation, about how I couldn’t even understand the phone menu for Busan Bank and how KEB, as friendly as it is to foreigners, seemed not to be answering their foreigner phone lines this weekend. She called back within a half an hour and told me that the cards were now deactivated. I even got a text from one of the banks to confirm (it was in Korean, but in context I understood). God bless Gloria and people like her. She also took it upon herself to ask if any charges had been made in the last twelve hours. The answer was, thankfully, no.

(by Brian)

I guess we’ll get all of the bad stuff out of the way. In this post I’ll talk about transportation on Jeju Island. To put it bluntly, I hate transportation on Jeju Island. I’ve come to prize the efficiency of Busan’s transportation system and even Seoul’s sprawling network of subways, buses, and taxis. But in Jeju? Not at all. Of course, I spent less than a full week on that island, but regardless, I’m glad to be back in Busan, in regards with transportation.

Jeju, as I mentioned before, is a volcanic island. The Korean peninsula is mountainous, but the island of Jeju is a mountain. It makes sense that neither 제주시 (Jeju-si/Jeju City) nor 서귀포시 (Seogwipo-si/Seogwipo City) has a subway system. In fact, both cities contain lots of rural areas. I spent much of the week wrapping my head around a city that goes from dense and urban to grassy and rural to calm and coastal in just a matter of miles. At least it seemed that way. My point is, rural areas are not exactly prime real estate for the underground rail market. That leaves buses and taxis.

But that’s still a problem. In Busan, I ride buses every day and the subway at least two or three times a week. In Jeju-si, I rode buses only a few times. Why? Because buses in Jeju are terrible. They’re more scattered, for one, and quite infrequent. Depending on the bus number, the frequency in Busan is potentially fifteen minutes at the most, and sometimes as low as fifteen seconds (of course, it’s always frustrating when you see two number 179s come back-to-back while you’re waiting for a number 17), with an average of maybe eight or nine minutes. In Jeju? I’m not sure about downtown, where we didn’t need buses as much because we simply opted to walk (a fifteen-minute walk to the seaside Food Street and a nearby waterfall? Okay!), but in the rural areas, the standard rule seemed to be more like twenty or thirty minutes.

And even then, we couldn’t figure it out. In Busan, buses and bus stops have clear listings of where buses go. Sometimes the bus stop will have the same route map that the inside of the bus will have, to let you know every stop for each number bus that comes to that stop. Sometimes they only list the prominent ones, but even then you have a general idea of where the bus is headed. In Jeju? We didn’t have a clue. The first time we tried waiting for a bus to save money on taxis, I spent probably fifteen minutes of our thirty-minute wait trying to figure out the chart, and at the end I was no more enlightened than I was before we got to the bus stop.

Which was in the middle of nowhere:

I snapped this really quick while there wasn't a car in sight.

If you look closely, you can see that there’s a lane at this intersection designated for U-turns. I appreciated that, because it meant we could hail a cab from either direction. Most intersections in Jeju seemed to have this useful lane (and a number of them in Busan as well). And hail a cab we did, after a bus finally came and the driver thoughtfully informed us that, if we were going to downtown Seogwipo, his bus wasn’t. So we waited another five or six minutes for an empty taxi to come by.

The taxi experience on Jeju was rather interesting and made for quite a bit of our adventure on the island. With such a limited public transportation system, we often had to use taxis. Of course, we tried to do everyone together in terms of location on the island, to save money. In a way, it was nice, because taxi rides are very comfortable and quick. In other ways, it wasn’t nice, because taxis are expensive (although still much cheaper in Korea than in most other countries, it seems, by what other English teachers have said). Also, in the more rural areas, taxis aren’t as common as they were downtown or even in the sparsest areas of Busan.

The worst taxi experience we had on Jeju was on Tuesday night. We were leaving a rather lonely area, but one that was rather popular because of a few tourist attractions. We had tried getting there by bus, but going to a PC bang (an Internet cafe) and looking up the bus information was no help. We took a taxi, and it cost about 16,000 won, or a little under 16 dollars. (I’m glad that most attractions themselves in Jeju are very cheap). It’s a bit pricey, but not too bad. On the other hand, getting back to our hotel was not nearly as fun.

After a few minutes, we finally saw an empty taxi. We hopped in and I felt a little uneasy. As I was opening the door, the decals on the door looked briefly like police decals. But it was a taxi. I shook off the uneasy feeling. When we got in, I told the driver where we wanted to go. He didn’t know what we were talking about, so we told him a different nearby landmark to go to. Then he said, ‘이만오천원.’ We know what that means, but he proceeded to show us 25,000 won so we would know what he meant.

Oh, so he wanted to charge us 25,000 won, eh? When it cost nearly 9,000 won less to go the same distance. I tried to ask him what the deal was, but of course he just spoke in Korean. I remembered reading, just a few days before, that no matter what, you should always insist on the meter. So I did just that. I pointed at the meter and said ‘Meter.’ Okay, it’s in English, but the Korean words for things like meter and kilometer are, well, meter and kilometer. I figured he should know ‘meter,’ especially if I point at it.

He answered me in a rational Korean tone. I imagine what he said was something like this: ‘I can speak Korean, but you can’t, so even though I’m trying to rip you off, I’m speaking in a rational tone so you think that there’s a good reason I can’t use the meter now. I’ll pretend it’s because it’s night, even though it’s not even 9:30, or that it’s because you’re going so far, even though you probably came here by a metered taxi for a fair price.’

Then he started to drive. Nuh-uh. I’m a person who’s still learning to stand up for himself, so it was especially important for me to do what I did here. I told him, ‘여기’ (yeogi). It means ‘here’ and it’s the way you tell a cab driver to ‘stop here.’ There’s also the more polite form of ‘여기요,’ with ‘yo’ added to the end, which is what I usually use. He didn’t respond at all. I said it probably four times. He kept going. Finally I said, ‘여기 주세요’ (yeogi juseyo). It wasn’t quite a correct sentence (it means ‘please give me here’), but 주세요 is a form that means both ‘please give me’ and ‘please do for me.’ But in order for it to mean ‘please do for me,’ you have to connect it with the verb you want to be done. I didn’t know that word, so I just said ‘please give me here.’

Thankfully (or not, as you will see), it worked. He stopped. I started to open the door and considered giving him some money. But what was I to give him? His asking price of 25,000 won? No, we didn’t go that far. So of course I gave him what the meter read: zero. He could have received at least a base fare of 2,200 won for 20 seconds or so of driving, but he refused to start the meter (and if he had used it, he would have received a full payment around 16,000 won). So even though I later started to feel guilty about not giving at least the base fare, I did feel kind of justified by the fact that, by all appearances, he seemed to be trying to rip us off and, in addition, the meter read zero.

So we got out of the cab and the driver drove away. I believe he sneered at us while he did.

So now all we had to do was wait for another taxi on this lonely road. That was the worst part, and the part that made us wonder if we should have just accepted the 9,000 won rip-off in order to actually have a ride home. Cabs were still passing by, but they seemed to have occupants. We continued to walk as we waited for cabs, and once in a while we’d see one with 빈차 (bin cha) lit up in the window, which means ‘empty car.’ I’d stick my hand out in the polite Korean gesture, and reactions were varied, but equally disturbing. Some cab drivers sped on as if they didn’t see us. A few slowed down and, after getting a good look at us, sped away. I think one even turned off the 빈차 after seeing us.

What was going on?

Ashley wasn’t quite serious when she suggested that perhaps the cab driver angrily called the other drivers and warned them about us, but it seemed to be true, as unbelievable as it was. After maybe 25 minutes of walking, I realized it would take us hours. We’d have to walk until some morning driver on a different shift spotted us. I started feeling sorry for what I had inadvertently put my wife through, with images of us having to sleep in some field or dragging our exhausted bodies to our hotel room at dawn running through my mind. Finally, though, we found a driver who stopped for us and took us to where we needed to go.

For much less than 25,000 won.

We also did in fact take a few buses. On Wednesday, we went to Jeju-si (we stayed in Seogwipo-si) and visited a few attractions on that side of the island. To get there, we took the same bus that brought us from the airport to Seogwipo. In America, a similar airport shuttle bus from Michigan City to O’Hare cost $25 one way. It would cost Ashley and me almost $100 to go round trip. This shuttle was very nice, at 5,000 won a ticket. Round trip price of around $20, around one-fifth of the cost for nearly the same distance traveled. The shuttle also ran every 20 minutes rather than every hour. So naturally, we took that bus rather than spending who knows how much on a taxi to the other side.

Once in Jeju-si again, we went into the airport itself and a tourist desk worker with excellent English kindly helped us figure a cheap way to go to where we wanted to go by bus. So we took that bus route and eventually got to where we had to get off. (Jeju-si, being the capital city, would have more buses, we thought, and it turned out that we were probably correct.)

Of course, we still had to walk a ways:

But two kilometers was not much at all. In fact, after fifty minutes on a bus, Ashley said it would be good exercise. It also got us an unexpected discount at one of the two attractions that we visited at the end of this two-kilometer walk!

Tune into 129° East later for more details on Brian & Ashley’s Adventures in Jeju!

[Note: Not all cab drivers were like the one described in this post. In fact, toward the end of our Jeju-si Day Activities, we visited an attraction closer to the bus terminal, where we returned after the two attractions mentioned above, but in the interest of time we took a cab. On the way back, the driver asked where our next destination was (in awesome English), after we had already said the airport. I wondered why he cared, but then we said Seogwipo. He asked if we wanted to go to the shuttle bus. So then I realized, he wanted to know which part of the airport to take us to. But not only did he thoughtfully keep that in mind, he dropped us off one of the stops for that shuttle bus, saving us money on the cab fare and bypassing about fifteen minutes of the shuttle travel time.]

As Brian has mentioned before, Jeju-do (Jeju island) is volcanic. That means that the soil is very good for growing things, all sorts of things. Jeju is particularly famous for citrus fruits like halla-bong and other tangerines. In the neighborhoods we walked through, I also saw several persimmon trees, what looked like a few nut trees growing wild, and once even some pomegranates. The richness of the soil is not wasted at all. And, as it turns out, the soil as well as the weather conditions make the island an optimal environment for growing tea. So during our vacation we decided to go to a green tea farm. I enjoy drinking tea (hot, iced, or whatever) so I was especially curious about what the tea farm would be like. Also, I heard they made special ice cream.

On Jeju island the green tea facility is called O’Sulloc Green Tea museum. In front of the museum there are some nice topiary-like shrubs shaped like tea cups:

OoOoh!

This picture was taken by a friendly person who offered to help us take a picture together.”같이” they said.

They kind of cut off Brian's head, but it was an appreciated gesture.

Before entering the museum itself, we tramped through the green tea fields for a little while. The fields were beautiful and green, with rocky volcanic soil, buzzing insects, and the light fragrance of something very essential: manure. The sun was bright that day, and it was hot. As is their custom, Korean women walked around with parasols to protect their skin; as is customary for me, I relied on my God-given brownness. It was really a delight to watch everyone taking fun pictures standing in the rows. So Brian wanted us to capture these  moment as well.

but not without hardships on my part.

As I have mentioned already, the sun was bright that day, and even though my skin was drinking in the sun with joy, my eyes do not share its enthusiasm. I was happy to be in the fields of the tea that I enjoy so much, but my feet were not happy on the rocky soil, considering my footgear (flip-flops). My nose was a little offended by the rich, wholesome smells of the fertilized earth, and I really wanted some of that famous green tea ice cream. But not before taking an idyllic photo of my beloved surrounded by a lush field-full of the leaves that I love:

Look at him. Isn't he so happy and cute? Okay, I know you can't see his face, but take my word for it.

After this we made our way inside. Because it was hot, and because I wanted ice cream. But before we could have any, we had to get some culture. So we paused to contemplate the tea exhibit and learn about its origins, how it has been served in various cups, and poured from various kettles including those carved entirely from a single block of stone. Finally we learned about the health benefits of tea, and how it was imported to England in the 16th century. Very interesting.

The tea was equally interesting, and I don’t mean that as some sort of euphemism. They had free samples of freshly brewed tea, which was much more fragrant and flavorful than the cheap green tea I had back at the apartment, many people were gathered around to taste the tea, and I smiled at the taste, knowing that I was soon going to have to buy some of my own to take home.

Although it was listed on the tourist maps as the O’Sulloc Green Tea Museum, the main feature of the museum seemed to be the cafe, which was bustling. The line for the comestibles was long, but people were happy to stand in it. The cafe chairs both inside and outside the cafe were full of folks eating and drinking. The cafe’s menu boasted such delights as green tea ice cream, cake, and cookies, and even an absolutely delicious iced citron green tea. After making our purchases we waited with a buzzer for our order.

This is what we got:

I doubt that any of this has much health value but it was oh so lovely to eat.

After we ate our treats, we decided to go up onto the observatory decks and survey the fields from above. The wind was blowing up there and the weather had cooled a bit.

I'm sure he was thinking deep thoughts about the meaning of life.

I wonder what I was thinking. Probably something like, 'Oh, no! The wind is blowing my dress too much! Well, at least I'm wearing shorts underneath.'

So after the wind became too much for me to bear, I went downstairs again to buy my souvenirs: Green tea for brewing both hot and iced tea, which I have enjoyed greatly since being back in Busan.

Then we found a taxi and went along our merry way.

(by Brian)

As you already know from the video of our experiences on Jeju Island, we hiked up Mt. Halla (known in Korea as 한라산 and pronounced Hallasan; each ‘a’ is pronounced ‘ah,’ and ‘san’ means ‘mountain,’ so ‘Mt. Hallasan’ is redundant). Halla Mountain is the highest mountain in the Republic of Korea (South Korea), and we hiked it. It is only too bad, as you also know from the video, that we did not go all the way to the top. We cannot therefore say that we hiked to the highest point in South Korea.

But it was definitely the highest I’ve ever climbed in my life. We went on a backpacking trip for Wilderness Living class in college, and that lasted a weekend. However, we hiked mostly horizontal distance (with some inclines), not vertical. On Mount Halla, we continuously traveled upward. It was a bit of a work-out.

We had planned a few things earlier in the week. On Tuesday, we decided that on Wednesday we would head to Jeju-si to see a few sites there. On Thursday, then, we would hike Hallasan. We should have consulted the weather report, of course, but that unfortunately did not cross our minds. Things would have been much different.

We woke up around seven in the morning, so that we could perhaps be on the mountain by nine or ten. According to our booklet, the trail we wanted to take (the other nearby trail did not go to the top, and the other trails started on the other side of the mountain) would take seven or eight hours. We wanted to be done before eight at night for obvious reasons (especially given our terrible experience finding a cab in the evening earlier in the week). However, when woke up, we saw fog and mist and clouds. Not a good sign. Of course, this was the earliest we had been up that week, and maybe things would have still been different if we had thought about that.

We checked the weather. Rain. What a bummer, yet hey, we can go back to sleep. So we did. A few hours later the sun was in the sky and Ashley woke up, expressing her wish that we had gone hiking, now that the weather was fair. I wanted to go, too, so I said, ‘Well, we’d have to leave right now.’ So we did. We got ready, headed to the convenience store to put some trail snacks in my bag and to get some water, and hailed a cab to take us to the trailhead. The cab driver was friendly, although he kept asking if we wanted to go to 영실 trail (yeongshil). No. That trailhead was quite far away. The cab fare would have been probably more than twenty-five dollars (equivalent). I think he simply didn’t know about 돈내코 trail (Donnaeko) because, as the booklet told us, it was only recently opened.

He dropped us off at what appeared to be a cemetery. There was a sign that pointed the way to the trailhead, and we arrived just after eleven. We walked up, about ten minutes, to where the park office was located. So we started perhaps 11:15. The sign showed us the breakdown of the trail distances, and I saw something that appeared to say that the trail takes about six and a half or seven hours to complete, round-trip. I don’t know for sure, since one number and its accompanying text was bigger than the other number and its accompanying text.

Well, I thought, we’ll be done around six o’clock, maybe, or a bit after. I had assumed we would take quite a while.

We started walking. First, it was a paved road that led to an orchard. That orchard led to a wooden staircase that was mostly horizontal. Three or four steps and then twenty feet or so of leveled walking before encountering more stairs. Ashley and I remarked that the booklet said this was one of the easier courses, but we didn’t know it’d be this easy! Not a problem with us, though, we just wanted to get to the top.

But of course, after a few minutes, we left that wooden walkway. We came into a forested area, and the real hike began. The slope was gentle for a while, but eventually we had to climb quite a bit. The scenery was great and the forest was quiet. Once in a while we saw one or two people coming back down the mountain. We smiled to them and said hello (in Korean, although some of them greeted us in English). We moved at a quick pace. We wanted to get up and down the mountain before it was too late and cabs became scarce. Once in a while, we saw a sign telling us how many of the seven kilometers we had hiked and how many were remaining (seven kilometers is approximately 4.35 miles, so the round-trip was just under nine miles).

After an hour and a half or two, when we reached the four-kilometer point, I noted the time and thought that we were going pretty good, and we’d make the top before two as long as we didn’t hit a wall. But, of course, just minutes later was when I hit the wall. I slowed tremendously. Ashley frequently had to slow down or wait for me, even though she is usually the one to take a hike leisurely to enjoy the sights more than the actual traveling. That lasted more than half an hour. I constantly would think, ‘Hey, I’m getting my second wind,’ followed by an attempted increase in energy only to resume crawling two minutes later. Finally, we came out above the trees, where everything was pure gorgeousness. The mountain also reduced its slope a bit, and then we really did have our second wind. We also saw more people. Lots of people, all headed back down the mountain. We remarked on how much this mountain reminded us of Lost. After all, that show was filmed in Hawai’i, which is volcanic just like Jeju. It makes sense that the mountains would seem similar.

This path was so inspiring and peaceful.

Some volcanic rocks just chillin' (pun intended) among all that lush greenery.

Above the clouds! Yeah!

Anyway, we finally got to a shack, at the end of the seven kilometers, although there was a wooden staircase that lead to the very top of the mountain (so the seven kilometers was simple the main part of the trail, without the added portion). There, at the shack, a man was waiting. He seemed a bit concerned or confused and asked us a question. I thought he asked us where we came from, so we answered, 돈내코 코스 (Donnaeko Course). He told us ‘no more climbing’ while saying something about three o’clock. We were confused, because it was perhaps twenty minutes after two. Some other climbers were sitting on a wooden platform. It seemed that it would take more than forty minutes to go up (it was a pretty big staircase), and so we wouldn’t have the time to go to the top.

We were sorely depressed. We wanted to see the crater lake at the top. Even without that lake, we had gone probably 90 or 95% up the mountain. So we sat down for a few minutes just to enjoy the view and compose ourselves before heading back down the trail in defeat. After a few minutes, Ashley heard the man speak to some elderly Koreans, who were enjoying what appeared to be a post-hike picnic. She gathered that he asked them to ‘go with’ us when we went back down the mountain. Yes, because we’re foreigners, which means we’re incapable of being safe while hiking.

We didn’t want to be chaperoned, so we left immediately, perhaps ten minutes after reaching the end of the trail. Sure enough, at one point we looked back up the mountain and saw those elderly Koreans going up the wooden staircase. Ashley quickly deduced that the man asked them to ‘go with’ us up to the top. We had been walking for ten minutes at a quick pace already, so going back up wasn’t an option at this point. So now our mood was twice as bad.

I’ll spare you, though, and tell you quickly that just an hour later we were glad. Hiking uphill is tiring, but hiking downhill is painful, while you’re already tired. Each step downward on another rock was another jolt on our wearied bones. And there were a lot of steps. Also, going up is a thrill. We’re going somewhere. Going down is anticlimactic. There isn’t nearly as much excitement in it. You also have to be careful not to go too fast and thus lose your footing. In the end, we were very tired and our legs were sore. Going up to the very top to see the crater lake would have added easily another hour and a half, or two full hours, to our trip.

On the way down we also consoled ourselves, before realizing that we weren’t so depressed after all, by talking about returning to Jeju for a weekend, or even just one night, to hike to the top. Flights to Jeju are really cheap, so it wouldn’t cost that much to do anyway. But now I don’t know if we’ll actually do that. Why?

Here’s the answer. Before we went to Hallasan, I saw a picture of Baekdusan (백두산, the highest mountain on the Korean peninsula, on the border of North Korea and China) and its crater lake, called 천지 or Heaven Lake, shown here:

Isn’t that beautiful? So I imagined 백녹담 (baengnokdam, meaning ‘White Deer Lake’), the crater lake of Hallasan, to be similar. And according to a picture of it I later saw on some promotional flyer for Jeju’s inclusion in the New7Wonders of Nature, it is that pretty. However, that was clearly a promotional photo. Or perhaps an old photo that means to suggest the need to preserve that area. Because after returning to Busan, I saw this photo of the lake:

Just not quite as majestic.

It just wasn’t as pretty as we thought. Of course, in person it might look better. On the other hand, the promotional photo was probably altered to be better than the truth. Who knows for certain? So in the end, we really didn’t suffer that much loss. We had a good hike. It was beautiful regardless of our expectations and their disappointments. Not to mention, when we got to the end of the trail, to the end of the 14 kilometers, it was just before or right at five o’clock. Meaning we did the trail in less than six hours! We are excellent hikers.

[Note: While writing this blog, I found another picture of the lake. Perhaps it is beautiful. It certainly is from this view: link. But don't worry. It doesn't bring back my depression. I'm quite happy right now.]

Ashley and I attend monthly Saturday night worship services in Korea. We have gone every month, on the second Saturday of each month, ever since we arrived, starting in March. A fellow Guest English Teacher, who happens to be a Korean who grew up in New Zealand, invited us. The services are in Korean, but our friend translates for us. We really appreciate the service because it is serious Christianity. The pastor, who speaks fluent English, travels the world (and I mean the world) constantly, which is why he can only speak once a month in Busan. He is the most missionary missionary I’ve ever met.

But anyway, that’s not the point. The point is that last month, out of nowhere, he asked me if Ashley could sing. I said that she could, and after the service Ashley had agreed to sing a song for the next service.

Tonight was that service. And here is that song:

Yes. It starts after about thirty seconds of the song. Usually we sit in the back because Gloria, our friend, has to translate for us without disrupting other people. So I wasn’t planning to record it, because the sound would not pick up on my camera (which is not a video camera) very well. Today, however, there were more foreigners than usual and it’s Chuseok weekend, a major Korean holiday, so less people showed up. Last weekend, Busan ended its annual firework festival at Gwangalli Beach. This year it lasted nine days, which is much longer than it was in previous years. I guess the story is that seven or eight years ago, Busan lit off some fireworks in celebration of some one-time event. And the people enjoyed the fireworks so much that they decided to shoot them off the next year as well. Now it’s pretty much there for the heck of it. Also, because it generates revenue from all of the tourism and from the flooding of the restaurants and convenience stories and coffee shops in the area.

Ashley and I wanted to go the weekend before last, on the Saturday evening when there was a firework competition between four foreign countries. However, it rained that day and we got lazy.

So we made sure to attend the final night of the festival last Saturday. I showed up early to meet our friends. Ashley would come later and find us. I met up with our friends near the beach and we looked for an ideal place to watch the fireworks. Eventually we gave up on getting seats on top of a restaurant and settled for the beach, which was getting more crowded by the minute.

The show would start at eight. By the time we sat down on the beach, it was around 4:30. Ashley planned to leave the apartment around that time, so I expected her at the beach around 5:15 or 5:30, depending on the crowd. I called her to let her know where we were located, about how she could probably see us from the sidewalk. She said the subway line was packed going toward the beach and completely bare in the other direction.

So naturally it took her a bit of time to arrive. Based on how I felt when we left the beach afterward, walking down the street, she must have wondered if everyone was a lemming and she was headed for a cliff.

And because it took her some time to arrive, the beach became packed to the point that a half-dozen or so police officers were refusing entry for any more people. Some people even tried to tell the officers that they had come from the restroom, that they had a seat already, that they had left their bag on the beach, and so on. After Ashley and I finally spotted each other in the crowd, she tried to get onto the beach. No go. She tried to tell one officer 남편 [nampyeon] which means ‘husband’ and to say 남편 있어요 [nampyeon isseoyo] which meant, in that context, ‘My husband is there.’ The officer proceeded to put the megaphone in her face and yell at her in Korean.

Meanwhile, I was on the other end of a line of officers blocking people from passing through the very narrow walkway between the crowds of people waiting for the show. Some Koreans kept talking to the nearest officer, so while I waited, I thought of what to say and how to say it. The young officer finished speaking to the Koreans, turned to me, and said, ‘You can go out, but…you can’t come in.’ I tried to tell him, in both languages, that my wife was on the street. He said the same thing again and added that there was no space. I told him that we had space. I pointed to one of the cheap plastic beach blankets my friends that everyone had and said that we had one, so we had space. After all, it seemed that some people were getting in somehow, evidenced by the occasional small stream of incoming spectators. But he simply repeated his line.

So I left. I walked onto the street. My wife had been yelled at by a megaphone in a foreign language, so I wasn’t going to leave her alone. Once I got to the top of the stairs, I was in shock. The street was filled with people. Filled with people, all sitting down. I found Ashley and sat down next to her, and we waited there, dejected, for the show to start.

For a few seconds, I wondered if I might be arrested. The tension between civilians and officers in that area threatened a chaotic breakout, and nudging and occasional pushing had already begun. Would I get caught up and mistaken as a troublemaker?

I couldn’t believe how many people there were. The street was full of people sitting down.

It was sprinkling for some time, hence the umbrellas.

I can’t remember the last time I was in such a crowded area.

After a few minutes, we heard a Korean woman saying ‘치킨 있어요’ [chikin isseoyo] which means ‘I have chicken’ or ‘There’s chicken.’ Well, to cheer ourselves up (and because we hadn’t eaten much), we bought some of that woman’s chicken.

We continued to wait for the show while we ate our supper on the street. I didn’t enjoy being forced onto the street, and I didn’t enjoy knowing that a Korean yelled point blank at Ashley with a megaphone, but I did enjoy the sense of adventure and unexpectedness that we were experiencing. I thought at the time, ‘There is no way just hours ago I would have thought, “I believe that I will end up eating chicken in the middle of the road tonight.”‘

After we finished eating chicken, we still had maybe ninety minutes until showtime. Then that sprinkling that I mentioned earlier became a bit heavier. Generally, Koreans don’t like to be out in the rain. Enough people left the beach that we saw people begin to attempt to enter the beach. We decided to try for it ourselves. We got up just in time to see the officers leaving. There was no longer a block on beach access. We got in and found our friends. I had texted them to say that I’d be out on the streets since Ashley couldn’t get in. One friend suggested I try telling the officers I left my child on the beach or something, but I said that I couldn’t lie like that. Plus, we had a pretty decent spot on the street. I didn’t want to risk losing that too. So we were glad to be on the beach.

Even though we still had about an hour of waiting left.

In that time, the rain picked up a little bit more, on and off. By the time the show started, I think the density on the beach was about half what it had been. And because the show was forty-five minutes long, and because occasionally the rain picked up, it didn’t take long for the density to halve again.

Finally the show started, and at the bottom of this post you can see a brief, cheap video I put sloppily put together.

After the show ended, we left the beach, but we did not go to the subway station. We knew that would be a waste of time. We just took a walk. Of course, for a few minutes, that walk consisted of slowly pushing forward in a crowd of hundreds who simply moved along the road. We didn’t know where we were going. We were just going. Eventually a crowd of people pushed through our crowd, and I realized the going had been so slow because two opposing forces were in the middle of a showdown. The crowds broke through and then we were able to actually see the ground ahead of us.

And boy was it dirty.

We took a long walk, eventually arriving at the subway station two stops down from the beach. It was crowded, but not abnormally so. But the subway car itself was very packed. We were very glad once we finally got back home.
