This weekend, Ashley and I tried a new restaurant. We passed by a sign one day that read 대림참치 (Daerim Chamchi), and we know that 참치 means ‘tuna.’ So we took note of it and, on Sunday, we walked down the stairway into the basement of that particular building, where this cozy little restaurant was located.

Did I say cozy? Maybe claustrophobic would be a better word. When we entered the restaurant, we saw a long, narrow table in a long, narrow room. The table had a space in the middle for the chefs to walk through and prepare food. I wasn’t quite prepared for such an intimate setting, but we had entered already, and there were plenty of seats. Only three other patrons dined there, leaving probably twenty or so extra seats empty. As foreigners in a mostly empty establishment sitting right across the counter from the chef, we would be scrutinized.

I heard the customers across the table from us say 외국인 on occasion, meaning ‘foreigner.’ Ashley says one guy even pointed at us while speaking. I think they laughed at our chopsticks skills. Or Ashley’s maybe: I’m quite proficient with chopsticks. I’m not bragging. I’m repeating the compliments of nearly every co-worker I’ve eaten lunch with. (Okay, I’m bragging.)

Another chef at the restaurant must have thought our skills were lacking, though, because after a few minutes he took away our metal chopsticks (the kind of chopsticks Koreans use) and gave us some wooden chopsticks (which are more familiar to most people and, because they have more texture, are easier for some people to use). I prefer the metal ones but I wasn’t going to argue.

You can be at ease, though. I purposely related all of the negative and minor details first, perhaps slightly inflating them in the process.

When we first sat down, the chef gave us the menu and asked if we spoke any Korean. I replied 조금만, which means ‘only a little.’ It turns out that his English is very good, though, and throughout the meal he would converse with us. He was very friendly and for that reason alone, I want to return to that establishment just so that he will know that we enjoyed our previous visit.

Yet there’s another reason. I also want to return because the food was awesome. As we looked at the menu, and as I tried to quickly read the Korean and decipher the meanings, the chef simplified things for us by telling us a few things about the main page. Next to one item was the price 20,000 won per person (about $17.50), next to another was 25,000, and then 35,000, and I think two more prices that reached 70 or 80 thousand won. He explained that each increase in cost meant an increase in the cuts of tuna you can get. So the real prime stuff must have been at that 80,000 won price. All the prices seem kind of expensive, but any kind of sushi or sashimi is, especially good stuff such as tuna. We also gave ourselves a weekly budget starting a few months ago, so if we decide on one day to treat ourselves, we simply cut back for the rest of the week.

The chef said something about getting full and telling him to stop. I did not want to assume, because of the language barrier, that he meant this was an all-you-can-eat deal. So I intended to eat until I noticed him looking at our bill and considering adding another tally mark to it.

He never did though. When Ashley got full and said so, I thought I’d play it safe and let that be it. The chef remarked, ‘Most of our guests eat lots. You don’t want any more?’ Well, I did want more, and I don’t like lying.

So I got more.

Lots more.

We did, after all, already have the bill (in Korea, you usually get it right away, which is nice). No one had bothered to even look at it. Also, I didn’t mean to eat so much. Whenever the board would be low on pieces of tuna, the chef would take the bin out from the cooler and cut a few more strips.

We didn’t only eat tuna, of course. Right away we were served our own bowls of salad, soup, and rice porridge, and on the board where the tuna would be placed were also some vegetables, sushi roll pieces, and some aged kimchi. All of which were replenished as needed. Throughout the meal, the hostess would bring out other dishes, such as such tasty vegetable dish or a hot bowl of steamed egg custard (it’s good).

I think we actually got a special treatment. I think that our menu choice allotted four different cuts of tuna, but I’m pretty sure we had more like seven. He would tell us which part it was, too, and suggest which sauce would go best with it (and, of course, he was right). Sometimes the soy sauce mixed with wasabi, sometimes the garlic oil. At one point, he got out a torch and used it on a few pieces of tuna. Then he assembled for each of us a treat with those torched pieces on a piece of roasted seaweed with a few well-chosen vegetables. It tasted like artwork.

I’m sure if I ate as much sashimi at SoHo (the place in Mishawaka where I would get sushi or sashimi back in America), I would spend probably 50 or 60 bucks for myself alone, probably more. One piece of tuna there would probably be three or four dollars, and seven dollars for the prime cuts. And although the pieces we ate at Daerim were smaller, I ate a good 25 or 30 pieces. At least. That’s not to mention the other food brought out to us periodically.

So how much did we spend? Our food cost 50,000 won, or about $43 for the both of us. The only times I ever got full at SoHo were from buying a regular dish and having just a few pieces of sushi on the side. This time I got full primarily on sushi.

Yeah, we’re going back someday.

Sometimes, Ashley and I go to the movie theater. We watch American movies, of course, which have Korean subtitles for the mostly-Korean audience. At any given time, I think a theater might show an average of three different English-language films. Take out the ones we absolutely don’t want to see (such as the children’s films and recent releases such as Breaking Dawn), and we end up watching most of these movies pretty quick.

We also would like to see some Korean movies. But we know that our Korean skills are not even high enough to watch a half-hour children’s show, so the only way it would be possible would be to see a movie with subtitles. Most people in Korea speak Korean, so it makes sense for movies not to have English subtitles.

Yet one day, while browsing talktomeinkorean.com, I saw that some theaters in Seoul and Busan have foreign subtitles. Could it really be so? I Googled it and found a page on the Official Site of Korean Tourism. It claimed two theaters in Busan that had foreign subtitles for select films. One theater includes Japanese subtitles and the other includes English.

Yes! We would be able to watch a Korean movie and perhaps pick up on some language use. Well, we went to that theater, in Centum City (which is a shopping district in Busan that includes the world’s largest department store, twenty feet next to another large department store) and could not see any markings that indicated which films had subtitles. We decided just to watch an English-language movie, The Help, and to come back some other day.

Well, today was that day. I made my plan and we went to Centum City again. This was my plan: to ask the ticket clerk 영어 자막 있습니까? It means, ‘Are there English subtitles?’ I guess I expected her to say, 네 (yes) and then show me a list of which movies had subtitles. Instead, she spoke in rapid Korean. I couldn’t catch a word of it. I guess that’s what I get. If I speak a fluent sentence, I guess I should expect such a fluent response.

I tried again. She didn’t understand what I meant. She asked me for the title of the movie I wanted to see. I didn’t know that. We just wanted to watch any Korean movie that we could. So I asked, 영어 자막 있는 영화? which is an incomplete sentence (I hadn’t planned this one like the other) roughly meaning, ‘Movie having English subtitles?’ or ‘Movies that contain English subtitles?’ She got excited and got a book of movie posters. I thought it would be a reference to which films contained subtitles, but then she opened the book and pointed at a movie we had already seen. An English-language movie, I mean. We said no, so she pointed to another. Saw it. Another. Didn’t see it but don’t want to. Finally I apologized to her and we left.

Well, we hadn’t eaten anything yet for that day so we decided to get some food. But I wanted to try one last time. I realized that my second Korean sentence wasn’t very good, and I had an idea to make it better. I went back and grabbed the notebook in my bag. I wrote a few sentences, which I would use as backup if I stumbled over my Korean.

I wrote 인터넷은 “이 영화집은 영어 자막 있는 한국 영화가 있습니다” 라고 했습니다. 영어 자막이 있는 한국어 영화가 있습니까? 만약 그가 있으면, 우리 보고 싶습니다.

Rough translation (or the good English equivalent of my poor Korean): The Internet said this movie house has Korean movies with English subtitles. Are there Korean language movies with English subtitles? If there are, we want to see them.

I said I would use the writing as a backup, right? Haha. Well, I got to the desk, a different employee this time, and simply held up the notebook. I guess my voice caught or I forgot what to say or…well, you know.

The woman looked at it for a few seconds in confusion (probably because, hey, what’s this foreigner doing shoving a notebook in my face?) and then shook her head apologetically and said no, they don’t have the subtitles.

Okay. I thanked her and walked away. Defeated. I wondered if I had remembered the theater correctly. But no. I got home and checked. That site clearly shows the correct theater (it’s at the very bottom).

Well, I guess we’ll just have to stick with English-language movies. We won’t get to see what very many Korean movies are like, for now.

Today, during the 20-minute break between fifth and sixth period, I took some candy to a few classrooms to pay back students who had won candy on a day when I had run out of candy. When I finished my task, I made my way back to the English Café, and a gang of students from one class accosted me in the hallway.

“Teacher teacher! Wake her up! She’s sleeping, wake her up!”

“What, huh?” Before I could get an answer, they huddled together to influence my movement toward their classroom. The rest of the class stood expectantly inside and there was one girl sleeping at her desk. She was all bundled up. (School hallways are not heated in Korea, and it would be too expensive to keep the classrooms constantly heated as well, because Koreans value fresh air and often open a window. There has to be a balance of fresh air and heat. From what I gather.) She had a coat on, she had her hands tucked into one of those pillows that has space for your heads. Her head was face down on her hands.

The students told me, “Teacher! Wake her up!” They looked so excited. They wanted to play some kind of prank on this girl.

“No,” I said to them, “it’s break time. She can wake up when it’s time for class.” I do not want to stand between a Korean high school student and her sleep. I think they don’t get enough as it is.

“No, teacher! No! Wake her up!”

The whole class was yelling at me to play this part in their joke, and I wondered that the student wasn’t waking up from the volume alone. Some people are heavy sleepers.

But.

But then I took a look at the student again (having been, for the past moment, directing my attention to the crowd of students egging me on).

“There’s no one in there,” I said.

“No, teacher, she’s there, she’s sleeping!” they all affirmed.

“No, she’s not there, there’s no one in there, 사람 없어요. No one is there.”

“No, teacher, 있어요! She’s there!”

So I pointed at the cuff of her coat, which was pinched shut inside the hand pillow.

The end of our contract period is approaching soon. We have less than three months remaining. If you are so inclined, please pray for us to make the right decisions for what we will do afterward, and that wherever we end up – Korea or America, or even elsewhere – we find suitable work. I’ll explain more later. Thank you.

By our contracts with the Busan Metropolitan City Office of Education, we get 10 days of vacation during winter break. The Lunar New Year, a three-day holiday in Korea, occurred on a Monday, so we actually get 12 weekdays of vacation. Ashley’s started after January 13 (Friday) and mine started on January 17 (Tuesday), so our vacations are only off by one day. We have fifteen calendar days of shared vacation. In the summer, we shared nine, including the weekends.

The vacation is still in progress: Ashley returns to work on February 1 and I the day following. But most of it has been accomplished. Here’s what was up:

First, we did a whole lot of nothing. We stayed home and relaxed with a whole lot of nothing. But on Sunday morning, we went to Gimhae Airport and flew down to Jeju Island. Yeah, we went there already, but this time we visited some friends from Andrews University. We spend three days hanging out with Chris and Becka in Seogwipo, the city that covers the south half of the island. We had quite some fun, although we were surprised by the weather in Jeju. The island is considered the “Hawaii of Korea,” but apparently that’s only acceptable to say in the summer. Almost everything was just as green as it had been, but the temperature was colder, and the wind was biting. I was glad I brought my scarf.

So was Chris.

In fact, it snowed a bit in Seogwipo. Only a bit, though, but in Jeju City (the north half of the island), it snowed a lot, as we learned on our slow bus ride to the airport on Wednesday.

In the background of that photo above is the Yakcheonsa Temple (약천사) we visited briefly on Monday. Chris and Becka thought that it would be all decorated with lanterns and other ornamentation for the Lunar New Year. However, there was only disappointment. They realized that perhaps the lanterns only come out for Buddha’s Birthday. They had also expected the holiday to be a big deal, as it is in China, with parades and parties and public celebrations galore. But it seems that most of Korea’s biggest holidays simply involve people visiting their eldest relatives and having a quiet celebration at home.

Making this place sparsely populated.

We also took walks along the coast of Jeju, near some waterfalls, and we revisited Cheonjiyeon Falls (천지연 폭포).

Chris and Becka at Cheonjiyeon Falls

Brian and Ashley at Cheonjiyeon Falls

After we went to Cheonjiyeon, we went to the coolest cafe I’d ever been to. It was a little wooden cabin house with a couple of fireplaces. There was one room where you could order drinks and snacks. The rest was one big room in the cabin with booths and partial walls added to make places for friends and families to gather. The atmosphere was very cozy, friendly, and “local.” We also ordered some sweet potatoes that were roasted in the fireplace, because Ashley loves sweet potatoes. Chris got some corn on the cob, but we’ve determined that Korea and corn have an odd relationship. I’ll leave it at that. I wish I had known about that place last time we were in Jeju, even though we went right by it. It’s hidden among trees and plants that grow all around it. We had seen it before, but only the part of it where Jeju oranges were sold at what appeared then simply to be a roadside stand.

Among other activities were visiting a noraebang (노래방) which literally means “singing room,” and having dinner at 행복한 차실 (which is also called, and literally means, Happy Tea Room). A noraebang is similar to karaoke at a bar, except you and your friends get a room to yourselves. You don’t have to sing in front of any strangers. Ashley sang Radiohead’s “Creep,” which everyone loved hearing when she sang it on Rock Band back home. I sang a few Korean songs (or tried to at least). Chris got a video of me singing 그렇고 그런 사이 by 장기하와 얼굴들. My best performance was on another song, though, but I don’t think he got a video of it. If he posts the video, I’ll add it to this page or make a new post for it.

And the Happy Tea Room is a small restaurant in the upstairs of some woman’s home. Although it’s called the Happy Tea Room, they serve full meals. We all ate some kind of soup that had green pieces of ddeok (떡, or rice cake). It was quite delicious. We met a couple of Chris and Becka’s friends there. Despite there being six people, apparently most of them don’t care much for kimchi. At one point I realized I had eaten most of the kimchi (it was especially good kimchi). I expressed my guilt of hogging all of the kimchi, but everyone assured me that I should eat it all myself. No problemo.

Other than that, we didn’t do too much. We just relaxed and hung out with our friends. It was cool to see them. They kept remarking how strange and awesome it was to see people from their former lives, and university no less. We had experienced it when we met Kristina, and when we had met Dr. Closser and Dr. Greig, but it had been a while since those visits. It was nice to see people from the past, to speak with them about our similar and differing experiences, and to have prolonged exposure to people who spoke English.

Unfortunately, somehow Ashley injured her foot during our last full day in Jeju. Sometime on Tuesday, her foot suddenly started hurting with every step. I suspect that it was because of all the walking we did. We hoped that her foot would feel better the next day, but that was not the case. On Wednesday morning, we left Jeju, and Ashley’s foot hurt just as much as it did the day before. Still, she toughed it out and we got on the plane to Seoul, where we planned to stay for two nights and relax. We had very little plans in Seoul, other than to meet Ashley’s former employer, from when she worked as a webcam tutor, and with Ashley’s foot injured, we doubted that we would add much to those plans. Which was okay, because…

...this was our hotel room...

...and this was the jacuzzi/shower that came with our hotel room, next to the heated-seat toilet...

...and here are the computers which were in our room...

...one of which had an input setting on this big screen TV in front of the bed.

That computer had a bunch of DVDs saved to it, so there were lots of movies to watch. And did I mention that the TV had surround sound? Ashley kept saying it was the coolest hotel she’d ever been in. It was pretty cheap, too.

With Ashley’s injured foot, we didn’t go far for supper that night. Before that, I stopped by a pharmacy to buy her an elastic bandage, first learning the word for “elastic bandage” in Korean (it’s 탄성 붕대 in case you’re interested) so that I could ask the pharmacist “탄성 붕대 있습니까?” (“Do you have elastic bandages?”) After she wrapped her foot, we walked down the street and found a tuna restaurant. It was a bit pricier than we expected, but it was delicious.

The next day we met David, Ashley’s former supervisor, who had also been trying to help us find jobs in Korea. He turned out to be a very friendly guy. I liked him, and not only because he bought us tea, lunch, and snacks. We went to a touristy area that’s popular with foreigners called Insadong, and one of the first things we stopped at was a snack cart, where David said, Oh, free samples. He gave us each a piece, and then the vendor encouraged us to try all of the flavors. David asked us if we liked it, so when we said yes, he bought us a bag. He wanted to take us to a tea house, but it wasn’t open yet, so we walked around and looked at various shops. Some of the shops allowed customers to make their own goods. You could make your own cake, or take a simple mirror and add jewels or beads or paint to it, or make a candle, and so on. We didn’t do any of these things, but it was neat to look at.

Then we went back to the tea house, which was now open. He and I both tried the ginger tea (he said he always gets jujubee tea, but that he should try something new). It’s now my favorite tea (or at least that ginger tea is my favorite; I suspect if I try to buy it elsewhere, it would highly disappoint me). Then we went to lunch, where all three of us were surprised and glad at the food. There were many side dishes with our meal, and all of them were very tasty.

David had printed out some information for the Seoul City Tour bus, which would have let us get off at any of 18 spots, see a sight, and wait for another bus to come every half hour to continue the tour. Some of the stops were just hotels, for various tourists, and we only saw a few items we wanted to see that we hadn’t. With Ashley’s injured foot, though, we also took the bus anyway as a way to see the city without having to walk too much. In the end, though, we decided just to take the cable car up Namsan to see the Seoul Tower. When we visited Dr. Closser and Dr. Greig, it was too late at night to get tickets to go into the tower, but this time we saw the tower. We also saw some traditional Korean performances at the top of Namsan, and we ate some of the best hamburgers I’ve eaten in this country.

Ashley looks at the Seoul sprawl.

A bit hazy out that day, I guess.

I think most days in Seoul might be like that.

In front of the sun, shining on the river. Looks a bit apocalyptic.

Last but not least: Ashley loves teddy bears.

Afterward we took a bus down the hill and then, when we were at the closest station to our hotel that was on that bus route, we took a cab (because Ashley’s foot was in quite a bit of pain) to our hotel to take it easy for the evening. The following morning would have us check out and get on the Mugunghwa, the cheapest (and slowest) train to Busan. We chose it for its scenic advantages over the faster KTX, although I think the scenery was much better last time we rode the Mugunghwa, when the scenery was in full green.

And now we’re back in our apartment. We have a few days of vacation left, but they will, I hope, be spent more productively, taking advantage of not being at work during business hours. We have some errands to attend to, including applying for an extension on our visas, because our one-year contracts started about 10 days after we entered the country on one-year visas.

And I hope that Ashley’s foot is fully healed this weekend as well. On Friday, she remarked that it didn’t feel quite as bad as the day before, although it still troubled her to walk at great lengths. Pray for her foot, please.

The Busan Decision

Look here, you who say, “Today or tomorrow we are going to a certain town and will stay there a year. We will do business there and make a profit.” How do you know what your life will be like tomorrow? Your life is like the morning fog—it’s here a little while, then it’s gone. What you ought to say is, “If the Lord wants us to, we will live and do this or that.” (James 4:13-15 NLT)

Ashley and I are right now living the above passage. On February 14, 2011, we said, “Tomorrow we are going on a plane to a certain city and will stay there a year. We will teach there and earn a living.” And now we say, “What does the Lord want us to do: this or that?”

Our contracts end on February 25. It’s a Saturday. As of that date, we will no longer be employed by the Busan Metropolitan City Office of Education (BMCOE). That admission was long in the making. Just months ago, we expected to stay at our schools and work at least one more year. In fact, we had even decided to stay at least three, and possibly four, additional years. It was our four-year plan.

Then December came. December is the month when people generally find out from their schools if they will be renewed. We had a stressful time. We heard from our colleagues on Facebook, fellow foreign teachers of English in Korea, that the BMCOE needed certain documents by a certain date. These documents included a health check, which would take a few business days to process. We were approaching the date without a word from our schools. Finally we asked our schools to give us a few hours off from work to go get our health checks processed, even though they had said nothing regarding these things. So I went to get my health check, and Ashley was to go the next day.

However, that next day, Ashley found out from her school that she would not be rehired next year. It turned out that she was doomed from the beginning, from the moment she was placed with a school that prefers to employ a fresh teacher each year.

We spent some time in deep thought, considering the options, which at the time appeared to be 1) go home and hope the job market wasn’t as bad as people were saying it was; 2) stay in Busan and hope Ashley finds a job; 3) stay in Busan while Ashley becomes a housewife, because then at least one of us would have a job. We didn’t like option 3 much, and option 2 seemed difficult, because although there are many jobs in Korea, it would be difficult for us to find her one that fit with our needs. Sure, hagwons are everywhere in Korea, and therefore the job market is generous. But hagwons are after-school educational institutions. Most of them have hours until nine or ten in the evening, which is a problem for us regarding Fridays. Still, we considered the possibility; some hagwons have morning hours, and some hagwons teach adults, which would be even more in line with Ashley’s abilities and interests.

Yet there was still the question of my employment. Was I to be rehired? I had begun to doubt. Ashley’s co-teacher had called my co-teacher to ask if I had been renewed, but my school said that they didn’t know. That’s enough to lower a man’s confidence. Finally, though, my school gave me a decision. I was called down to my co-teacher’s office, where she told me, “Congratulations, you passed the evaluation.” I told her that I didn’t know, though, if I could accept the renewal, and I explained the situation.

“I talked with Ashley’s school and they said that if you are rehired then they will change her points.”

What? Really? This was great news if it were true. In either case, my co-teacher said I needed to decide to turn in the documents for renewal by the next day. I went back to my office and contacted Ashley, telling her the great news. Later, my co-teacher came and said, “I called Ashley’s school and they are not sure if they will change her points. So please consider that when you make your decision.”

Heartbreak. Utter heartbreak and anger. What is up with Ashley’s school? Maybe there was something lost in translation. Maybe my co-teacher misunderstood Ashley’s co-teacher, and then that misunderstanding was translated. It could happen in English alone. This was in English and Korean, so there you go.

The next day I asked my co-teacher if Ashley’s school had decided for certain whether they would hire her. “No.” Then I brought up the possibility of submitting my documents and then, if Ashley failed to find a job, of refusing to sign the contract. She said it was alright. Then she asked me to sign the contract. She explained, when I showed apprehension, that it was a preliminary contract. It didn’t even have all the details filled in yet. She also explained that my school would allow me to back out of my contract a few weeks before the school year would start if Ashley couldn’t find a job.

They were certainly being very generous, and I did note that the contract itself allows employees to give a 60-day notice if necessary. If push came to shove, I could work for two months and then leave, or even fill out a six-month period.

Well, a few days later, my co-teacher called me to her office. When I saw her, she just looked up from her computer at me. Normally she would say 안녕! (Hi!), so I started to wonder if something was bothering her. She told me to sit and asked if I wanted some tea. She was very quiet. Finally she sat down and said, “I don’t know how to tell you this, but…”

My evaluation had been 81. The minimum to renew was 80. I had received a perfect score on attitude, but I had missed some points on teaching and student reaction. The BMCOE, probably in an effort to meet a reduced budget, decided to cut high school foreign teachers by raising the minimum evaluation score to 85.

“Oh, okay,” I said. I explained that it was quite alright, because it made decision-making easier for Ashley and me. And in truth I was indeed very calm. My co-teacher was more upset, it seemed, than me. She had been afraid how I would take the news, but I assured her that it was quite alright. And it was. I had been quite depressed earlier at the thought of leaving my school, just when more of the shier students began to be less shy around me, just when I started to form closer relationships with some of my co-workers, just when many students had been telling me, “We love you. Our school loves you.”

But I think I moved on from that. I’ll still miss my students and co-workers, but it no longer feels like the end of the world.

The Daejeon Decision

So we couldn’t stay in Busan unless we got university positions or found a Sabbath-friendly hagwon to work at. Ashley had remained in contact with her former supervisor, from when she worked as a webcam tutor for elementary and middle school students in Korea. He began looking into jobs for us around Seoul, where he works, and throughout Korea. He passed our resumes on to various schools, and one school in Daejeon seemed very promising: 대전삼육초등학교 (Daejeon Sahmyook Elementary School). It’s an English immersion school, meaning that the students learn many of their subjects—math, science, language arts, and geography—in English from foreign teachers. It’s also a school run by Seventh-day Adventists, meaning that there would definitely be no trouble with keeping the Sabbath.

The news came at a time when we were just starting to give up, and it seemed like the answer to a prayer. When Ashley spoke with her former supervisor, David, he said that the school was very keen on hiring us. And the principal wanted to meet us on a Sabbath to assess our character. Scary, okay, and at first I didn’t like the idea of going to Daejeon on Sabbath, but I later reasoned, They want us to go to church with them and meet them; it’s not an interview.

That thought seemed confirmed when we received a call from the school. A Korean woman then interviewed us, without warning, over the phone. She seemed very excited at our interest in their school, as they have seventeen foreign teachers, and only one of them is Adventist. I asked her if the others were at least Christian, and she said no. I was quite surprised. Usually Adventist institutions are quite selective in that regard.

David also told us that the school was worried that we would change our minds once we saw the school. So they really seemed to want to hire us, even though we don’t have experience teaching subjects other than English and I have no elementary education experience. Our Adventist background seemed to be working in our favor.

Our faith also seemed to be in our favor, in a way. We said to each other that despite our lack of experience, if God wanted us to have this job, He would give us the ability, if not immediately then, at least, over time. We also decided that if we were not offered the job, then it would definitely be God’s choice. We felt good about either outcome.

The interview had already taken place and they still wanted us to go meet them, so things seemed quite positive. So we went to Daejeon, and we met the staff of the school. One staff member, Stephen, showed us around the school before church started. Then we went to church, and then, finally, we went to the school cafeteria to eat lunch with everyone. A few teachers who sat with us started to ask us some questions. It seemed quite alright at first, like mere conversation. “Oh, how long have you been in Korea?”, “Where are you from?” and so on. The principal came, too, and he asked us some questions. Eventually they called some other teachers over and we realized, as the questions turned into, “What are your strengths as a teacher?” that this was an interview.

Even when lunch was over, the principal made a prayer to “end the interview.” Then Stephen took us back to the train station. Wow, I thought, just wow. Ashley told me later that they were surprised that we showed up for church, that they only expected to meet us afterward. Which means that they had only wanted us to come to interview us. Which they had already done on the phone. I wondered if they had even spoken with the woman who called us.

Anyway, I started to wonder if we would get hired. On one hand, the principal had showed concern over my lack of smiling during the sermon. (In Korea, there’s a prejudice for foreigners who smile. They think that foreigners who don’t smile 24/7 won’t win the students’ trust or affection, which isn’t quite true. My students love me, and I don’t smile 24/7. I also learned to smile more as time went on. In any case, when he expressed this concern, I mentioned it was because I was concentrating on listening to the sermon, which was in Korean, and translating what little of it I could. I didn’t mention that Stephen was also translating it, but only parts of it that he was able to, so that I had to listen to him once every third or fourth sentence that he would translate. I said that I could smile more often. I even smiled quite a bit during lunch and while Stephen was showing us the school.) On the other hand, the principal’s prayer (which was translated by one of the English teachers) ended with something like, “and I hope we get to work together.”

As it turns out, by “we” he must have meant “Ashley and our school.” We got news a few days later that they wanted to hire Ashley but not me. David said that Stephen argued vehemently in our favor, but that some other teacher didn’t like me. The school thought I was too nervous (which I didn’t really feel nervous at all, but I guess not smiling equals afraid). In any case, Ashley told them that she wouldn’t accept their offer. Daejeon is smaller than Busan. If it seemed difficult for us to have me working in Busan and hope Ashley could find a job, the chances were to be much slimmer in Daejeon. In any case, we accepted this news as God’s will, although we were, I admit, quite sad the day we found out the news. The details of our situation, some of which are not included in this post because of length (and the inability to translate certain thoughts into words without a great effort that I wish at the moment not to expend), convinced us that the Daejeon decision would be God’s decision for us regarding employment in Korea this year (after all, if He had wanted us to stay, we would have been hired; I suppose it’s also still possible that we get a job here, and one given by God’s will, because nothing is impossible, but we must first visit our families).

While all of this was happening, we were trying to figure out our plan of action regarding coming to America. If we had landed the job, we would have visited for about two weeks in the States during our vacation, which is going on right now. If not, we would simply wait until the end of our contracts to see our families. This interview happened just a bit over a week before our vacation started, so we were looking at some very last-minute flight possibilities. As it turned out, we didn’t need those flights after all.

So we spent our vacation as mentioned in the previous post, and within a few days of February 25, we’ll be, Lord willing, on a plane to LAX.

See you soon.

PS: One of the teachers at my school, who talks to me frequently in order to practice her English skills, told me that this year, unlike other years, the student evaluations for teachers were unusually low, that it seemed that a considerable number of students simply rated all the teachers low. She said, “My score is low. My heart is broken.” So I wonder if, had that not happened, I would have had a better score. Not that it matters, but I was quite interested to learn this detail a few weeks ago.

A few years ago I heard a joke that I really appreciate. I think of it often. It goes like this: A rabbi in Russia was walking downtown toward the synagogue. A Cossack soldier asked him where he was going, to tease him. The rabbi replied, “I don’t know.” The soldier thought it was funny and chalked it up to the rabbi being some silly old Jew, but then it kept happening. Every time he would ask the rabbi where he was going, he would say, “I don’t know,” and then proceed to the synagogue. Finally, he’d had enough. The rabbi one last time answered, “I don’t know,” and the soldier yelled, “Every day you go to the synagogue, for years now. And every day I ask you where you’re going, you say you don’t know. How can you not know?” Filled with anger, the soldier grabbed the rabbi and dragged him to the prison. Where the rabbi said, “I told you I didn’t know.”

Two weeks ago, I wrote about the events that ultimately led us to the moment wherein we had to realize that we would be going back home a little earlier than we had expected. I must eat my words. Ashley and I will continue to work in Korea.

We’d been quite calm.  In my previous post, I mentioned that we were trying to see what happened as God’s will, or, in the least, I should add, that even if your own plans don’t happen, life goes on and in the end, none of it will matter by comparison.

That being said, on Friday, I said goodbye to my students and co-workers. Korean teachers change schools every four or five years, so on Friday, a half-day of school, all of the teachers who are leaving appeared on stage in the school’s auditorium so that they could all bow to the students and the students could cheer them on for their new schools. As an exiting teacher, I was included in that ceremony. Afterward, teachers packed things up and went home. There is no more school until March 2, when the new school year begins, but foreign teachers usually have to stay. Thus, I would be coming back to school, but my students and co-workers would not.*

And I’ll admit it. Once I got back to my apartment I broke down. I was excited to come home, to see my family and friends, to be in my own country, but I just said goodbye to one of the most significant years of my life (I’m not insulting my other years at all or diminishing the importance of them and the people who populated them; I merely mean that I changed a lot in Korea, and even without that, I’d say spending a year on the other side of the globe after living for nearly 25 years in one little pinpoint of it is rather significant).

Shortly thereafter, I received a message from Ashley. She wanted us to pray for a place to live (which would mean finding jobs as well), and over the days she had been stressing the importance of praying for jobs themselves (not just any jobs, as those are everywhere in Korea, but a workplace where we would be needed, and appreciated). I think lately that we’ve learned a bit more about what trusting God means, and how to live without anxiety, as Jesus commands (it’s still a struggle, of course, but I have more hope these days). Nonetheless, we didn’t know what we’d be doing once we returned to America. We had plans for a few interviews and applications, but you never know how long that might last. Some people live that life for months or even years. I wanted to go home and relax and enjoy my time with people. I didn’t want to have to go home and then look for a job. I didn’t know which scenario would have been worse: to get home and be jobless for several months or to get home and land a job that would require immediate relocation, thus preventing me from spending much time with my family. This is not even to mention the thought that finally occurred to me a few weeks ago: what about health insurance? We have it now, but once we go return to America….

So I prayed. I can’t remember what I said, but I do feel that I put more faith into it than many other prayers. It’s something I’ve been learning lately. Sometimes, an effective prayer almost feels like a gamble, except one where the entire roulette wheel is full of one number. Sometimes, you know it’s not your number, and then the prayer almost feels meaningless, but sometimes…sometimes it’s your number. But I can’t boast. Perhaps only in hindsight I feel like I had faith then. Perhaps I wasn’t faithful, but God was.

So we both prayed, I at home and she at work. Perhaps one hour later, or even less, Ashley sent me a message. David, her supervisor from her days as an online English tutor for Korean students, told her that a school was interested in potentially hiring us.

At first, to be honest, we were kind of upset. We had decided to come home. We had even purchased our plane tickets. And, in fact, we had even turned down a last-minute interview request that he had mentioned a couple of weeks ago, so he knew (or should have known) that we didn’t want to hear any of it. (We turned down the interview because, for one, Ashley’s foot was in quite some pain. It’s better now, but also at that time, we were on a two-day trip to Seoul and had already passed our window for visiting America. If we started another school year, we wouldn’t get to visit our families first, and we really needed to do that.)

Nonetheless, our job-seeker profiles were adrift in cyberspace and David continued to field the calls, never presuming that we were not interested, whatever Ashley told him. This time, Ashley told him that we had already purchased tickets and that we weren’t interested. A few minutes later he sent a text, “I’m sorry that I did it without your permission, but I gave your number to the vice principal.”

What?!

So the school called her. It was a school that had had a vacancy for one teacher before, but due to a sudden occurrence, another teacher had to leave, so the school now needed two teachers. Ashley told them right away that we had already booked our tickets and planned on going home.

“Oh, well that’s okay. We’re flexible. You can start at the end of March.”

What?!

The school is 서해삼육초등학교 (Seohae Sahmyook Elementary School; Seohae means “western sea” and is the Korean name for the Yellow Sea), so it’s run by Adventists, just as the school in Daejeon is. The person who called Ashley this time, though, was not an English-fluent Korean. He was Canadian, and he’s the head English teacher. He understood our desire to go home first and supported it, having himself benefited from the same process.

So Ashley and I discussed it together and agreed to visit the school and the town on Sunday, just to check it out and see. Mr. Anderson told us that if we liked it, he would inform the vice-principal and principal, and they would decide if they would be willing to accommodate our need to go home. He told us to stand our ground if the vice-principal, who would also meet us, asked us to cancel our tickets and allow the school to reimburse us.

We visited the town, which is quite small. It takes over three hours on two trains to get there, and there are only a handful of buildings with more than two or three stories.

Reminds me of home.

It’s bigger than that, of course, and the schools are very nice. That was just a photo I took quickly before we got on the train to go back to Busan. Sometimes, while riding the train, I see little farming communities with houses and stores spread far apart, and I was afraid Gwangcheon would be like that. As it turns out, everything is comfortably spaced, and the train station is even just 10 or 15 minutes by foot from the apartment, so it’s not too much of a burden to hop on the train and pay two bucks to go into the city.

The school was very nice. Mr. Anderson and his wife (who is Korean) and daughter (of whom I am jealous, as she’s bilingual) showed us around and explained a few things. They even showed us the apartment we’d be staying in if we got the job. It’s a bit smaller than our current apartment, but we don’t need as much space. It’s also newer. And it’s in walking distance from the school.

We asked a few questions, including when their summer vacation began. Since my sister’s getting married at the end of July, it is important for us to be able to go back home at the right time, especially because my sister was already expecting us to be in America once we had “decided” to come back home. Mr. Anderson told us, “July 20 to August 13.” All I needed to know was that July 28 is right in the middle of that, so there wasn’t even need to ask if we would be able to take a few days off of work.

The vice-principal, Mr. Moon, came by and met us. For a moment, it seemed like he was going to ask us to give a lesson demonstration (actually, he did ask us). We weren’t warned of that, and Mr. Anderson and his wife were kind of shocked. How can you do a lesson demonstration with no students and no preparation? After a few minutes, he relented. Perhaps we should have just stood up and started talking about…ummm…Idunnowhat, but we also kept in mind that, hey, not getting this job is not the end of the world.

He did ask us to consider canceling our trip home, but we stayed firm. We had already told our families, and we couldn’t so easily back out on our word. Mr. Anderson, I guess, told Ashley that he would probably be like that just to cover his own tracks, knowing that the school needs two teachers, but also having to at least try negotiation.

So Mr. Anderson gave us a copy of his own contract as a reference and asked us to let him know by the next morning (today) our decision. If we said yes, the vice-principal and the principal would then have the decision, if letting us come a month late would be too much. (The VP also asked if one of us could stay, as one of the teacher’s we’re replacing isn’t actually leaving until March 25, so one of us could come late without any worry. But we declined. If it was to be a problem, then okay, we’ll just go home.)

We were feeling hungry so Mr. Moon drove us to a restaurant (and dashed away after telling the owners that he would pay the bill). So we had a bite to eat with Mr. Anderson and his wife and daughter before heading back home, and that was the best 육개장 (spicy beef stew) that I ever had. I think that may have been when I decided I wanted to move to Gwangcheon.

Gwangcheon is here, by the way.

So we got on the train and, while we were waiting during our transfer, we called and said that, if the vice-principal and principal agreed, we would work at the school. Then we finished our journey home. Hoping and praying that God’s will would be “Yes.” Just two days before this, we had expected to go home.

As I stepped off the bus to go to work today, I got a phone call from Mr. Anderson. And we’ll be returning to Korea after a few weeks of rest back home in America. I’m excited and a bit nervous. As I said before, I don’t have elementary education experience, and this school, just like the one in Daejeon (although different in some ways I appreciate), is an English immersion school. We’ll be teaching subjects like science and social studies and language arts all in English. It’ll be different from our experience as “guest English teachers.” So we hope, with God’s grace, to learn quickly.

So it’s very shocking to us, that suddenly we will be coming back to Korea. In my previous post, I almost made it seem like God didn’t want us to stay in Korea, at least for the moment. I did, however, say that I couldn’t know God’s will. I said, “I suppose it’s also still possible that we get a job here, and one given by God’s will, because nothing is impossible, but we must first visit our families.” And that’s exactly what’s going on.

Everything seemed so perfect. At first, I didn’t like the idea of moving to a small town, but once I was there, I liked it. There’s a mountain nearby for hiking and a river. Walking to work means more exercise. Fewer western restaurants (okay, no western restaurants) means cooking more often and saving more money. Less city means less pollution. Living in a place with fewer foreigners means I should be forced to speak more Korean. The offer resulted from persistence beyond our control and it came after heartfelt prayer. The vacation time is perfect for our needs, and the school is accommodating our condition. We wanted to stay in Korea and learn more Korean, and spend more time abroad before settling down. Ashley’s mom had also wanted to visit us in Korea, and now she still has that opportunity (if she wants), to experience a new country with family who are familiar enough to be comfortable guides. Ashley has been quoting this verse for the last few weeks, and I think it applies here: “The blessing of the LORD, it maketh rich, and he addeth no sorrow with it” (Proverbs 10:22 KJV). The only question that remains is, Can we do this job? It’s a question that you have to ask yourself about any job, though, and I think the answer will be, Yes. Even if it takes some persistence and patience.

*And I did come back to school today, on Monday. At one point, I noticed that one of my co-workers was online on the school’s message system. She’s not an English teacher, but she enjoys talking with me and practicing her English sometimes. On Friday, I think my longest conversation was with her, when we talked about our respective plans for the future, and she called me her friend. So I went downstairs to say hi and saw also a few other teachers and the principal. We all sat down together and shared a big pastry. So I have this week off. I’ll go in for my final week next week, and then I’m coming home for a good, stress-free (i.e., without running around doing interviews and filling out job applications) visit.

Next month we’re moving to Gwangcheon. It’s northwest of Busan. We’ll no longer be living near 129 degrees east, but instead about 126 and a half. I don’t like the sound of 126andahalfdegreeseast, do you? Hmmm, conundrum…

Brian and I had to go up to Gwangcheon to get all the immigration stuff sorted (Yay! Now, our work visas are all in order!). We had to go up separately since Brian had Thursday off, and I didn’t. I wasn’t too keen on making the whole 7 hour round trip alone, so Brian stayed in Gwangcheon after signing his contract and completing the visa process, and I took Friday off and made my way to Gwangcheon after work on Thursday afternoon. I planned to do all the paperwork on Friday morning and then Brian and I would head back to Busan together.

To make things easier, we spent a night in our soon-to-be apartment. We took some pictures to show you what the new place looks like:

This slideshow requires JavaScript.

It’s smaller than the apartment we’ve had for the past year, but that’s fine. We have a small extra room in the apartment here in Busan, but we don’t go in there enough to even bother to heat it in the winter.

Seven, to be precise. We leave in one week. As I write this sentence, it is 12:45 in the afternoon on Sunday, February 19. Our flight is at 2:00 on February 26, so we leave one week, one hour, and fourteen minutes from now (the time changed to 12:46 mid-sentence).

I’m excited. Home feels like so long ago. I wonder how it will feel to be on American soil after more than a year. To see signs, all of them, in English. To use bills that have “United States of America” stamped on them. To understand all of the various conversations happening around me in public places (and having to work a little harder to tune them out). To greet my family and friends with hugs and handshakes rather than Facebook chat bloops.

We’ve got lots to do and so little time (at home). We also have lots of time and little to do (at work). I have five days of work yet, and as far as I know, I have no duties other than to be there. At home, though, we have to get ready. We need to pack up our stuff by Wednesday night, because on Thursday, Ashley’s school is sending a cleaning company to clean our apartment for the next tenants. On Friday (which is our final payday), I have to leave work a little bit early so I can go to the bank and close my account. I have two bank accounts in Korea. EPIK opened accounts for us all with Korea Exchange Bank when we first came, but my school does business through Busan Bank. I won’t be living in Busan, so I’m going to close that account. Sometime on Saturday the gas company is coming to shut off our gas (Ashley’s school is trying to get them to come as late in the day as possible so that we won’t be cold). Then we’ll get on two planes. The first, a two-hour flight operated by Japan Airlines, to Tokyo. We’ll wait there for almost three hours, and then we’ll board a flight by Singapore Airlines, lasting ten hours, to Los Angeles. The reviews for both airlines are extremely high. We’ll arrive at 11:50 am, two hours and ten minutes before we left. I plan to call myself in Korea with the lottery numbers.

Thirteen days later, the day after my own birthday, we’re boarding a flight by Korean Air, another very popular airline, to go to Incheon International Airport near Seoul. After taking a bus to Seosan, someone from our school is loading us and our stuff up in a van and taking us to Gwangcheon.

I am really looking forward to those twenty-five days. See you soon!

Right now, it’s 9:20 am (at the time of posting), Pacific Standard Time, because I’m no longer in Korea. I’m in Hesperia, California, for the next 12 days. We left Busan yesterday at 2:00 pm, when it was nine at night on Saturday in California. We boarded a plane and spent the next 16 and a half hours traveling to the United States.

Our last night in Busan was spent with our closest Korea-made friends: Stephen, Brian and Kathleen (a married couple), and Laurent, a Frenchman who’s been in Korea for 15 years. We ate burritos at Brian and Kathleen’s apartment, played Apples to Apples, and sang some songs at noraebang (again, that’s karaoke, except you only have to sing in front of your friends instead of the entire crowd). It was a great night, in my humble opinion. We actually spent quite some time with these friends in the last couple of weeks, always saying goodbye, just in case, only for one of us to arrange another get-together at a Korean barbecue establishment or on a mountain trail.

At the end of it, we went home and finished packing. We had packed most of our stuff three days earlier, because an administrator from Ashley’s school came by to check our apartment (for damage and to make sure the supplies given to us were still there) on Thursday while we were at work.

We went to sleep and packed the rest of our stuff, the things we used right up to the last moment (such as our computers, toothbrushes, and last change of clothes), and cleaned the apartment to a decent, presentable status. At 9:20 (although he said to expect him between 9:30 and 10:00), Mr. Lee—the head English teacher of my school, who considers himself our angel in Korea and assigns himself missions to help us—rung our doorbell. I picked up the intercom and said, “여보세요?” (the standard greeting for when you answer a phone). Mr. Lee didn’t respond; I merely saw him, on the screen, look around. Ashley answered the door and he greeted us happily, explaining that he heard me say “여보세요?” and for a moment was embarrassed, thinking that I was Korean and that he had gone to the wrong apartment.

We carried our stuff to his car and loaded it all in. We gave one box of stuff to Mr. Lee, who offered to keep at his apartment anything we knew we wanted to keep in Korea, so that he could ship it to us when we return. (He is one of the most thoughtful people I met in Korea.) I went to the security guard’s office and gave him the keys, telling him “이백육호” (number 206) so that Ashley’s school could retrieve them for the next tenants.

Then Mr. Lee’s son drove us all to the airport, about a 20-minute drive from our apartment (Mr. Lee himself never got a license). We gathered our things and said goodbye to Mr. Lee, thanking him for his year of great kindness. Then we went to check in at the airport.

And apparently we were very early. Our flight was at 2:00, and we arrived four hours before that. Our flight was purchased through Korean Air, but operated by Japan Airlines. We couldn’t find any desk open for Japan Airlines, so we asked someone at Korean Air. She told us that we would have to go to Japan Airlines, who would open at 11:50. So we had to do some waiting. While we waited, I exchanged some of our Korean won to United States dollars. Ashley was excited when I gave her some Benjamins.

When I exchanged the money, I handed the woman most of my Korean cash and asked for American currency. We’re keeping some Korean money not only to show it to people back home, but also so that we’ll have some when we return. The exchange clerk counted my money and then calculated the exchange. Next, she merely pulled bills from a box that sat on the desk in front of her. A box which had no lid. A box on the counter just feet from me. If I had had the nerve, I could have reached that box and grabbed a fistful of 100-dollar bills. I suppose few people would have such nerve, though; you wouldn’t get very far.

Right before exchanging the money, I saw Stephen. He was on his way to check in and would come back and say goodbye to us when he was done. Later he did come back, explaining that he now knew why his plane ticket was so cheap (other than what he had already learned from Internet reviews, that Air China is a thoroughly terrible airline): he had to pay 200 dollars for an 11-kilogram bag. I think the charge resulted because, while most airlines allow one carry-on luggage piece plus one “personal item,” including a small backpack, Air China considered that to be two pieces.

So we said our goodbyes again and Stephen went through security. We still had some time to wait. When it was time to check in, we approached the desk, and the clerk took our printed itinerary so she could check our bags and give us our boarding passes. For a few minutes, we were afraid. She couldn’t pull up our second flight, from Tokyo to LA. Finally she managed to at least ensure our bags were on that flight, so that we wouldn’t have to retrieve them and then check them again, and explained that, because our second flight was through a different airline, it seemed we would have to get our boarding passes at the next airport.

So then we went through security. It took two minutes. We still had quite a wait, of course, and at one point I saw Stephen (again) because his flight had been delayed by about 15 minutes.

Eventually, we got on our first flight, Japan Airlines to Tokyo. It was scheduled as 2:00 to 4:00 (with Tokyo in the same time zone as Korea), yet the flight lasted only until maybe 3:30. The captain had even announced at the beginning of the flight that he expected it to last an hour and a half. A similar bit of time-saving occurred on our next flight, too, because that ten-hour flight was announced by the pilot as nine hours (and he was pretty accurate).

That first plane was kind of small, so I wasn’t exactly comfortable, but the flight was short. Despite the flight’s brevity, they served us a meal. It wasn’t anything at all big, but it was definitely more than a pack of peanuts.

Then we got to Tokyo, where we went to go to our connecting flight. We saw a sign saying we needed our boarding pass to go through security. We showed our itinerary to the woman, who showed it to someone else, and they let us go through (after all, the print-out clearly showed that we had purchased a ticket). We went through security and then learned that our flight was coming from Terminal 1. We were in Terminal 2, so we had to go downstairs and get on a bus to go to Terminal 1. Even once we got to Terminal 1, we had a long walk to take to get to our gate. We were glad that we had eschewed a flight with a one-hour layover for one with almost three hours of waiting (a one-hour layover is my ideal layover time for domestic flights in America, not international flights between two different airlines overseas). We finally found the desk for connecting flights and got our boarding passes, and then waited. I think I fell asleep for fifteen minutes or so.

Finally we boarded our plane, which was incredible. It felt roomier than the Japan Airlines plane (not that Japan Airlines isn’t any good, but it was a small plane for short flights). Ashley had a window seat, and the window was, I would say, almost a foot from her face, because the wall curved away from the seat to give passengers a bit more room. I noticed that the overheard storage bins were curved into the wall very nicely, as well, which was especially nice for the middle row of seats. I’ve been on planes before where the overhead bins over the middle seats simply come down as one big box from the ceiling, so turbulence makes it shake. On this plane, it was shaped to be more seamless with the ceiling, and I never once heard it shake.

We each had our own TV screen with a remote control for selecting any of the various options we had: a library of movies, TV shows, music albums, radio stations, e-books, audio books, and games. I was excited because there were movies in several languages, including Korean movies with English subtitles. So I watched two Korean movies: 오직 그대만 (the English title was “Always” although I think “오직 그대만” means “only you”) and 완득이 (titled in English as “Punch” even though the Korean title is simply the main character’s name).

I also liked that flight because they gave us some socks. We could wear them, if we wanted, so that we could take off our shoes while wearing fresh socks, to let our feet breathe and not have well-traveled, smelly socks offending our noses or those of our neighbors.

Finally the plane landed. We got off the plane, walked a long way to US Customs, and made our way through that. The flight attendants on our plane had announced that US citizens did not need to fill out a customs form, but I think they must have been mistaken. We did had to fill one out, so we did, but it was easy. I just wrote my name, birthdate, country of travel, then checked “No” a few times and signed my name. Well, I did also write that we were bringing some tea and clothes that were purchased abroad, but that would have ruined the flow of my previous sentence, and even that was accomplished in ten seconds.

After customs, we retrieved our luggage and made our way to the world outside the airport. We don’t have cell phones in America, so I had to go get some change for a pay phone so that Ashley could call her mom and tell her we were here. We went outside, waited a few minutes, and then there were Ashley’s mom and sister. We crammed our stuff into the car and then made our way to Ashley’s grandparents’ house, where we visited and ate our first meal in America: pasta, salad, and some amazing raisin bread.

Then, I fell asleep.

어제 저녁에 우리가 한국에 돌아왔어요. Yesterday evening, we returned to Korea.

I don’t know how I feel about that right now. When I first found out that we would be leaving Busan, I was upset. Then I looked forward to being back in America. Then, as our time in Korea drew to a close, I started feeling sad. Then we got new jobs and I was excited to come back, only to go home to America and realize I didn’t want to leave. Then I got on a plane and couldn’t wait to be back in Korea. Then the plane landed in Korea and I wondered, “What am I doing here?”

So kind of like this.

Perhaps it’s only because in two days I’ll be at a new job, and right now I don’t know what I’m going to do when I get there. Perhaps the undercurrent of anxiety is driving my thoughts on the subject, but I briefly wonder, “Did we make the right choice?” If you read my last few blogs, you’ll see that prayer and faith played a big part in our decision to return to Korea, but last night on the bus from Incheon International Airport to Seosan, where our school picked us up to take us to Gwangcheon, I wondered, “What if all of the stuff that seemed like perfect puzzle pieces falling into place was just to see if we would decide to take a leap of faith in America, and now we’ve chosen our downfall?”

Well, I sure hope not. Now that I’ve written that out, I hear how ridiculous and paranoid it sounds. But I did realize over the last few days that one reason for wanting to stay in Korea—to learn more Korean—turned out not to be so important after all. In America, I don’t need to know Korean. Another reason I wanted to come back was Korean food. But you know what? I survived for almost a month without any Korean food. (Initially I planned on making some Korean food or going to the Korean restaurant and speaking Korean, but I never got around to any of that. Although there were a few times when I thought, “I feel in the mood for some naengmyeon or some doenjang jjigae.”)

Finally, some of my favorite aspects about living in Korea were specific to Busan. For one, the transportation system in Busan is excellent. However, we won’t need it here, so that’s a neutral point. There aren’t as many restaurants and stores in Gwangcheon, but we’ll manage. What I refer to the most are the friends we made in Busan. In the last few months especially, we made some good friends in Korea. We went hiking with these people. We went to Korean barbecue together. We went to noraebang and sang songs. We went to the apartment of two of them (the married couple we befriended) and ate burritos. One of those friends left Korea when we did, so he’s back in California now. A few of those friends are still in Korea, but they’re in Busan. So now we’ve left our friends back home to come to Korea, but our friends in Korea are also far, far away. We also have friends we know both from home and in Korea, but they are also far away.

So if we left two groups of friends to come to Gwangcheon, and if we can survive without eating or speaking Korean, why did we come back?

I think I may have had similar thoughts in my mind when I first came to Korea. It was so long ago, though, so I don’t remember. I remember of my first months in Korea feeling very glad. But what about those first few days? Didn’t I sit in the taxi on the way from the airport, looking out at the foreign streets and buildings, wondering to myself, “Wow. I’m in another country. I’m in Asia. And I’ve come to live here. This is…weird. What are we doing? Why did we come here?”

So now I’m thinking similar thoughts and asking myself similar questions. I think I will have to rediscover the answers for myself as time goes by.

And I think those answers will be worthwhile.

—–
