In the spring of 2008, I took a contemporary poetry course at Andrews University taught by Dr. Scott Moncrieff. During the class we sampled different forms of poetry and read works from several poets. We also experimented with and shared our own poetry. That spring was when I wrote my first villanelle (I think it ended up being published in a poetry textbook somewhere).

Now–though I’m constantly scribbling snippets of (awful) free verse poetry–whenever I sit down to write a formal poem, I find myself trying to compose a villanelle. It’s a form that’s both challenging and fun, and writing helps to clear the head sometimes. Especially if you’re like me.

This particular poem expresses some of my thoughts about our new (tiny) home in small-town South Korea. I hope you enjoy reading it.

 

The things I like about this place:

4 white plates and 1 kitchen sink–

There’s less to clean in a smaller space.

 

Two sets of sliding doors bring grace

and wooden floors add charm, I think.

The things I like about this place

 

must not exclude the slower pace

of towns that lack sour sewer-stink.

(There’s less to clean in a smaller space).

 

Fat clouds in a fresh sky replace

tall, jumbled buildings that would shrink

the things I like about this place.

 

Inside it’s cozy, in any case,

a few cute mugs for our hot drinks…

There’s less to clean in a smaller space,

 

which brings a half-smile to my face–

I must be idler than I think;

The thing I like about this place:

There’s less to clean in a smaller space.

On the rooftop of our building, nothing blocks the view. Our small living-space is almost directly below my feet.

A few days ago I posted about feeling concerned about returning to Korea. I haven’t been back for even a week, but I think I can say that it was unnecessary. The concerns, I mean.

I know you haven’t heard much from us. I apologize for that. I haven’t posted anything here, I haven’t sent out e-mails, and I haven’t even been on Facebook very much to let people know that I’m still alive. In fact, if I don’t get on Facebook tomorrow while at work, I can claim that I didn’t use it on the job during my first week at all. I suppose today I finally had the opportunity, but instead I took a walk in the hallways and made a vocabulary PowerPoint for the next unit in science class.

The similarities between my previous job and my current one are not endless, not at all. In Busan, I lived in a city and worked in a girls’ high school, seeing, in a week, 20 classes of between 30 and 40 students (most under 35, though) and teaching only English conversation with very little structure and a truck load of free time I could have spent making better lessons. I wasn’t proud of my performance there. I had plans for improving it (mostly by coordinating more with the Korean teachers and spending more time and care on each lesson), but you know the story.

Now, in Gwangcheon, I live in a small town and teach at an elementary school. I have 24 classes, with 18 students in my largest class and eight in my smallest. Yes, I teach English conversation (one class of second and third graders, and one class of fourth and fifth graders), but I also teach language arts (one class of third graders and one of fourth graders) and science (one of fourth graders and one of fourth graders). Then there’s an after school program I have with eight third graders. Some of the other teachers have called the after school classes “glorified babysitting,” but we still learn English.

In Busan, I was the only foreign teacher. Here, there are six of us, and one of the others is married to a Korean who lived with him in Canada for several years. She speaks fluent English. There’s no shortage of conversation partners. Of course, I kind of miss talking to Koreans (especially a few specific teachers at my old school). There’s something inherently different about speaking with a Korean and with a fellow foreigner. I think part of it is the bit of informational cultural exchange that can happen in such a conversation.

In Busan, I had to leave my apartment around 7:30 and take the bus to work, then arrive back at my apartment around 5:20, give or take. In Gwangcheon, I can leave the apartment around 8:10 and get home by 4:40 (if I leave right away), all by walking for about ten minutes. Probably a bit less, even.

In Busan, I had a job that is called, by many who hold the same position, “not real teaching.” Perhaps some of the materials our students are learning is a bit watered down for their grade level (considering the language barrier), but we’re still very much teachers here. We take attendance, give grades (in EPIK at the public schools, students generally don’t earn grades for the foreigners’ classes), and teach numerous unique lessons each week. All of that made me wonder if I was up for the job, but after four days on the job (one day spent in training, by watching other teachers teach my classes), I think that I made the right choice in coming to Gwangcheon. Things can change in the future, but I only think that it will improve. My elementary teaching skills will be refined (plus I’ll become even more familiar with the setup of this school and the way things work).

I’ve really been hard at work. On Monday, Ashley and I watched the other foreign teachers teach our classes. Starting Tuesday, we taught on our own (except those classes that don’t meet on Mondays; those we observed, so that each class had one observation/training period first). With getting adjusted to the school, figuring out the system, and dealing with classes, we haven’t had lots of time to do whatever we wanted. Being newly arrived (with jet-lag lasting until we started work) also means we’re still slowly stocking our fridge and cupboards (we don’t have a car, which means I’ve been making one or two trips each day to the supermarket ten minutes away to either stock our cupboards or to make that night’s supper). Added all together, it made us quite tired. Most of this week, we’ve been going to bed around 9 pm, give or take an hour, and waking up between 5 and 6 am. That means going to bed three-to-five hours earlier than normal and waking up an hour, give or take, earlier as well. It also means that we came home, went to the store, made supper, washed the dishes, then had a very small bit of down time before giving in to sleep.

And I kind of like it. The Bible says, “The sleep of a labouring man is sweet, whether he eat little or much: but the abundance of the rich will not suffer him to sleep” (Ecclesiastes 5:12 KJV). My labor certainly is more in quantity than it has been for most of the last year, and the sleep indeed is sweet. There’s something nice about going to bed at nine, not too long after dark has arrived, and waking up to see it off. As we get adjusted to our jobs, I’m sure that this won’t last, but for the moment I’m enjoying it. I previously had some concern about what we would do in such a small place like Gwangcheon, but that concern is unfounded, at least for now. We have no time for wondering what to do. We wake up, go to work, come home, and go to bed. It is a simple life, and one not so quickly desired for trade.

On February 26, Ashley and I left Korea for the first time since we had arrived in the country. On March 22, we again left Michigan for our other peninsular home. This post is the first of two about what happened between those two days. I’ll try to be brief.

We arrived late in the morning on Sunday, February 26. We had left early in the afternoon on February 26, making February 26, 2012, officially the longest day of my life. We made it through customs quite easily and had no problem claiming our luggage. The problem we did have was that, having lived outside of the country for a year, we had no cell phones. At the airport in Busan, I had exchanged some money so that we would have some before finding ATMs (and good thing, too: we had been sent new ATM cards, and to make a long story short, we didn’t know our PINs). However, I was given mostly Benjamins. I also had a ten. Thus I had to make change with the ten so that Ashley could call her mother from a pay phone to let her know that we had arrived. A few minutes later, we met Ashley’s mom and sister. The hurry of airport pick-ups, though, kept our reunion effectively to, “Hi there! Let’s get this luggage in the car, eh?”

We went from LAX to Ashley’s grandparents’ house in Pasadena. We caught up with Ashley’s grandparents and cousins before having lunch and crashing (at least, I crashed, so I remember nothing that happened afterward until we got back in the car and went the rest of the way to Hesperia).

Normally when we would visit Ashley’s family, we would be with a large group. There would be siblings, cousins, sometimes aunts and uncles. This time, however, there were Ashley’s mother and sister. Her sister, this time, had a job.

It meant that Ashley and I would be alone for part of the day. It was decided, therefore, that we should rent a car. Fortunately, Ashley’s sister went to work in the afternoon, so she took us to the car rental place in the morning and dropped us off there.

We entered the shop and, after the clerk asked us for a credit card, we realized that we didn’t have one. I had a debit card, but there was a set of extra regulations and stipulations for using those. We needed to go back home to retrieve Ashley’s purse.

Now remember two things: we had no American cell phone, and Ashley’s sister had dropped us off.

Thus began the adventure of walking to a nearby gas station to make change, using their faulty payphone, and then finding a better payphone and finally calling Ashley’s sister to bring the purse. And to wait for us. Just in case.

We had a rental car, so we figured we should use it. On Wednesday we went to the Devil’s Punchbowl.

Seen here.

That trip was about an hour from Hesperia. The next day, we screwed up our courage and drove four hours to…

Death Valley is one of the most beautiful, one of the most inspiring, one of the most worth-a-four-hour-drive-and-a-nearly-six-dollar-gas-price places I’ve ever been to.

Five eighty-seven. Plus 9/10ths of a cent.

I had often wanted to visit Death Valley, mostly because of a few pictures I had seen of the night sky. There’s hardly any light pollution at all, so the stars abound. As for the daytime Death Valley, what would be there to see except a bunch of dirt-tan dryness?

It turned out to be the opposite. Our night sky was a bit of a disappointment, because the moon was more than half full. Next time we go, we’ll have to schedule on a new moon night, when the moon won’t outshine the stars. However, we still saw dozens, perhaps hundreds, more stars than we would see in Busan or even in Berrien Springs.

But the daytime Death Valley? I want to go back. I want to go back and take in even more of that beautiful, beautiful, beautiful place. I thought I would see monotonous, rusty terrain. I was wrong. Before we even got to Death Valley, I knew I was wrong. Google Maps showed the last hour and a half of the drive to be on a lonely desert road. What it didn’t show was how diverse the scenery would be on that drive. Every five or ten minutes, the terrain changed. I saw flat, brown desert. I saw small rocks and boulders. I saw desert bush. I saw a field of what I’m guessing was salt. I saw smooth, rocky hills, and I saw rough rocky hills. I saw mountains of several shades, patterns, and shapes.

And when we got to Death Valley proper, it all continued.

The next day, we drove another hour into the depths of Death Valley National Park to visit Scotty’s Castle. It was Ashley’s idea, and I wasn’t too keen on visiting it (“Why visit some random guy’s hundred-year-old house in the middle of the desert?”), but, again, I was wrong. Very wrong. Scotty’s Castle, with its innovations in its time period and location, and the very amusing story of its history, was yet another highlight of our amazing two-day visit to Death Valley.

Finally we drove back. It would have been a standard trip if a rock truck carrying talc hadn’t slammed into the back of another truck on Death Valley Road (CA-127). The road was blocked. Cars lined up by the dozens on a road where you pass another vehicle once every few miles. We stopped there about 50 minutes, learning, piece by piece, what kind of accident had taken place. The talc-loaded truck had failed brakes. Normally on such a deserted road, the driver would have switched to the left lane to pass the truck ahead. As it turned out, at that moment there actually was another vehicle, a small car, in the oncoming lane. Therefore, the driver opted to rear-end the next truck. The driver of the car thanked him for sparing his life. Fortunately, no one was killed, although I spent fifteen or so minutes believing there had been no survivors. “They said two trucks,” I thought. “I just see a few bits that could be part of one. No one could survive that.” But I was wrong. Apparently, it was just a case of the diesel fuel igniting and burning everything to gone.

In California, we also met Ashley’s high school friend, the mother of her godson. On our last evening in California, we visited her house and shared a meal. We also went together to the botanical gardens at University of California – Riverside, which is probably the nicest (and most comprehensive) botanical gardens I’ve been to. I don’t think we saw the whole thing.

Ashley’s grandparents also bought us tickets to a dance performance, which included a ballet performance plus a few contemporary acts. I wasn’t too interested in ballet, and I expected the event to be just okay. What have I said a few times already in this post? I was wrong. I had a ton of fun. I think it would have been impossible not to. The dancing was spectacular, the styles were varied, and at one point, the dancers grabbed audience members and pulled them onstage to join the fun. Including one old woman who appeared to have the time of her life on the stage and who, at one point, lost her wig.

So that, in a rather large nutshell, was California. In part two, I’ll write about our time in Michigan.

On February 26, Ashley and I left Korea for the first time since we had arrived in the country. On March 22, we again left Michigan for our other peninsular home. This post is the second of two about what happened between those two days. I’ll try to be brief.

We landed at O’Hare International Airport around 3:00 pm CST. The date was March 9, also known as my mom’s birthday. I don’t think I’m being too conceited when I say that my arrival was probably the best birthday present I’d ever given to her in my lifetime.

My parents came to O’Hare to pick us up. Our plan, originally, was to have an early dinner in Chicago, to celebrate Mom’s birthday and our return. Instead, we decided to get out of Chicago before rush hour hit. We could eat in Michigan City instead.

As it turned out, Michigan City was too far for our hungry stomachs. We stopped in Portage and had dinner at the Longhorn Steakhouse. We all ate steak, even Mom, who only eats steak at home.

During dinner, my Mom remarked that it felt like we had never left. I wonder why that is. I thought the same thing, and later, while meeting our friends, we made similar observations. I suppose that it’s just easier to pick up where you left off with people you’re close to.

When we got to my parents’ house—for almost 25 years I called it my house—we were met by an excited trio of nieces. Perhaps I exaggerated that. We have a trio of nieces, but one of them certainly wasn’t excited. Abigail was less than a year old when we left, so I think she simply wondered who we were.

The oldest one, though, run up to and jumped onto Ashley, holding onto her for probably a full two minutes before letting go. Kaylee missed us both a lot, but Ashley especially, I think because Ashley used to play with her more.

When we left, the middle one only spoke a few words and so I wasn’t sure how much she would remember us. But when we got home she spoke in full, sophisticated sentences and called me Uncle Brian and talked to us as if we had been there all along. So that was nice.

Ashley and I visited my grandfather for a couple of hours the next day and caught up with him, and later in the evening we saw our friends for the first time in over a year and went to a Japanese restaurant with them. We had also gone to a Japanese restaurant in California with Ashley’s mom and sister, an amazing all-you-can-eat buffet with quality food and a great price. There was no buffet at this place, but it was nonetheless fulfilling. And no, I didn’t eat a lot of Japanese food in Korea except for the few times we ate sushi, because Japanese food and Korean food aren’t really the same thing. Before moving to Korea, I had expected Korea and Japan to be similar and close, like friends. The actual relationship between the two countries, however, is not entirely jovial.

In California, we of course had experienced some jet lag, but after a day or two, I think it mostly went away and, while we had a hard time waking up in the morning (who doesn’t on vacation?) we mostly kept to a reasonable schedule. However, I think Daylight Savings Time was the straw that broke the camel’s back. We moved 17 hours back when going from Korea to California.Then we transferred to Michigan and jumped forward three hours and, two days later, one more hour forward. We got tired, so it took us a few days before finally making more rounds to see more people.

Finally we went to campus to meet people. We said hello to the folks at the bookstore and we made our rounds at the English Department, including a student-guided tour (i.e., by Serenity) of Buller Hall. It was nice to catch up and see everyone. Even though I’m sure my mom talked increasingly more and more about our return as it neared, the people at the bookstore still seemed shocked to see us. I guess the time can do that to a person. I guess it can also be a case of not knowing exactly when we’ll come marching in.

Which happened in its ultimate form when, after visiting a few professors at Nethery and going back to the bookstore for a few minutes, we returned to the English Department to seek out Dr. Pittman. We had stopped by her office once but had quickly deduced that she was busy with conferences. The timing was perfect. We walked into the building and were perhaps ten feet into the hallway when Dr. Pittman emerged from another room down the hall. She headed toward her own office, which put her facing us. I think it took her a good two or three steps before her vision focused on the two approaching persons down the hall. My memory is a bit hazy on the exact details, but I think she made some form of audiovisual exclamation.

In the end, we managed to meet with all the professors except Dr. Warren and Dr. Kim, though Dr. Kim joined the faculty as we were finishing our graduate studies, we never had a class with her, and she’s on leave. I think the familiarity is minimal in both directions.

We had sated our sight-seeing, adventure-going appetites in California, so we spent most of our time in Michigan simply hanging out with our friends and/or family and relaxing. This included a lot of playing with our nieces. In fact, one other reason, other than sleepiness, that it took a few days to make it to campus was that I hurt my shoulder playing with them. I should probably add Ashley’s godson to that. The day before we left, when we had visited Ashley’s friend, I played with Jayden, including swinging him around by his feet and whatnot. Just days later in Michigan, I pulled all three nieces on a blanket along the hardwood floor, and all three of them combined are rather heavy.

For a few hours, I was really worried. My mom thought it could have been the same problem she had with her shoulder, which required surgery. “Great,” I thought. “During the four weeks in which I have no medical insurance I need surgery.” As it turned out, according to a chiropractor, all it needed was ice and an over-the-counter anti-inflammatory (ibuprofen).

What else happened in Michigan? We went shopping with my parents, who bought us some stuff to help replenish our work-situation wardrobe (somehow I managed to destroy most of my slacks). We also had a family get-together on one Sunday, finally seeing everyone else we hadn’t had a chance to see until then. We played games, ate spaghetti, and had a general good time. And on our last day in Michigan, we had a small birthday party (for me, because that day was my birthday).

The next day, early in the morning, we started our trip back here, to Korea.

I have to say that my overall impression of being in America was, “This is weird.” When we landed at the airport in LA, I thought, “We’re in America! Whoa!” When we were in the car on our way to Pasadena, I thought, “Look at all these cars. They’re driven by Americans! And look at those street signs!” While we were driving through residential areas, I thought, “Look, no mammoth apartment buildings! This is so weird!” Eventually, I adjusted, but for a few days, and with brief, occasional episodes thereafter, I simply felt at a loss for words at my present location.

I also have to say that I think that this vacation, to America, to California and Michigan, was one of the best vacations I’ve been on, and it was vacation I spent, more or less, at home. Most people go away from home for vacation, but we went to it. (I suppose people who move away for college go home for vacation, but I didn’t have to do that, so I never had that experience until now.) It makes sense, though. It was this vacation wherein I saw the most people I care about, and it was a vacation that was actually and almost fully defined by the theme “relax.”

Yes, I definitely want to visit that place again.

We haven’t been much in contact lately. I put up two blogs, but that was old news. We’ve been nearly silent on our life in Gwangcheon, and we haven’t said much beyond this blog either.

We’re still getting adjusted, in some ways, although in some ways that’s not quite true. A better excuse is that I’ve been sick for more almost two weeks now. I almost called in sick the first day, but I didn’t. I woke up a few hours before work and by the time work started, I was feeling better. That’s how it is. I’m sickest in the mornings. In fact, for the last few days, I have barely felt sick, or have felt sick not at all, during the day, only to wake up the next morning with another sore throat. It’s not fun. I feel fine, but all day I have to remind myself that I am indeed sick, “So drink some tea, and stay away from those cookies.”

It’s good that I didn’t call in sick. Another foreign teacher did, so the rest of us had to fill in for his classes. I asked the head teacher what would happen if two people called in sick. He and I both had felt ill that day, but decided to come into work. He answered that the first to call would be lucky, and that the second to call, well, too bad. It would be too much to cover for two missing teachers, unless those teachers were genuinely very ill.

This last Friday marked three weeks since we’ve returned to Korea. It’s odd. I feel like I was here months ago. Maybe it’s because I was, and not just in Korea, but here in Gwangcheon, from when we initially visited the school. But it also seems like this place is, well, where I live, and not where I just moved to.

I wonder if it has to do with our life last year. We lived in Busan, in a foreign country, away from everyone, together but alone, keeping comparatively to ourselves. Here, it’s the same, although we have more co-workers who came from North America.

In Busan, we went out to eat frequently. Sometimes once or twice a week, but also five or six times a week. Sometimes it was easier and more effective than buying a bunch of groceries and trying to use them all between just two people. In Gwangcheon, though, we’ve been out to eat only a few times, and one of those times was a company dinner. We cook much more often.

I think it helps that we eat breakfast more often, too. When we first started working, we had so much to do that we would go to bed around nine or ten at night. Sometimes even eight, which is about four or five hours earlier than I would normally go to bed. We would get up earlier than we’d need to, so we’d make breakfast. In Busan I got into the habit of not eating breakfast. Now we eat breakfast more often, which means we can afford to buy more groceries because we’ll use them up. (Well, usually. I bought a bag of potatoes and used quite a few, but after a few days of not using them, perhaps a week and a half after the purchase, the rest of them sprouted massively.)

Sometimes I feel like I’m not in Korea. I go to work, where I share an office with six other fluent English speakers. I go to class and teach Korean students, but most of them have skills equivalent to or better than the high school students I taught last year (I guess it’s not that difficult a feat). Then I go home and talk to my English-speaking, American wife. Even walking downtown feels slightly less like Korea. In Busan, I practiced reading Hangeul by reading signs. Lots of them, all the time. We’re not in the city, so the signs are less frequent. In Busan, we’d get on a bus everyday, either to go to work or to go get food. Now we generally get on a bus once a week, to go into Hongseong. It’s more analogous to living in Berrien Springs. I didn’t ride buses in Berrien Springs (except school buses).

Well, I guess that’s all I have to say for the moment. The next post will just be a slideshow of some pictures I finally took of our surroundings.

We had a break this week. Last week we had Wednesday off because of a national election-based holiday. This week, both Tuesday and Wednesday offered a bit of rest. I say only a bit because we still went to work. The difference was what we did once we got there.

Tuesday was “Science Day.” This meant that the students did special projects. Some students built plastic-bottle rockets, while others put together puppy robots or played with something very similar to Erector Sets. The very young students only drew, but according to Ashley, they drew science-inspired things like space houses, underwater schools and apartments, people flying with rocket shoes, diamond-growing trees, and so on.

Something I haven’t explained about our school yet is our grade level system. I’m going to divert the stream of this post to discuss that before carrying on further. Our school is an elementary school, and like all Korean elementary schools, we have grades 1-6. We also have six foreign teachers. Each of us is assigned to a grade. I have grade 4, I assume because I have the highest level of interaction with that grade. I teach a handful of second graders, about half of the third graders, a few fifth graders, and about half of the sixth graders. Unless I’m mistaken, however, I teach all of the fourth graders. Just not at the same time.

The way our school works is that classes are divided into proficiency levels, at least for when it’s time to go to English class. So when, for example, it’s time for fourth graders to go to their English-version science class, some of them stay in their homeroom with their Korean teacher, and their English teacher comes to them. The rest of them go to the English side of the building and have class with the foreign teacher, without the assistance of a Korean teacher (these are the higher level students). For conversation classes, there can even be three or four levels.

So for fourth grade, I teach language arts to the Ruby students in their homeroom (Ruby is the lowest level, while Amethyst is the highest, although most classes are split between Ruby and Emerald), and I teach science to the Emerald students. Between science and language arts, then, I see all of the fourth graders. I also have some of the Emerald students in conversation class with a few fifth graders.

Anyway, because I’m assigned to fourth grade, I check their English journals every week. Students have to write one entry in an English diary/journal each week, and we mark their diaries. And for any special occurrence or activity, we go and help in whatever way we can, including for Science Day. We went to our classrooms and…watched the students build their rockets or assemble their puppy robots or draw their gemstone-yielding vegetation. Our head teacher had told us just to go for a short while, though, because there wasn’t much for us to do.

After an hour or two, the head teacher and I went outside, because the students that had built rockets were gathering to launch their rockets, and we wanted to watch. So I took some pictures, spending most of my time trying to get a picture as the rocket was leaving the launching apparatus. It turned out to be rather difficult. If you press the shutter at one moment, you get a picture of a stationary rocket. If you press the shutter the next moment, you get a picture of a stationary, but empty, rocket-launching apparatus.

Exhibit A: Two deadbeat rockets just sitting there.

Students waiting outside for their turn at the launchers.

Two students saw me taking pictures and posed. Not sure if they thought I was trying to take their picture or if they just decided that I was going to take their picture.

HaHAH!

Blast-off!

This one sadly landed within the frame of the picture.

So that was a bit of fun, and the next day was our rescheduled field trip. The school had thought the weather on Friday was going to be bad, so they rescheduled it to Wednesday. The first, second, and third grade classes went to a museum and folk village (Ashley is assigned with the second graders, so she went with them; actually the three female foreign teachers are with the lower three grades, while the three male foreign teachers are with the higher three grades). I went with grades four, five, and six to 용봉산 (Yongbongsan, or Yongbong Mountain) for a hike. I had a lot of fun. We went hiking, we stopped to eat lunch and share snacks at the top of the hill, and then we went back down. I really enjoyed that mountain, too. It’s a good mountain. I think I’m partial to mountains that let me walk all over big boulders, though, which may explain part of my satisfaction with the trip.

The rest of my satisfaction may have been a bit of schadenfraude, though. It was funny to hear the students complaining about the strenuousness of the hike. Early on in the hike, one student who was talking to me said, “Teacher, I don’t know why we came here. It is not beautiful. This is not trip. This is like punish.” She did later admit, though, that it was beautiful. Once we were higher up and could see other peaks and into the valleys.

Hike commencing in 5...4...3...2...1...

We've but gone a stone's throw and it's time for a rest. Okay, maybe eight or nine stones' throws. And maybe by a pretty strong arm. In any case, you can see we're still on the paved road. This was the break before starting the hike proper, before going into those trees and onto dirt-and-rock paths. Before the point of no return. (Really. The buses left after this, to wait for us on the other side.)

And up we go.

The peak, as seen from somewhere much lower on the mountain.

Some unhappy students.

But onward we march! Or climb.

Going around a corner. This was probably the scariest moment for some students because the path was rather narrow and a bit steep.

And on the edge of the mountain.

Shortly after crossing that area...break time! There was an ajumma (literally "married woman" but more often it refers to Korean women middle-aged and older) selling popsicles and cold drinks, so most of us contributed to her mountaintop business.

Very strange. Flat, sparse land and suddenly a block of tall buildings. I think one of the Korean teachers said it will be a new city.

And finally, the descent.

Many of you may have been wondering, “what do Brian and Ashley do all day over there in Korea?” While I can’t answer for Brian, as I haven’t memorized his schedule, I hope that this brief post will help you conceptualize the structure of my working day. (note that our working hours are from 8:20-4:30, but actual school ends around 2:40. You never can tell in Korea, since the students all stay at school after normal classes are over)

Here’s my weekly schedule:

~My weekly schedule. Mondays are the busiest!

You can see that I’ve highlighted each class with a different color to keep everything orderly in my mind. When I first looked at my schedule it was overwhelming, but now I realize how good I’ve got it compared to some of the other teachers!

Here are some important features of my schedule:

  • I have 1st periods free Monday-Thursdays! (on Mondays everyone has 1st period free)
  • I have no classes after lunch on Fridays! (Also we go home at 2:30)
  •  The number after the class name denotes grade level. Social Studies 1 is  first grade Social Studies. Con 2,3 is a conversation class for second and third graders.
  • Ruby/Sapphire/Emerald are the students’ English levels. Ruby is low and Emerald is high.  I teach a lot of low level. It can be brutal at times!
  • The title that appears after the  gem levels belongs to the the course text book. Sixth grade Language Arts  is reading Shining Star A right now.
  • The room number lets me know where I  have to go to teach the class. Room 1 is the first grade homeroom, room 2 is the second grade homeroom etc. E1 means English classroom 1. Instead of meeting with the students in their home room, we have class on the “English side” of the school, closer to our office. Generally we meet with low levels in their homeroom (where the Korean teacher can assist with translation if necessary) and higher levels in the English rooms.

My last teaching hour of each day is ASP, which stands for After School Program. Some of the parents pay extra to have their kids stay for this extra “class.” We do have a textbook, but this class is generally considered glorified babysitting by some.

My class, however, consists of ten high-level first grade students. So, although the schedule says I should be teaching them in the homeroom, I actually use E1. The other ASP 1 teacher has lower-level 1st grade ASP and she was having a hard time without the Korean teacher’s help, so we switched. My class tends to speed through the easy workbook–and once they finish they want to be out the door–so I have to come up with extra activities and songs to keep them occupied for the full 40 mins.Hhaha. (The parents complain if they see their kids get out of ASP early).

Yesterday, since it was the last Thursday of the month, my ASP class had a snack party and watched Tom and Jerry. In Korea, kids bring their own snacks for parties. They even bring snacks for the teacher! I received an orange juice, an assortment of chips and a candy bar.

Songs aren’t just useful for ASP, though. With first grade, I use the Please Be Quiet song almost daily. Sometimes I try to play the air guitar (lamely). It doesn’t make them be quiet, but it helps them practice using those cherubic singing voices of theirs. Also, they love imitating the characters on the screen, or answering “NO” in response to the song’s request to “please be quiet.”

“Teacher, please be quiet!” the first graders shout, but they’re only asking for me to play the song.
